description: Office 365 is a cloud based productivity suite for individuals, companies and even government agencies. It is designed to deliver software as service to any and every user regardless of location. The Office 365 solution is designed to relieve the technical challenge of software management and delivery, regardless of location from the local IT personnel. This allows the IT professional to focus in implementing, deploying and operating Office 365 services and administrating supporting technologies, like email, collaboration and storage. If you’re an IT professional who takes part in evaluating, planning, deploying, and operating the Office 365 services, including its dependencies, requirements, and supporting technologies this series will demonstrate and help you to see what is involved in setting up Office 365 for your organization.

If you’re an IT professional who takes part in evaluating, planning, deploying, and operating the Office 365 services, including its dependencies, requirements, and supporting technologies this series will demonstrate and help you to see what is involved in setting up Office 365 for your organization.
name: Microsoft Office 365 - 70-346 (2017)
subtitle: Managing Office 365 Identities and Requirements

If I flip on over here,

00:02:23.807 --> 00:02:26.647
Here is the latest exam

00:02:26.647 --> 00:02:29.411
to the site that they've changed here, and

you can see where it says, document

00:02:34.132 --> 00:02:38.196
These changes were

00:02:38.196 --> 00:02:43.170
You wanna make sure that you are prepared

So this is not meant for someone is just

56

know it means it's gonna be much more

or if you're not familiar with

So my suggestions, of course,

this first exam, make sure you also

objectives there as well to understand

understand those products too, okay?

So that way you'll be familiar with some

about this way too.

So once you have that in your mind and

68
00:04:19.598 --> 00:04:24.196
Underneath the provisioning,

What does that actually mean?

82
00:05:07.191 --> 00:05:12.043
As well as understanding the use

112

114

115

116

118

119

120

121

122
00:07:44.412 --> 00:07:46.874
So make sure you pay attention there too.

123
00:07:46.874 --> 00:07:52.124

124
00:07:52.124 --> 00:07:56.474

125

126
00:08:00.155 --> 00:08:04.544

127
00:08:04.544 --> 00:08:08.237
So, if you're ready to do that,
join us in the very next episode.

128
00:08:08.237 --> 00:08:14.379
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie introduce how to setup an Office 365 tenant. They introduce the basic tenant provision steps.  They review the best practices for tenant account provisioning.
episodes.title: Provision Office365 Tenants

35
00:02:01.920 --> 00:02:04.870
>> Okay, Ronnie, so what if I've
identified the need for this shift or

00:02:17.290 --> 00:02:21.800
So don't mistake this idea of just saying,

43
00:02:21.800 --> 00:02:25.650
You wanna make sure that as we start to

44
00:02:25.650 --> 00:02:30.090
Office 365 for our company,

45
00:02:30.090 --> 00:02:32.470
our organization, or
maybe even for somebody else.

46
00:02:32.470 --> 00:02:34.360
You're working for somebody else and
you're having to provision it for

47
00:02:34.360 --> 00:02:39.260
them, but you wanna keep in mind some very
simple things that are going to happen.

48
00:02:39.260 --> 00:02:43.610
And it's not super technical at

49

a little bit more attention to

I know it sounds strange, but

it's something that you're really gonna

We also, of course then at that point,

would actually select either

Or if your company has already decided

00:03:40.930 --> 00:03:42.800
they wanna start off
with something simple.

69
00:03:42.800 --> 00:03:45.370
You can do that as well and

organizational information on

So that's what we want to prepare for

Because if you misstep you might find

454
00:25:45.110 --> 00:25:49.320
to move forward because there's still
some more stuff that we have to cover,

455
00:25:49.320 --> 00:25:51.790
such as how do we handle
things like updates?

456
00:25:51.790 --> 00:25:56.477
And how do we get the Office 365 out to
other users inside of our organization

457
00:25:56.477 --> 00:26:01.031
besides a guy who's actually managing or
administrating it at this point?

458
00:26:01.031 --> 00:26:02.499
We need to deal with all that.

459
00:26:02.499 --> 00:26:05.030
And that's gonna be coming up
in future episodes as well.

460
00:26:05.030 --> 00:26:08.077
So Cherokee, there's a lot more for
us to cover in Office 365.

461
00:26:08.077 --> 00:26:09.640
>> All right, well,
thank you for being with us.

462
00:26:09.640 --> 00:26:13.138
And I look forward to you navigating
us through that additional information.

463
00:26:13.138 --> 00:26:14.786
And stay tuned, you don't wanna miss that.

464
00:26:14.786 --> 00:26:17.330
But for this show,
we are gonna go ahead and sign out.

465
00:26:17.330 --> 00:26:18.920
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

466
00:26:18.920 --> 00:26:19.606
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

467
00:26:19.606 --> 00:26:22.256
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

468
00:26:22.256 --> 00:26:28.225
[MUSIC]

469
00:26:28.225 --> 00:26:31.177
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie use the Office 365 Admin Center to configure the tenant for new features and updates.  They describe the use and show where to configure these settings for the tenant.  They remind us that this only affects software that has been downloaded with those settings not software setup with different settings.
episodes.title: Configure for New Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.149

2
00:00:01.149 --> 00:00:02.576
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:02.576 --> 00:00:08.238
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.238 --> 00:00:10.603
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.603 --> 00:00:15.080
>> Welcome to your
Managing Office 365 show.

6
00:00:15.080 --> 00:00:16.890
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.890 --> 00:00:20.200
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at different types of

ways we can configure and

9

And back with us today in studios,

Thank you for having me on the show

And realizing that it is about software

The entire Office suite and

Remember that when we get an Office

And that's what we need to be able to do.

>> Well, this isn't like that historical

you would go into one of those big box

go ahead and download and install it.

23
00:01:07.810 --> 00:01:10.960
So what are we looking at with this

00:01:10.960 --> 00:01:15.040
Well, the question modern

Cherokee is really going back to there

physical software and making sure that we

You would then of course have to actually

In an enterprise, in a home user,

that's probably not exactly

But when you start talk on an enterprise

that idea sounds horrific in today,

I can't imagine moving around

And then having the product key and

So during this time, at least for

And the very fact that we've probably

either deploy it using some type of

Or even pushing it out using group policy,

45
00:02:31.710 --> 00:02:35.290
Okay, now when you start talking
about those two items, right?

00:02:35.290 --> 00:02:37.640
We're now getting more into
deployment technology.

47
00:02:37.640 --> 00:02:40.690
We're now getting into
more enterprise features.

48
00:02:40.690 --> 00:02:45.670
But Office 365 is designed actually for,
well, all environments, right?

49
00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:49.450
Whether you're a home user, whether
you're actually a small business user,

50
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:51.160
whether you're an enterprise user.

51
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:53.650
Whether you're a government
user it wants to go and

00:02:53.650 --> 00:02:56.260
do everything that what we've

00:02:56.260 --> 00:02:59.200
One, get the software to you, okay.

Two, manage the licensing that we have.

And then three, which is probably the one

than anything else is how do we manage
things like new features that come out and

00:03:11.870 --> 00:03:14.040
updates that come out as well.

58
00:03:14.040 --> 00:03:17.760
And that's where it becomes
a bit more challenging, okay?

59
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:22.050
So when we start to take a look at this
particular aspect of what we're talking

60
00:03:22.050 --> 00:03:22.880
about, okay.

00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:26.190
We need to discuss this

So, Cherokee, when we start talking about

What do we normally talk about?

What are the two types of technology

>> Okay, so that like you had referenced

00:03:47.790 --> 00:03:51.020
an enterprise solution like System Center

And then we also have that C2R for

00:03:54.848 --> 00:03:58.970
>> Right, yeah, those two are probably the

00:03:58.970 --> 00:04:03.640
the deployment server that we have if we
choose to run that inside of an image or

anything else that we choose.

But those are kind of the big ones.

00:04:06.310 --> 00:04:09.210
MSI and then Click to Run,

75

C2R, these are other ways that we also

76
00:04:14.600 --> 00:04:18.234
Now, whenever we start to talk
about this idea of using an MSI,

77
00:04:18.234 --> 00:04:21.395
it actually is easily deployable.

78
00:04:21.395 --> 00:04:25.450
They've kinda packaged everything

once we have the Microsoft Installer,

00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:36.500
We can download that
MSI to a local machine,

run that MSI, and then install software.

82
00:04:39.750 --> 00:04:43.394
Now, in that sense, though, Cherokee,

can you think of any drawbacks with

84
00:04:46.742 --> 00:04:51.050
>> Okay, so kind of going back
to that old school DVD or

CD sitting there on the shelf,

00:04:52.770 --> 00:04:58.390
sometimes you have to worry about that
MSI file not being current or up to date.

87
00:04:58.390 --> 00:05:01.140
>> Yeah,
that's kind of the biggest thing, right?

88
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:03.870
Is that your MSI,
you don't know how old it could be.

00:05:03.870 --> 00:05:05.660
It's just like the DVD.

How long has it been sitting on the shelf?

Let's say, it's been sitting there for

00:05:09.950 --> 00:05:11.480
Well, how old is the MSI?

Well, if I deployed it

If I'm not the most vigilant of admins,

00:05:19.420 --> 00:05:22.320
that MSI could be sitting there for

00:05:22.320 --> 00:05:26.940
I deploy that to a group of computers,

And then you go, okay, well, let's do some

And then you're kind of like,

No, we're not joking you, it does

So an MSI is good, don't get me wrong,

You have to kind of redeploy a new

00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:04.700
Now, that's not as bad as it sounds but

When we start talking

Okay, the Click-to-Run is actually unusual

That allows us to go ahead and install but

Now, that sounds a little bit

>> I don't know, I just did that

00:06:29.485 --> 00:06:30.287
I love that.

00:06:30.287 --> 00:06:33.075
You can start to listen before

00:06:33.075 --> 00:06:33.895
And that's because, what?

118
00:06:33.895 --> 00:06:35.445
It's based off of streaming, right?

119
00:06:35.445 --> 00:06:37.725
>> Yeah, because the streaming
technology says, sure,

00:06:37.725 --> 00:06:39.780
let's play this while

121
00:06:39.780 --> 00:06:41.245
>> [LAUGHS]
>> To me, coming from over,

00:06:41.245 --> 00:06:42.875
I'm like, how, what?

00:06:42.875 --> 00:06:45.145
I can't believe that they're

00:06:45.145 --> 00:06:46.240
But they are.

125
00:06:46.240 --> 00:06:51.600
>> And this idea of the Click-to-Run is
pretty much the one that Office 365 says,

00:06:51.600 --> 00:06:55.290
this is what we really want to do.

127
00:06:55.290 --> 00:07:01.830
Now, in your organization, if you're not

00:07:01.830 --> 00:07:07.880
If you're not migrating
100% over to Office 365 for

00:07:07.880 --> 00:07:09.830
the deployment of your office products.

00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:15.720
Then you're gonna end up seeing maybe
a hybridized approach in this way.

131
00:07:15.720 --> 00:07:19.480
Some of your organization,
which is still going to be out there

00:07:19.480 --> 00:07:23.960
with infrastructure internally on

133
00:07:23.960 --> 00:07:26.350
You're still going to be

it is very possible that you may see that.

135
00:07:28.272 --> 00:07:32.876
But then it may be your newer users who

136
00:07:32.876 --> 00:07:36.232
subscription running,
that you may see where everything is

137
00:07:36.232 --> 00:07:39.223
actually deployed with a C2R,
or Click-to- run.

138
00:07:39.223 --> 00:07:45.130
Which allows them to simply sign on

139
00:07:45.130 --> 00:07:47.874
Click on the link where it says to click

140
00:07:47.874 --> 00:07:49.679

141
00:07:49.679 --> 00:07:54.507
And begin using some of those

142
00:07:54.507 --> 00:07:59.259
then install, and then you're
still using it at the same time.

143
00:07:59.259 --> 00:08:03.632
So it is all possible that his is
something that Office 365 really does

like, and
doing something like this, right?

00:08:06.820 --> 00:08:08.609
You might be wondering like I did,

00:08:08.609 --> 00:08:12.621

00:08:12.621 --> 00:08:16.534

very valuable to Office 365 to do?

00:08:16.534 --> 00:08:21.295
And those are questions that we'd really

00:08:21.295 --> 00:08:23.796

00:08:23.796 --> 00:08:28.761
The Click-to-Run, it really has
its advantage in this fact, okay?

00:08:28.761 --> 00:08:36.109
Anytime then for Office 365 users, if you

152
00:08:36.109 --> 00:08:39.913
When you download it from

you're not getting the edition that's

00:08:46.460 --> 00:08:50.540
You're not getting that, you're getting
whatever the edition is at the end

155
00:08:50.540 --> 00:08:53.460

156
00:08:53.460 --> 00:08:56.800
In that life cycle, the live,
the most up-to-date,

157
00:08:56.800 --> 00:08:59.910
one that you can get
at that point in time.

158
00:08:59.910 --> 00:09:00.920
So whenever you download it,

159
00:09:00.920 --> 00:09:04.500
you're not just downloading from a library

160
00:09:04.500 --> 00:09:08.130
You're downloading from Microsoft,
their latest available edition

161
00:09:08.130 --> 00:09:11.710
in that particular cycle

162
00:09:11.710 --> 00:09:16.472
And so that means you are constantly
pretty much up-to-date when

163
00:09:16.472 --> 00:09:20.479
you download that software
directly to your computer.

164
00:09:20.479 --> 00:09:26.650
Think about what that saves us then

165
00:09:26.650 --> 00:09:32.590
When I think about that idea of an MSI,
and it's a file that's six months old,

166
00:09:32.590 --> 00:09:36.030
the security then in six month's
time could have lapsed so

167
00:09:36.030 --> 00:09:38.780
badly that,
that may be a vulnerability, right?

168
00:09:38.780 --> 00:09:42.180
>> Most definitely, and at least if I know
that I'm getting the most current and

169
00:09:42.180 --> 00:09:44.370
latest and greatest version.

170
00:09:44.370 --> 00:09:47.120
I'm hoping that those security
issues have already been addressed,

171
00:09:47.120 --> 00:09:48.660
they're from Microsoft's side.

172
00:09:48.660 --> 00:09:51.850
>> Yeah, at lease they have
actually addressed from that point

173
00:09:51.850 --> 00:09:52.840
that they know of.

174
00:09:52.840 --> 00:09:57.070
Up in that point where you're downloading
it, you're getting that latest feature.

175
00:09:57.070 --> 00:10:01.932
So in that sense, you'll probably see that
the Click-to-Run is gonna be preferred

176
00:10:01.932 --> 00:10:05.860
from the Microsoft Office standpoint or
Office 365 standpoint.

177
00:10:05.860 --> 00:10:09.755
Now the key here is for
the decision maker to understand, right?

178
00:10:09.755 --> 00:10:14.080
The decision maker needs to know this
one thing which is gonna be key.

179
00:10:15.270 --> 00:10:21.330
If you're trying to, not if you're trying,
if you're already running the MSI

180
00:10:21.330 --> 00:10:28.750
install of Office 2016 on your computer,
somehow, some way that you got that, okay?

181
00:10:28.750 --> 00:10:34.440
You cannot actually run the Click-to-Run
version side by side with it,

182
00:10:34.440 --> 00:10:35.230
it would not work.

183
00:10:35.230 --> 00:10:39.624
You'll have to uninstall the previous
one and then run the Click-to-Run.

184
00:10:39.624 --> 00:10:44.073
If you're running the Click-to-Run
you can't install the MSI version on

185
00:10:44.073 --> 00:10:46.250
the same computer as well.

186
00:10:46.250 --> 00:10:51.142
So they are not compatible, make sure
you understand that before you start to

187
00:10:51.142 --> 00:10:54.994
move forward with your Office
365 plans and deployment.

188
00:10:54.994 --> 00:10:59.057
You wanna make sure that you talk that
over with whoever it is that you need to

189
00:10:59.057 --> 00:11:00.650
as you move forward.

190
00:11:00.650 --> 00:11:03.360
If somebody is sticking
to their guns saying,

191
00:11:03.360 --> 00:11:07.490
you're not getting rid of our
deployment now in this, okay?

192
00:11:07.490 --> 00:11:11.980
Well, that means you gotta consider what
is gonna happen if people would say,

193
00:11:11.980 --> 00:11:15.980
I wanna run this, and
then their office installation fails them

194
00:11:15.980 --> 00:11:18.410
because you're running the Click-to-Run,
okay?

195
00:11:18.410 --> 00:11:24.160
So, just kind of be aware of that
before you start to move in a different

196
00:11:24.160 --> 00:11:28.020
direction, than what your organization
is really wanting you to push towards.

197
00:11:28.020 --> 00:11:32.870
So, that one fact alone is enough to
kind of cause a lot of heartaches,

198
00:11:32.870 --> 00:11:34.570
if you are not paying attention.

199
00:11:34.570 --> 00:11:39.407
And you go that's great, yeah, we used to
that, but now that we're doing Office 365,

200
00:11:39.407 --> 00:11:41.648
just install right over your old 2013.

201
00:11:41.648 --> 00:11:44.840
It's not gonna work,
it's not gonna happen that way, so

202
00:11:44.840 --> 00:11:48.245
you'll have to remove that first,
so do that as well, okay?

203
00:11:48.245 --> 00:11:51.770
All right so, how does this end
up really working then, okay?

204
00:11:51.770 --> 00:11:55.672
With especially the features and
the updates, okay?

205
00:11:55.672 --> 00:12:00.727

00:25:04.760 --> 00:25:06.800
service updates from Office 365.

430
00:25:06.800 --> 00:25:14.420
So, if I click on Edit,
this is where you can see how it's done.

431
00:25:14.420 --> 00:25:19.762
And you'll see that even for
at this point, a couple of things, right?

432
00:25:19.762 --> 00:25:22.260
Even though they have
changed the terminology,

433
00:25:22.260 --> 00:25:25.905
they've even changed terminology
here inside of Office 365.

434
00:25:25.905 --> 00:25:28.640
It's not the same as what
we just talked about.

435
00:25:28.640 --> 00:25:31.370
So I wish I could say,
yes this is gonna match up.

436
00:25:31.370 --> 00:25:35.640
But no it's just standard release,
if you want everybody to go ahead and

437
00:25:35.640 --> 00:25:39.970
get early notice first release for
everyone you can change that.

438
00:25:39.970 --> 00:25:44.430
You want to just do a test group
you can select this one instead.

439
00:25:44.430 --> 00:25:48.040
You name it that's something
you can also see and do.

440
00:25:48.040 --> 00:25:50.970
>> Okay Ronnie so once you just
showed us that configuration change.

441
00:25:50.970 --> 00:25:51.890
Since we're already here in

442
00:25:51.890 --> 00:25:54.710
the interface is there anything
else you'd like to share with us?

443
00:25:54.710 --> 00:25:57.360
>> Right, there's actually one other
place that we need to change this but

444
00:25:57.360 --> 00:26:02.200
in my brand new Office 365 tenet that I've
created, I haven't downloaded anything, so

445
00:26:02.200 --> 00:26:03.820
it's not gonna appear
where it needs to be.

446
00:26:03.820 --> 00:26:09.700
So I'm gonna switch over to another Office
365 account right here that we're running.

447
00:26:09.700 --> 00:26:11.170
Yes, this is the one for Joey here.

448
00:26:11.170 --> 00:26:12.670
>> I was gonna say,
look at the background.

449
00:26:12.670 --> 00:26:13.210
>> Believe it or not, I know, right?
>> [INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]

450
00:26:13.210 --> 00:26:16.310
>> This means that Vaughn is actually

451
00:26:16.310 --> 00:26:18.480
who's been administrating this one for
us here.

452
00:26:18.480 --> 00:26:21.480
So I'm gonna switch on
over to the admin center.

453
00:26:21.480 --> 00:26:24.800
From there I'm going to select,
where as I going?

454
00:26:24.800 --> 00:26:30.400
I was going underneath settings here and
then services and add-ins.

455
00:26:30.400 --> 00:26:35.490
And under services and add-ins if I
scroll down I should be able to find this

456
00:26:35.490 --> 00:26:41.750
link right here which says Office
software download settings.

457
00:26:41.750 --> 00:26:48.770
And if I click on that link,
And I scroll down here, okay?

458
00:26:48.770 --> 00:26:53.170
Notice that here they show
the updated feature ready.

459
00:26:53.170 --> 00:26:59.830
How often do you want users to get
feature updates for Office 2016 apps?

460
00:26:59.830 --> 00:27:03.740
So, notice they really only
give me two options here.

461
00:27:03.740 --> 00:27:08.300
Whereas before they gave me that
semi-annual targeted and that semi annual.

462
00:27:08.300 --> 00:27:11.540
Remember that semi-annual
means every six months, right?

463
00:27:11.540 --> 00:27:13.665
Usually in January and July.

464
00:27:13.665 --> 00:27:17.670
Whereas the targeted staggers
that a little bit, so

465
00:27:17.670 --> 00:27:22.260
that you're about two months after
the July, or the January release.

466
00:27:22.260 --> 00:27:26.280
So, in March is when that semi-annual
target would be, and that gives you

467
00:27:26.280 --> 00:27:30.070
a little bit before the next time that
the new update actually releases.

468
00:27:30.070 --> 00:27:34.350
It's more for the idea of you testing out
to see if you want to actually update to

469
00:27:34.350 --> 00:27:36.350
that new feature or not.

470
00:27:36.350 --> 00:27:38.080
So you'll have that, too.

471
00:27:38.080 --> 00:27:40.720
And notice that the Mac version
doesn't actually give us any.

472
00:27:40.720 --> 00:27:43.100
Let me see, if I expand this one out here.

473
00:27:43.100 --> 00:27:47.530
No, even the Mac version here doesn't have
that particular update for us as well.

474
00:27:47.530 --> 00:27:52.020
So this is one of those where you wanna
pay attention to both of those settings.

475
00:27:52.020 --> 00:27:56.980
So whether they're underneath
your organizational profile and

476
00:27:56.980 --> 00:28:00.480
then right here under
the release preferences.

477
00:28:00.480 --> 00:28:05.660
Then you may also have to go
into services and add ons and

478
00:28:05.660 --> 00:28:10.260
from there also office,
software, download settings.

479
00:28:10.260 --> 00:28:13.650
Both of those are locations
that you may have to check out

480
00:28:13.650 --> 00:28:17.650
as you're having to reset this if that's
what you're going to do to change your

481
00:28:17.650 --> 00:28:21.040
organization over into those
preferences that you want to instead.

482
00:28:21.040 --> 00:28:25.080
So by understanding that,
that will then set up your organization.

483
00:28:25.080 --> 00:28:29.590
Either be on that fast track that we want
to or the idea of the monthly release.

484
00:28:29.590 --> 00:28:33.830
Or the former current releases
is what they call it, and

485
00:28:33.830 --> 00:28:36.240
then either the semi-annual,
the semi-annual target or

486
00:28:36.240 --> 00:28:39.810
those two differed channel
releases as well, okay?

487
00:28:39.810 --> 00:28:42.040
So take a look at those, remember that
you'll actually see the links for

488
00:28:42.040 --> 00:28:45.390
those in our show notes as well, and that
will give you that ability to compare and

489
00:28:45.390 --> 00:28:47.180
contrast them a little bit more.

490
00:28:47.180 --> 00:28:50.976
But Cherokee, that should help us to
get started, and at least keep our,

491
00:28:50.976 --> 00:28:53.747
you know, Office 2016 up to date,
if we need to.

492
00:28:53.747 --> 00:28:56.053
>> System up to date, our applications
there, so thank you for that.

493
00:28:56.053 --> 00:29:00.290
I do feel confident with that, and
then at least now I can make the decision.

494
00:29:00.290 --> 00:29:03.480
I have enough education to say, hey,
do I want to be on the fast track,

495
00:29:03.480 --> 00:29:05.640
the slow track, or
how do I want to receive these updates.

496
00:29:05.640 --> 00:29:06.920
So thank you for that.

497
00:29:06.920 --> 00:29:10.520
And thank you for joining us as well,
but we are out of time for this episode.

498
00:29:10.520 --> 00:29:14.100
Stay tuned for more great information,
but for this show, we'll sign out.

499
00:29:14.100 --> 00:29:15.620
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

500
00:29:15.620 --> 00:29:16.340
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

501
00:29:16.340 --> 00:29:21.051
>> See you next time here at ITPro.TV.

502
00:29:21.051 --> 00:29:24.730
[MUSIC]

503
00:29:24.730 --> 00:29:26.964
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie explain some basic DNS concepts to help setup Office 365 to work with a Custom Domain Name. They describe how to add a custom domain name and work with DNS records to make it work with Office 365.
episodes.title: Add and Configure Custom Domain
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.090
Welcome to IT Pro.TV.

2
00:00:01.090 --> 00:00:02.987
I'm your host, Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:02.987 --> 00:00:06.952
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:06.952 --> 00:00:11.039
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.039 --> 00:00:13.464
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:13.464 --> 00:00:15.576
Helping you to learn everywhere you go.

7
00:00:15.576 --> 00:00:18.379
I'm Zach Memos and
your host for Office 365.

8
00:00:18.379 --> 00:00:19.572
I'm with Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:19.572 --> 00:00:22.951
And we're gonna add and
configure custom domains right now.

10
00:00:22.951 --> 00:00:24.019
Ronnie, what's that all about?

11
00:00:24.019 --> 00:00:27.680
>> Well, when we take a look at
the idea here on Office 365,

12
00:00:27.680 --> 00:00:31.054
we start to actually realize
something that we already

13
00:00:31.054 --> 00:00:35.410
got an existing infrastructure
that we're probably already using.

14
00:00:35.410 --> 00:00:40.485
And we are now adding in
Office 365 as a component.

15
00:00:40.485 --> 00:00:43.588
Now the problem that we
have is relatively simple.

16
00:00:43.588 --> 00:00:46.397
That when we start to add
something like this in,

17
00:00:46.397 --> 00:00:49.206
it means that, well,
what we need to also figure

18
00:00:49.206 --> 00:00:53.195
out how do we get well what we have
existing to work along with the new.

19
00:00:53.195 --> 00:00:55.522
In other words the Office 365 here.

20
00:00:55.522 --> 00:00:59.450
So what we're actually doing when we start
talking about configuring an additional

21
00:00:59.450 --> 00:01:01.783
domain is to take what you
have in your work place.

22
00:01:01.783 --> 00:01:04.813
So, for example, right here at ITPro.TV,

23
00:01:04.813 --> 00:01:08.819
on the Internet it's just ITPro.TV,
that's my domain.

24
00:01:08.819 --> 00:01:13.394
But when we configured the initial setup
that we did in previous episodes on

25
00:01:13.394 --> 00:01:14.419
Office 365.

26
00:01:14.419 --> 00:01:19.075
What we actually ended up
configuring was essentially

27
00:01:19.075 --> 00:01:25.362
the itprotvdemocode.onmicrosoft.com,
and that is another domain.

28
00:01:25.362 --> 00:01:29.632
So today we're gonna actually kind of take
a look at how we are able to well really

29
00:01:29.632 --> 00:01:32.134
start to use what I
already have in existence.

30
00:01:32.134 --> 00:01:37.901
My itprotv.demoaccount and domain name
to actually work with Office 365 and

31
00:01:37.901 --> 00:01:42.224
get things to start rolling there
where I can configure it for

32
00:01:42.224 --> 00:01:46.060
things like email as well as Skype for
Business.

33
00:01:46.060 --> 00:01:49.622
And even some of my files and
SharePoint stuff that I need to.

34
00:01:49.622 --> 00:01:54.268
So all that has to happen if we really
want to kind of have a seamless

35
00:01:54.268 --> 00:01:57.401
transition by using Office 365, okay?

36
00:01:57.401 --> 00:01:59.912
So that begins with us
actually taking a look at,

37
00:01:59.912 --> 00:02:03.800
actually configuring something
like DNS and making sure it works.

38
00:02:03.800 --> 00:02:05.811
>> So we're going to be looking
at human-readable names and

39
00:02:05.811 --> 00:02:06.762
things like that, right?

40
00:02:06.762 --> 00:02:10.018
>> Yes, we are, so,
in the idea here, as we begin, so

41
00:02:10.018 --> 00:02:14.760
let's make sure that we have at least
a basic understanding of DNS, right?

42
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:17.303
So we're gonna just do
a little bit of a primer,

43
00:02:17.303 --> 00:02:19.728
we're not going really
deep into DNS at all.

44
00:02:19.728 --> 00:02:24.254
But just as a stand point to get us ready
and familiar with some of the things that

45
00:02:24.254 --> 00:02:28.868
we'll actually have to actually be able
to do and get setup to do as well, okay?

46
00:02:28.868 --> 00:02:32.870
So when you start talking about the idea
of human readable names, right?

47
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:37.125
Zach, on the Internet right now there
are so many different machines out there.

48
00:02:37.125 --> 00:02:41.501
But the way that they communicate is
they learn about each other by their IP

49
00:02:41.501 --> 00:02:42.287
addresses.

50
00:02:42.287 --> 00:02:43.370
And computers can do that,

51
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:45.593
it doesn't matter how many
IP addresses are out there.

52
00:02:45.593 --> 00:02:50.802
There can be billions of them, and
my computer, right here in the studio,

53
00:02:50.802 --> 00:02:55.035
can find any one of them if I know
what the other IP address is.

54
00:02:55.035 --> 00:02:57.864
So it can actually do that,
but the very fact is,

55
00:02:57.864 --> 00:03:01.867
the computer's not really caring
what machine I really connect to.

56
00:03:01.867 --> 00:03:03.297
I'm the one that cares and

57
00:03:03.297 --> 00:03:06.619
I'm not gonna remember every IP
address that I need to go to.

58
00:03:06.619 --> 00:03:11.502
So instead there's a naming system that's
been developed out there that allows

59
00:03:11.502 --> 00:03:16.017
us to be able to say, when I type this
name into a browser or when I want to make

60
00:03:16.017 --> 00:03:20.751
a connection to that machine, I just have
to type in something that I can read,

61
00:03:20.751 --> 00:03:24.556
that the machine can then translate
into those IP addresses and

62
00:03:24.556 --> 00:03:26.330
make the connection for me.

63
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:28.740
And that system of course is DNS,

64
00:03:28.740 --> 00:03:33.879
Domain Naming System is what that
particular service is called.

65
00:03:33.879 --> 00:03:34.734
>> DNS.
>> Yep, so

66
00:03:34.734 --> 00:03:39.544
DNS exists out there on the Internet, but
it also exists within our own local area

67
00:03:39.544 --> 00:03:43.240
network as well and
we have to actually kind of understand it.

68
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:47.431
So let's take a look at our systems and
make sure that we understand what we're

69
00:03:47.431 --> 00:03:49.855
really dealing with when
we start to do this.

70
00:03:49.855 --> 00:03:54.491
So here is just a very simple example
that I have inside of my own local area

71
00:03:54.491 --> 00:03:55.180
network.

72
00:03:55.180 --> 00:03:59.402
I have a machine that may want to
go out to our own website, okay?

73
00:03:59.402 --> 00:04:02.485
And this one's gonna be itprotvdemo.com.

74
00:04:02.485 --> 00:04:06.853
Now of course there's so many different
ones that are out there, but we're gonna

75
00:04:06.853 --> 00:04:11.680
use itprotvdemo.com or .org, or something
like that, as we continue to move forward.

76
00:04:11.680 --> 00:04:13.911
It depends on what's actually
available right now.

77
00:04:13.911 --> 00:04:17.080
And we've got three or four of the names
registered, but I know I've used them

78
00:04:17.080 --> 00:04:19.830
throughout different services so
I have to see what's available.

79
00:04:19.830 --> 00:04:21.809
But let's say that I want to get here.

80
00:04:21.809 --> 00:04:23.804
Well, my machine doesn't really need that.

81
00:04:23.804 --> 00:04:30.784
Remember what my machine needs is
the IP address to itprotvdemo.com.

82
00:04:30.784 --> 00:04:37.489
Well, what if my machine right here
does not have the IP address to it?

83
00:04:37.489 --> 00:04:39.530
Well, that's when it goes and

84
00:04:39.530 --> 00:04:43.226
it makes a request of what we
call our DNS server, okay?

85
00:04:43.226 --> 00:04:47.109
The server is essentially that service
that is running on that machine's software

86
00:04:47.109 --> 00:04:48.499
that's running on machine.

87
00:04:48.499 --> 00:04:52.648
That will answer how this
machine can get there.

88
00:04:52.648 --> 00:04:57.525
So this particular machine over here on
the left-hand side asks a question, and

89
00:04:57.525 --> 00:04:59.326
the DNS server will respond.

90
00:04:59.326 --> 00:05:04.476
And the way it does it is by checking
in its own DNS records to see

91
00:05:04.476 --> 00:05:09.546
if it actually has that ability
to get to itprotvdemo.com.

92
00:05:09.546 --> 00:05:14.362
So that server, whatever the IP address
is, it can do that and we are off and

93
00:05:14.362 --> 00:05:15.667
we're ready to go.

94
00:05:15.667 --> 00:05:21.866
Inside of that DNS server it is very
possible that has a complete zone or

95
00:05:21.866 --> 00:05:27.769
a database or everything that
end with itprotvdemo.com, okay?

96
00:05:27.769 --> 00:05:31.847
But inside of that database
are a list of different records.

97
00:05:31.847 --> 00:05:36.162
Now these records are not super acceptable
to everything that we're doing, but

98
00:05:36.162 --> 00:05:37.316
they are important.

99
00:05:37.316 --> 00:05:42.013
So we have to understand at least
the basic nature of sumlist when we start

100
00:05:42.013 --> 00:05:42.937
here, okay?

101
00:05:42.937 --> 00:05:45.542
So every single zone, or
every single database,

102
00:05:45.542 --> 00:05:49.026
the most important record in there
is what we call an A record here.

103
00:05:49.026 --> 00:05:53.384
But in today's world you may
also see quad A records and

104
00:05:53.384 --> 00:05:58.239
that is because it also maps to
IP version six addresses too.

105
00:05:58.239 --> 00:06:01.281
So a single A maps to IP version 4, and

106
00:06:01.281 --> 00:06:06.428
then you have quad A records that
map to IP version 6 addresses.

107
00:06:06.428 --> 00:06:10.364
Any time that you have a name,
a fully qualified name here,

108
00:06:10.364 --> 00:06:16.350
that matches up to an IP address, that is
called an A record, is what that's called.

109
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:20.103
And that is by far the most important
record inside of this database.

110
00:06:20.103 --> 00:06:22.207
Without that record the rest of these,

111
00:06:22.207 --> 00:06:24.966
it really doesn't work as
well as you want them to.

112
00:06:24.966 --> 00:06:29.868
So it really does relate back to
the idea of this A record, okay?

113
00:06:29.868 --> 00:06:33.103
The next one that we have here is a CNAME,
okay?

114
00:06:33.103 --> 00:06:35.399
CNAME stands for canonical name.

115
00:06:35.399 --> 00:06:38.309
Another term for
canonical is the term alias.

116
00:06:38.309 --> 00:06:41.493
So what I can do instead is actually say,
hey,

117
00:06:41.493 --> 00:06:44.284
I want this name to also match up to this.

118
00:06:44.284 --> 00:06:49.580
So instead, let's say that instead
of it going to itprotvdemo.com,

119
00:06:49.580 --> 00:06:51.888
I might even be able to put www.

120
00:06:51.888 --> 00:06:57.399
And say, look, if it's actually somebody
is typing in www.itprotvdemo.com,

121
00:06:57.399 --> 00:07:01.506
send it to whatever is matched
to this A record as well, okay?

122
00:07:01.506 --> 00:07:06.030
So, we can create aliases for
different places that we have, okay?

123
00:07:06.030 --> 00:07:07.479
>> Right.
>> And that usually for

124
00:07:07.479 --> 00:07:10.552
us again kind of the basics
that we have here.

125
00:07:10.552 --> 00:07:14.154
Now starting from that point, though,
okay, there's a couple of other ones.

126
00:07:14.154 --> 00:07:16.981
Let me kind of go through
kinda the generic ones and

127
00:07:16.981 --> 00:07:19.135
then we'll kinda hit the ones that for

128
00:07:19.135 --> 00:07:23.400
at least Office 365 is gonna be more
essential that we pay attention to.

129
00:07:23.400 --> 00:07:27.264
So I'm gonna skip over the MX record for
right now, and

130
00:07:27.264 --> 00:07:30.540
let's talk about this idea of the PTR,
okay?

131
00:07:30.540 --> 00:07:36.410
The pointer record or the PTR record
is actually a reverse lookup.

132
00:07:36.410 --> 00:07:40.975
So instead of me actually needing
the name which gets resolved

133
00:07:40.975 --> 00:07:45.799
to an IP address what instead I can
have is I can actually have the IP

134
00:07:45.799 --> 00:07:48.718
address that resolve itself to a name.

135
00:07:48.718 --> 00:07:53.158
And that again is gonna be set up ready
for us through the system administrator

136
00:07:53.158 --> 00:07:57.750
through the network administrator on
that particular network as well, okay?

137
00:07:57.750 --> 00:08:00.647
Now believe it or
not the other ones right here,

138
00:08:00.647 --> 00:08:05.441
these are the ones that I'm really
focusing on Especially for Office 365.

139
00:08:05.441 --> 00:08:09.800
Why don't we talk about the MX records
just briefly just like I did here.

140
00:08:09.800 --> 00:08:12.330
We're gonna talk about NS,
which stands for Nameserver Records.

141
00:08:12.330 --> 00:08:14.810
Those are gonna be very important as well,
okay?

142
00:08:14.810 --> 00:08:18.060
So the MX record of course is for
the mail exchange.

143
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:22.570
And then the NS records here are for
the nameserver records.

144
00:08:22.570 --> 00:08:26.270
Now when we start talking about
it at the basis here, right?

145
00:08:26.270 --> 00:08:30.730
NS records are important because they
actually tell us who is authoritative for

146
00:08:30.730 --> 00:08:32.920
that particular zone.

episodes.description: Description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie explain some basic DNS concepts to help setup Office 365 to work with a Custom Domain Name. They describe how to add a custom domain name and work with DNS records to make it work with Office 365.
episodes.title: Add and Configure Custom Domain Part 2

So once we actually get all of
that done you have now been

301
00:18:25.070 --> 00:18:30.180
able to successfully see some of that
information Handed over and ready to do.

302
00:18:30.180 --> 00:18:33.830
Now, because we didn't actually
have all those services set up yet,

303
00:18:33.830 --> 00:18:37.920
I'm going to wait until we get some of
those services set up, and then add those

304
00:18:37.920 --> 00:18:41.210
DNS records along the way, making
sure that we are up and ready to go.

305
00:18:41.210 --> 00:18:44.240
Now, if you do not have any of
that configured, such as Skype for

306
00:18:44.240 --> 00:18:48.560
business online, and your email is not up,
and you're not using SharePoint and

307
00:18:48.560 --> 00:18:52.420
stuff, Setting it all up now is
probably the better thing to do because

308
00:18:52.420 --> 00:18:54.740
it means it's ready to go
when you're ready to go,

309
00:18:54.740 --> 00:18:58.150
and everything will be
pretty much handled for you.

310
00:18:58.150 --> 00:19:02.120
But for our sake, we're just gonna kind
of leave it as is for right now and

311
00:19:02.120 --> 00:19:06.380
have it actually kind of build up as
we move along through our series here.

312
00:19:06.380 --> 00:19:08.490
>> Doing a great job, Ronnie, as usual.

313
00:19:08.490 --> 00:19:12.100
Add and configure custom domains,
part one and two.

314
00:19:12.100 --> 00:19:12.760
Watch them both.

315
00:19:12.760 --> 00:19:13.840
It's for the exam.

316
00:19:13.840 --> 00:19:17.380
And make sure you see everything in
the Microsoft Office 365 series,

317
00:19:17.380 --> 00:19:18.440
also good for you.

318
00:19:18.440 --> 00:19:21.400
And check out our course library,
hundreds of videos,

319
00:19:21.400 --> 00:19:23.870
all designed to help you go further.

320
00:19:23.870 --> 00:19:25.450
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

321
00:19:25.450 --> 00:19:27.140
They'll be glad you did.

322
00:19:27.140 --> 00:19:27.840
Thanks for watching.

323
00:19:27.840 --> 00:19:28.610
I'm Zach Memos.

324
00:19:28.610 --> 00:19:29.460
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

325
00:19:29.460 --> 00:19:30.930
>> And we'll see you again very soon.

326
00:19:30.930 --> 00:19:37.120
[MUSIC]

327
00:19:37.120 --> 00:19:40.676
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Zach explore what it takes to plan a pilot.  They provide an overview of the steps to get a pilot started.  They discuss the types of users who should be included in it. Also, they talk about some of the workloads that do not need to be migrated.  Lastly, they demonstrate the use of a tool that tests the Health, Readiness and Connectivity.
episodes.title: Pilot Users and Workloads
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.058 --> 00:00:06.405
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet- [CROSSTALK] [INAUDIBLE]

2
00:00:06.405 --> 00:00:08.303
[MUSIC]

3

>> Hello and thank you for

helping you learn wherever you go.

6

I'm your host Zach Memos, and this is
Office 365, Pilot Users and Workloads.

7

Wonderful episode, and

If you've been following along from the

Well, we are now at this point and saying
hey, we really haven't seen a lot but

Remember that you've actually taken a look

We've even showed you how to make sure

So there's a lot of steps that

26

Now, when it gets down to that point,

there's still some other

Cuz ultimately,
this is not just the idea of a sandbox and

a play station for me to be able to learn.

Even though you might be getting ready for

Ultimately, right, the end result,

as well as you understanding how you're

So that means that at this point Zach,

36

37

38

>> And as we do so,

Some of the comments that you get from

Get used to it.

48

the idea of rough is kind of

50

>> [LAUGH]
>> You might get more than you actually

55

And then, to also think about the users

>> Mm-hm.
>> As well as actually understand when

So instead, one of the best things

that's exactly what we're talking about.

A pilot really begins with

79

Now, behind all this, Zach, it says,

If I am trying to get this all set up,

What happens, Zach,

let's say it's 50% of our users.

It's possible, or is there

In other words, there's a very small and

>> So, some of

00:07:27.410 --> 00:07:29.400

Designate Pilot Users here, okay?

In other words, can they still

>> It's easier to do this

174

175
00:08:44.979 --> 00:08:45.966

176
00:08:45.966 --> 00:08:50.339
>> That way we can go ahead and
just verify this also out too, okay?

177
00:08:50.339 --> 00:08:54.142
Collaboration sites, if we're using
something like SharePoint for

178

179
00:08:55.693 --> 00:08:59.722
Whatever it is that we have available
to us, if all that's a part of it,

180
00:08:59.722 --> 00:09:03.753

of Office 365 are also still able

181

182
00:09:05.980 --> 00:09:07.485
The other thing that we'll also of course,

183
00:09:07.485 --> 00:09:11.450
see during this time is
preparing the pilot user.

184
00:09:11.450 --> 00:09:15.635
And that means of course,
well basic idea of giving them the test,

185
00:09:15.635 --> 00:09:20.592
not the testing, the training that we
need to provide for that user, as well.

186
00:09:20.592 --> 00:09:24.050
Now this is essential,
we don't want to just go right, Zach,

187

pick out five people and then,
Zach just goes, you, you, you, you, you.

188
00:09:28.320 --> 00:09:29.400
This what's gonna happen next.

189

You're probably gonna
surprise him a little bit,

190

especially like somebody that's
a salesperson over there.

191

For your company,
that's a multi-million dollar company, and

192

193

He's got a possible six digit

194
00:09:47.150 --> 00:09:48.550

195
00:09:48.550 --> 00:09:50.750
You've just assigned

How do you think that, that person feels?

197
00:09:52.980 --> 00:09:54.732
>> I think he might be a bit stress.

198
00:09:54.732 --> 00:09:55.700
>> [LAUGH]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Zach show the use of IdFix.  They discuss the reason to use IdFix and its importance if you have an on-premises AD and want to use directory sychronization.  Lastly, they also discuss creating a basic test plan
episodes.title: Run Idfix

Because I said, even though

So when we start to

That everything is actually okay,

ready to do what we want to do in terms of

But what if I am now moving on in this

Now we need to actually figure

So, is there a check for this side of the

When we're running this pilot, especially

here is actually got this set up, it may

And so now that we are talking about maybe

>> Mm-hm.
>> And if it's not,

we're gonna actually run into some issues.

74

So the great thing is Office 365 has

75
00:04:42.700 --> 00:04:49.210
out there, just like we saw with the idea

76
00:04:49.210 --> 00:04:53.160
But now we're actually gonna

00:04:53.160 --> 00:04:58.260
right, the on-premises side and use a tool

78
00:04:58.260 --> 00:05:03.110
So inside of our screen here, okay,
the first thing that I'm gonna do,

79
00:05:03.110 --> 00:05:06.710
now that you know about the tool IdFix,

80

Now, before I do that, okay, I want to

I wanna talk about some of the

00:05:16.360 --> 00:05:19.890
So let's first focus in on this idea of

83
00:05:19.890 --> 00:05:23.720
the actual hardware requirements itself so
that we could take look.

84
00:05:23.720 --> 00:05:28.120
So I'll kinda change that and let us
focus in on it a little bit here, okay?

85
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:33.650
So IdFix Hardware requirements,
the key here that I also didn't add in but

86
00:05:33.650 --> 00:05:39.090
I'll add it in now, okay, is that we
have to actually do one more thing here.

87
00:05:39.090 --> 00:05:42.530
So let me add this one in and

88
00:05:42.530 --> 00:05:46.620
It's not gonna really be run

89
00:05:46.620 --> 00:05:50.560
So it probably requires Windows,
is what it's gonna require.

90
00:05:50.560 --> 00:05:54.336
So normally today, of course,
probably at least Windows 7 and above.

91
00:05:54.336 --> 00:05:56.754
And if it asks you to run

92
00:05:56.754 --> 00:05:59.049
again run to your latest operating system.

93
00:05:59.049 --> 00:06:03.308
For me, it'd be Windows 10 or Server 2016
is probably what I would run it from.

94
00:06:03.308 --> 00:06:04.840
So it's gonna be Windows-based.

95
00:06:04.840 --> 00:06:09.000
You're probably not gonna be able to
run this from a Mac computer, okay?

96
00:06:09.000 --> 00:06:13.740
Secondly, that computer has to have
a minimum of four gigs of RAM.

97
00:06:13.740 --> 00:06:15.620
Now that's pretty hefty for

98
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:19.490
a utility that's gonna be run,
but it is that requirement.

99
00:06:19.490 --> 00:06:25.240
Now it used to be where it was only
two gigs of RAM at some point.

100
00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:29.895
But somewhere along the line, whenever
they actually decided to add this in here,

101
00:06:29.895 --> 00:06:31.901
it requires four gigs of RAM to run.

102
00:06:31.901 --> 00:06:35.445
And that's because they've gotta search
through everything in Active Directory,

103
00:06:35.445 --> 00:06:37.475
might as well spread it
out over four gigs of RAM.

104
00:06:37.475 --> 00:06:38.707
>> So that's four dedicated gigs?

105
00:06:38.707 --> 00:06:43.370
>> Yeah, you need to at least have four
gigs of RAM on that machine to run it.

106
00:06:43.370 --> 00:06:46.660
So, it might be that but
that's what it requires.

107
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:50.470
The other one, though,
is a minimum of ten gigs of free space

108
00:06:50.470 --> 00:06:53.310
that you have to also
have available to you.

109
00:06:53.310 --> 00:06:56.492
Now this actually may be the one,
we talked about two gigs earlier, and

110
00:06:56.492 --> 00:06:58.480
I think it always required four gigs.

111
00:06:58.480 --> 00:07:03.012
But it used to be a minimum of two gigs of
free space, but today it says ten gigs,

112
00:07:03.012 --> 00:07:04.260
is kinda the change.

113
00:07:04.260 --> 00:07:08.930
So a few changes have happened over the
period of time that we've actually seen.

114
00:07:08.930 --> 00:07:11.795
And of course .NET Framework 4.0.

115
00:07:11.795 --> 00:07:16.769
And the strange thing is it's really not a
lot different than what we saw when we ran

116
00:07:16.769 --> 00:07:18.500
that configuration check,

117
00:07:18.500 --> 00:07:22.845
against our Office 365 configuration
from our own local computer.

118
00:07:22.845 --> 00:07:25.879
That still required at least a .NET 4.0.

119
00:07:25.879 --> 00:07:31.707
Required you to have that RAM
is more normally on the server,

00:07:31.707 --> 00:07:36.070
you'll probably have that much anyways.

121
00:07:36.070 --> 00:07:39.270
And running a Windows environment, that's

122
00:07:39.270 --> 00:07:42.260
>> And so, Ronnie, this information
could possibly end up on the exam?

123
00:07:42.260 --> 00:07:44.422
>> Right, yeah, that's kinda the key here.

124
00:07:44.422 --> 00:07:47.743
If you can't get the system run,
check your minimum requirements and

125
00:07:47.743 --> 00:07:51.232
figure out whether or not you have all
these requirements to run if you're

126
00:07:51.232 --> 00:07:53.275
actually running into that issue, okay?

127
00:07:53.275 --> 00:07:58.234
Now the other requirement that we
also can take a look at Is that there

128
00:07:58.234 --> 00:08:01.111
are permission requirements as well.

129
00:08:01.111 --> 00:08:05.530
Now for us specifically is actually
one particular permission requirement.

130
00:08:05.530 --> 00:08:08.996
Which is the ID fix permission
requirement, right here.

131
00:08:08.996 --> 00:08:14.090
What ever account that you sign into on
that computer, needs to have read and

132
00:08:14.090 --> 00:08:17.030
write access to the Active Directory.

133
00:08:17.030 --> 00:08:21.340
Well, normally that's the only type of
access you generally have to, of course,

134
00:08:21.340 --> 00:08:25.000
Active Directory unless you
think that you can try and

135
00:08:25.000 --> 00:08:29.555
do this on a read-only domain controller,
which you cannot do, okay?

136
00:08:29.555 --> 00:08:34.000
Cuz that only gives you read-only
access into the Active Directory.

137
00:08:34.000 --> 00:08:37.480
So it doesn't matter if you have read and
write access in your log to a read only

138
00:08:37.480 --> 00:08:40.300
domain controller,
it's not gonna allow you to do so.

139
00:08:40.300 --> 00:08:44.440
So make sure that you do have an account
if you're running this as read and

140
00:08:44.440 --> 00:08:46.710
write access to Active Directory.

141
00:08:46.710 --> 00:08:50.140
Most of the time there's very few
people that really do get access in

142
00:08:50.140 --> 00:08:54.920
Active Directory, but you just wanna make
sure that they do have that read, write.

143
00:08:54.920 --> 00:09:00.173
Now this one, this last one here is
a little bit more strange and I have

144
00:09:00.173 --> 00:09:06.353
seen this kind of over time end up being
something that is sometimes not this way.

145
00:09:06.353 --> 00:09:10.953
When you download ID Fix wherever you
actually download it from over a period of

146
00:09:10.953 --> 00:09:13.950
time it has changed
a couple of times here.

147
00:09:13.950 --> 00:09:15.880
Used to just be an executable, but

148
00:09:15.880 --> 00:09:20.780
what you're also likely to see today
is that it downloads as a zip, okay?

149
00:09:20.780 --> 00:09:26.480
And then when you extract it you might
find out something there is not a .exe

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Zach demonstrate the steps to setting up email for Pilot Users. They show each step and  discuss what must be considered for a successful pilot to take place.
episodes.title: Setup Email for Pilot User

>> Fantastic, wow, set up email for pilot

>> There's not gonna be a part two.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to get the help of the FastTrack Center to onboard Office 365 services.
episodes.title: Engage Fasttrack Center for Office

In getting setup, talking amount of

407
00:22:04.350 --> 00:22:08.840
help users get the most from their
premier cloud productivity suite.

408
00:22:08.840 --> 00:22:11.860
Boy it sounds like a lot of
promises right there okay, but

409
00:22:11.860 --> 00:22:13.175
they are willing to deliver.

410
00:22:13.175 --> 00:22:16.010
Now here's where I got some
of those details from that

411
00:22:16.010 --> 00:22:19.410
we talked about in terms
of eligibility okay.

412
00:22:19.410 --> 00:22:23.190
So you can also see all this
information right there again.

413
00:22:23.190 --> 00:22:28.840
And the other thing, of course, that I
didn't point out, let me see if I can

414
00:22:28.840 --> 00:22:33.620
zoom in on this one without driving
us all nuts at the same time, okay.

415
00:22:35.500 --> 00:22:38.130
So here,
notice I've kind of highlighted this.

416
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:44.165
As long as you have current and
eligible Office 365 plan subscriptions,

417
00:22:44.165 --> 00:22:48.597
you can start using FastTrack
onboarding migration and

418
00:22:48.597 --> 00:22:53.043
adoption services or
use them again at any time, okay.

419
00:22:53.043 --> 00:22:57.791
So it gives you that too, and
now notice, go to FastTrack for

420
00:22:57.791 --> 00:23:02.277
Office 365 Resources,
I'm gonna select that link.

421
00:23:05.041 --> 00:23:07.760
Let's see, any other, there we go,
down here at the bottom.

422
00:23:10.720 --> 00:23:14.320
Now at this point, you can see some
of the generic options, right.

423
00:23:14.320 --> 00:23:18.950
Onboarding is specifically what we are
talking about, as far as the exam here.

424
00:23:18.950 --> 00:23:24.160
So here on the onboarding, to get engaged,
that’s what we would select here.

425
00:23:24.160 --> 00:23:28.010
And it leads you to a business
partner that can help you.

426
00:23:28.010 --> 00:23:30.830
Now this is probably not what
you’re normally looking for.

427
00:23:30.830 --> 00:23:33.830
But here’s where you can
actually go at this point,

428
00:23:33.830 --> 00:23:36.250
if you actually need to select that.

429
00:23:36.250 --> 00:23:39.000
So if you wanna learn more about it,
you select here.

430
00:23:39.000 --> 00:23:41.320
And let’s see what other tools are there.

431
00:23:41.320 --> 00:23:45.060
So here's kind of the generic
options that are available.

432
00:23:45.060 --> 00:23:51.460
Now, if I go into Microsoft FastTrack here
and I sign in, let me select the Sign In.

433
00:23:51.460 --> 00:23:55.320
It says, hey, sign in and
read your profile.

434
00:23:55.320 --> 00:23:58.500
So it says I am signed in, and
I already did this a little bit earlier so

435
00:23:58.500 --> 00:24:01.110
I wouldn't have to try and
type in that password.

436
00:24:01.110 --> 00:24:02.345
Cuz it was a long password.

437
00:24:02.345 --> 00:24:03.230
>> Mm-hm.

438
00:24:03.230 --> 00:24:07.690
>> So here it should give me some
information as it's now reading and

439
00:24:07.690 --> 00:24:09.390
setting me up here.

440
00:24:09.390 --> 00:24:12.230
You still have to go through and
you still have to register and

441
00:24:12.230 --> 00:24:17.190
do all the rest of this information
as you need the FastTrack here, okay.

442
00:24:17.190 --> 00:24:21.200
So you'll simply fill out at information
and then you'll tell them what you need

443
00:24:21.200 --> 00:24:24.632
and you'll either get either
generic responses back or,

444
00:24:24.632 --> 00:24:27.290
you'll actually get the service
person to call you back.

445
00:24:27.290 --> 00:24:29.355
And to set up everything that you need for

446
00:24:29.355 --> 00:24:32.400
FastTrack to get started in
doing what we want to, okay.

447
00:24:32.400 --> 00:24:35.330
Now I'm not gonna set this up because
I don't really qualify, okay,

448
00:24:35.330 --> 00:24:36.880
I'm using a free account, okay.

449
00:24:36.880 --> 00:24:39.630
And not only that, I don't have 25 seats,

450
00:24:39.630 --> 00:24:44.040
so even though they show me as being
registered here, more than likely,

451
00:24:44.040 --> 00:24:47.380
they're probably gonna look and
go, that's a free one.

452
00:24:47.380 --> 00:24:48.900
For right now and probably not do this.

453
00:24:48.900 --> 00:24:53.150
But this is where you begin, and
the steps after this is relatively easy.

454
00:24:53.150 --> 00:24:56.393
Just follow the directions and
that will get you started.

455
00:24:56.393 --> 00:24:59.417
In terms of the engagement,
you'll either get, like I said,

456
00:24:59.417 --> 00:25:03.241
assigned to an engineer or they'll lead
you to a library of great resources that

457
00:25:03.241 --> 00:25:05.771
you can actually be able
to pull from as well, okay.

458
00:25:05.771 --> 00:25:09.933
So Zach That is how we
really do get started with

459
00:25:09.933 --> 00:25:14.649
this process of using FastTrack for
Office 365.

460
00:25:14.649 --> 00:25:18.960
And help us bring our onboarding
process as we continue to move forward.

461
00:25:18.960 --> 00:25:23.250
>> Wow, that was a great episode,
engage FastTrack Center for Office 365.

462
00:25:23.250 --> 00:25:26.200
I learned an awful lot,
I'm sure you did, too.

463
00:25:26.200 --> 00:25:29.711
And make sure you watch every single
episode of the Office 365 series,

464
00:25:29.711 --> 00:25:31.263
also go to our course library.

465
00:25:31.263 --> 00:25:34.852
There's hundreds of videos there,
all designed to help you go further.

466
00:25:34.852 --> 00:25:38.130
And tell everybody know about ITPro TV,
they'll be glad you did.

467
00:25:38.130 --> 00:25:40.280
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

468
00:25:40.280 --> 00:25:41.000
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

469
00:25:41.000 --> 00:25:42.567
>> And we'll see you again soon.

470

471

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss and show how to enable client connectivity to Office 365. They review the records that need to be added to the DNS registrar for email, communication and collaboration to work. Also they focus in on configurations on proxy and firewall to access Office 365 Keywords: dns,srv records, ns records, mx records, srv records, firewall settings, proxy settings.
episodes.title: Enable Client Connectivity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.514
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.514 --> 00:00:06.217
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.217 --> 00:00:08.073
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.073 --> 00:00:09.939
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:09.939 --> 00:00:13.579
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:13.579 --> 00:00:16.621
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.621 --> 00:00:18.190
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

8
00:00:18.190 --> 00:00:19.939
And this is Office 365.

9
00:00:19.939 --> 00:00:24.220
We're going to enable client connectivity,
with the one and only Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:25.710
Ronnie, great to have you here.

11
00:00:25.710 --> 00:00:26.730
Thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:26.730 --> 00:00:30.340
>> Well, thank you for inviting me back
on the show, Zach, as we continue on and

13
00:00:30.340 --> 00:00:34.790
learn more about of course, getting
Office 365 set up for our organization.

14
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:39.310
And of course connecting to, well,
the Office 365 cloud as well.

15
00:00:39.310 --> 00:00:43.286
So during our series we'll really
talk now about setting it up, and

16
00:00:43.286 --> 00:00:47.623
gone through the ideas of actually
making sure that a pilot is ready to go.

17
00:00:47.623 --> 00:00:51.844
But some of the other things that we now
need to begin to think about as well of

18
00:00:51.844 --> 00:00:54.520
course is the idea of client connectivity.

19
00:00:54.520 --> 00:00:58.588
Now, when we start talking about that for
an organization is not just enough to say,

20
00:00:58.588 --> 00:01:01.705
okay, I'm connected to the Internet and
that's good enough.

21
00:01:01.705 --> 00:01:06.248
But inside of an organization you may
actually connect with a couple of

22
00:01:06.248 --> 00:01:11.253
different devices in between, and
those devices may need to be configured so

23
00:01:11.253 --> 00:01:16.267
that we get the best possible user
experience that we can with Office 365.

24
00:01:16.267 --> 00:01:20.630
And what we're gonna be specifically
referring to today, okay.

25
00:01:20.630 --> 00:01:23.640
Is really gonna be of course
two different devices.

26
00:01:23.640 --> 00:01:29.150
What we're gonna talk proxy servers
as well the idea of firewalls.

27
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:32.850
Now, when it comes down to both of them
the proxy server is probably the one

28
00:01:32.850 --> 00:01:36.240
that's bit more mysterious in
the connections that we have.

29
00:01:36.240 --> 00:01:38.780
So we're probably gonna
focus in on that one too.

30
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:41.555
>> So in fact,
my very first question to you, sir,

31
00:01:41.555 --> 00:01:46.230
is help us understand more about the proxy
server, and how that might be applied or

32
00:01:46.230 --> 00:01:48.567
used in the Office 365 environment?

33
00:01:48.567 --> 00:01:51.246
>> Yeah, that's actually something
that we have to consider,

34
00:01:51.246 --> 00:01:53.920
especially if we are actually
using a proxy server.

35
00:01:53.920 --> 00:01:54.650
There is no doubt,

36
00:01:54.650 --> 00:01:59.860
that lot of organisations like the use of
a proxy server and what it does for us.

37
00:01:59.860 --> 00:02:04.090
So let's take a look at my screen
hopefully this will help us a little bit

38
00:02:04.090 --> 00:02:06.525
to understand what's going on, okay?

39
00:02:06.525 --> 00:02:11.144
So when we have a couple of different
things happen right, so here it is,

40
00:02:11.144 --> 00:02:14.496
everybody inside of my
itprotvdemo.com network.

41
00:02:14.496 --> 00:02:15.081
>> Uh-huh.
>> And

42
00:02:15.081 --> 00:02:19.550
what I may have of course then as we
connect out to the rest of the world.

43
00:02:19.550 --> 00:02:22.661
There's websites out there,
there's Office 365,

44
00:02:22.661 --> 00:02:26.949
there's other places beyond the edge
of my network that's out there, okay?

45
00:02:26.949 --> 00:02:29.864
To simplify that I've removed
every other object in between,

46
00:02:29.864 --> 00:02:32.948
but let's say that what's right
here of course is a proxy server.

47
00:02:32.948 --> 00:02:35.849
Now what does a proxy server really do?

48
00:02:35.849 --> 00:02:41.235
Notice that all of my devices internally
they go through the proxy server

49
00:02:41.235 --> 00:02:46.900
itself Before it goes out to websites,
and possibly even to Office 365.

50
00:02:46.900 --> 00:02:50.485
But let's focus in on
the website aspect first,

51
00:02:50.485 --> 00:02:54.380
and talk about why this
is also important too.

52
00:02:54.380 --> 00:02:59.160
So when my clients connect
out to a particular website,

53
00:02:59.160 --> 00:03:02.860
they are not connecting
directly to those websites.

54
00:03:02.860 --> 00:03:06.672
Right in between,
they're gonna hit the proxy server, and

55
00:03:06.672 --> 00:03:09.973
the idea of the proxy server
is to act on behalf of me.

56
00:03:09.973 --> 00:03:14.687
So if I'm on that machine,
it is acting on my behalf to then

57
00:03:14.687 --> 00:03:19.120
contact what that other
website is going to be?

58
00:03:19.120 --> 00:03:24.060
Now when that website responds,
it returns the information back,

59
00:03:24.060 --> 00:03:29.030
not directly to me but
it returns it back to the proxy server.

60
00:03:29.030 --> 00:03:33.170
The proxy server then also acts
on behalf of the web server

61
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:36.360
to return that response back.

62
00:03:36.360 --> 00:03:38.970
Notice that what this does is
it abstracts us a little bit.

63
00:03:38.970 --> 00:03:43.490
In other words, it puts another device
in between that when I'm never really

64
00:03:43.490 --> 00:03:48.980
directly connecting to is pretty much any
machine that is out there somewhere else.

65
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:54.290
On my particular edge of the entire world
really resides at this proxy server.

66
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:58.330
So it adds a kind of layer
of defense in a sense here.

67
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:02.780
It's not the best layer of defense, but it
adds a little bit of a defensive layer in

68
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:07.010
that sense is that nobody's ever
directly connecting out there.

69
00:04:07.010 --> 00:04:09.690
We're connecting through this
idea of the proxy server.

70
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:13.800
>> Yeah, I was gonna say it's like
a defense and it's also like a liaison.

71
00:04:13.800 --> 00:04:17.690
>> Yeah, it kind of works in that
same aspect and that same way.

72
00:04:17.690 --> 00:04:24.020
Now, the key though to understanding
how or this working out, right?

73
00:04:24.020 --> 00:04:27.420
You got to think about what
a proxy server does, okay?

74
00:04:27.420 --> 00:04:31.974
Now, when we start thinking about what
a proxy server does, there's three or

75
00:04:31.974 --> 00:04:34.946
four things that a proxy
server really does for us.

76
00:04:34.946 --> 00:04:39.936
And the reason why I'm actually focusing
in on this, because this is what's going

77
00:04:39.936 --> 00:04:44.160
to affect our particular user experience,
also with Office 365.

78
00:04:44.160 --> 00:04:49.390
So, in the very first sense, in the way
that I talked about right here, okay?

79
00:04:49.390 --> 00:04:52.058
So far when we actually start doing this,
okay?

80
00:04:52.058 --> 00:04:56.600
Well, a proxy server can do like
I said three or four things,okay?

81
00:04:56.600 --> 00:05:00.790
So when it comes down to one of the first
things that it does is what we call

82
00:05:00.790 --> 00:05:03.120
end point inspection.

83
00:05:03.120 --> 00:05:07.300
Now, that's kind of sound like
a technical thing but really isn't.

84
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:12.100
When we are connecting from
ITProTV demo machine over here.

85
00:05:12.100 --> 00:05:15.200
It hits the proxy server, and
says hey, you wanna go this website?

86
00:05:15.200 --> 00:05:18.049
Well, it has to actually take a look and
go,

87
00:05:18.049 --> 00:05:21.131
do I really want to make
that connection or not?

88
00:05:21.131 --> 00:05:25.340
In other words, it actually goes to that
endpoint and kinda decides whether it's

89
00:05:25.340 --> 00:05:28.817
good or whether it's bad, and
it allow us to make that connection or

90
00:05:28.817 --> 00:05:31.755
it allows a proxy server to
make that connection, okay?

91
00:05:31.755 --> 00:05:35.725
So it does that idea of what we call
end point inspection to that point.

92
00:05:35.725 --> 00:05:37.630
>> Mm-hm.
>> The other thing it can do though,

93
00:05:37.630 --> 00:05:42.010
is again, talked about the good and
the bad, it can do content filtering.

94
00:05:42.010 --> 00:05:44.520
So let's say we go to that website, but

95
00:05:44.520 --> 00:05:48.030
I have already set up some
rules here on the proxy server.

96
00:05:48.030 --> 00:05:52.185
Say, if that website shows something I
don't want show internally in my network.

97
00:05:52.185 --> 00:05:52.860
>> Mm-hm.

98
00:05:52.860 --> 00:05:55.010
>> Then, I want to filter it out.

99
00:05:55.010 --> 00:05:58.913
So it allows me to actually do
some content filtering as well.

100
00:05:58.913 --> 00:06:04.193
The third thing which is prior why a lot
of organizations do also do this, okay?

101
00:06:04.193 --> 00:06:08.650
Is the ability to do what we call caching,
okay?

102
00:06:08.650 --> 00:06:11.320
What does caching actually do for us?

103
00:06:11.320 --> 00:06:15.140
It allows me to request
whatever that information is.

104
00:06:15.140 --> 00:06:19.628
And from that website, it stores it
locally on the proxy server, okay?

105
00:06:19.628 --> 00:06:20.330
>> Mm-hm.

106
00:06:20.330 --> 00:06:25.130
>> When we do that, what does that mean
for all the other devices internally?

107
00:06:25.130 --> 00:06:31.140
It means that if go to very same website,
okay, that this guy just went to,

108
00:06:31.140 --> 00:06:34.910
they don't always have to actually
get another request from the website.

109
00:06:34.910 --> 00:06:38.970
They simply pull it down from
the proxy server itself and

110
00:06:38.970 --> 00:06:41.940
it speeds things up incredibly.

111
00:06:42.990 --> 00:06:46.470
So it really can do that or us.

112
00:06:46.470 --> 00:06:49.220
So the idea of speed is a big one.

113
00:06:49.220 --> 00:06:52.280
The idea that actually being to do
the things that we talk about content

114
00:06:52.280 --> 00:06:56.030
filtering doing basic
end point inspection.

115
00:06:56.030 --> 00:06:58.060
All that really is kind of key, and

116
00:06:58.060 --> 00:07:01.750
then of course along with the end
point inspection essentially routing.

117
00:07:01.750 --> 00:07:02.930
Do we wanted to go here or

118
00:07:02.930 --> 00:07:07.950
not it actually has a routing table
that can help us to be able to do that?

119
00:07:07.950 --> 00:07:09.160
So Zach,

120
00:07:09.160 --> 00:07:14.710
those are kinds of the basic things
that a proxy server does for us here.

121
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:18.478
And this also means that it does it for
any other website,

122
00:07:18.478 --> 00:07:22.954
we also have to think about it in terms
of the context of it doing it for

123
00:07:22.954 --> 00:07:26.344
us when we connect to Office 365 as well,
okay?

124
00:07:26.344 --> 00:07:27.064
>> Mm-hm.

125
00:07:27.064 --> 00:07:29.714
>> So
this is something that's important for

126
00:07:29.714 --> 00:07:32.950
us to think about as we
begin to proceed on.

127
00:07:32.950 --> 00:07:40.740
The reason why is that in Office 365,
it is a different environment, okay?

128
00:07:40.740 --> 00:07:43.609
And this is why it's actually important.

129
00:07:43.609 --> 00:07:48.272
So when we actually try to
connect to Office 365, well,

130
00:07:48.272 --> 00:07:54.641
we've gotta think about some of the things
that Office 365 is already doing.

131
00:07:54.641 --> 00:07:58.651
And we gotta think that some of
the traffic that Office 365 is

132
00:07:58.651 --> 00:07:59.869
delivering to us.

133
00:07:59.869 --> 00:08:03.104
And what can happen here if
we actually start to do this.

134
00:08:03.104 --> 00:08:05.640
So that is what we want to
take a look at next here.

135
00:08:05.640 --> 00:08:10.190
Is actually think about this idea and
this process as well okay?

136
00:08:10.190 --> 00:08:14.690
So, first and foremost then Zach,
as we start to take a look at this.

137
00:08:15.900 --> 00:08:17.930
One of the things that
ends up happening right?

138
00:08:17.930 --> 00:08:20.230
When we start talking
about the proxy server.

139
00:08:20.230 --> 00:08:23.176
Is a couple of other things
that end up going on too.

140
00:08:23.176 --> 00:08:29.310
Between my network itprotvdemo and

141
00:08:29.310 --> 00:08:35.960
the Office 365 connection,
there is no open connection.

142
00:08:35.960 --> 00:08:40.770
In the sense that not anything
is sent in clear text, okay?

143
00:08:40.770 --> 00:08:45.760
And that means that everything
in between itprotvdemo and

144
00:08:45.760 --> 00:08:49.160
Office 365 is pretty much encrypted.

145
00:08:49.160 --> 00:08:50.050
>> Right.

146
00:08:50.050 --> 00:08:54.870
>> Well what does a proxy server
do with the encrypted content?

147
00:08:54.870 --> 00:08:57.270
Not really much it can do, okay?

148
00:08:57.270 --> 00:09:02.740
If you want it to do the content
filtering, it can't, okay?

149
00:09:02.740 --> 00:09:06.170
It can't do that because
it doesn't have a way

150
00:09:06.170 --> 00:09:09.450
to break that encryption right then and
there, okay?

151
00:09:09.450 --> 00:09:13.650
Now if you want it to, can it do that?

152
00:09:13.650 --> 00:09:18.670
Yes but you have to actually set up
something else if you want that to happen.

153
00:09:18.670 --> 00:09:22.610
If you wanted to inspect
encrypted content in between

154
00:09:22.610 --> 00:09:25.830
you have to actually set up certificates,
okay?

155
00:09:25.830 --> 00:09:29.600
So that there's an end point
certificate that is, excuse me,
