port 443, right?

382
00:22:47.380 --> 00:22:49.132
Now it's amazing, right?

383
00:22:49.132 --> 00:22:53.910
Here we are, and we're in October of
2017 as of the recording of this show.

384
00:22:53.910 --> 00:22:55.120
>> Yes.

385
00:22:55.120 --> 00:22:58.150
>> Very, I say very little, fewer.

386
00:22:58.150 --> 00:23:02.370
I don't even remember in the past year,
year and a half that I've actually gone to

387
00:23:02.370 --> 00:23:08.520
a website that hasn't already been enabled
with a little security lock, right?

388
00:23:08.520 --> 00:23:12.000
So in other words,
every website seems to be secure.

389
00:23:12.000 --> 00:23:17.730
So why in the world do I have to
open up port 80 to go through?

390
00:23:17.730 --> 00:23:22.570
Well, this is more of just a convenience
idea when we start to do this.

391
00:23:22.570 --> 00:23:28.150
So when your users open up a web
browser to connect in to the portal,

392
00:23:29.300 --> 00:23:37.090
Most of them don't type in
https://portal.office.com.

393
00:23:37.090 --> 00:23:39.467
Most of the time they just open up and

394
00:23:39.467 --> 00:23:43.528
they pick whatever their
particular browser is going to be.

395
00:23:43.528 --> 00:23:47.650
And when they do that, they just
type what I do, portal.office.com.

396
00:23:47.650 --> 00:23:48.950
They get to my log in page.

397
00:23:48.950 --> 00:23:51.210
There it is, I'm ready to go, okay?

398
00:23:51.210 --> 00:23:52.420
Often doing that.

399
00:23:52.420 --> 00:23:54.554
Well, truly, when I do that, right,

400
00:23:54.554 --> 00:23:59.030
what it's actually expecting to connect
on through the web browser is port 80.

401
00:23:59.030 --> 00:24:03.306
But in Office 365, it says hey,
if it comes in on port 80,

402
00:24:03.306 --> 00:24:06.970
flip it over to port 443 anyways, okay?

403
00:24:06.970 --> 00:24:10.310
So, it is just a matter of
convenience that we allow for

404
00:24:10.310 --> 00:24:11.840
something like that to happen.

405
00:24:11.840 --> 00:24:14.640
So then that way, somebody doesn't just
get an error that comes back to them

406
00:24:14.640 --> 00:24:19.410
saying, you can't connect
to portal reality, right?

407
00:24:19.410 --> 00:24:21.805
The whole thing is you are not,
we give an error,

408
00:24:21.805 --> 00:24:24.035
we don't actually allow
it to come through.

409
00:24:24.035 --> 00:24:29.072
You're not connecting to
http://portal.office.com,

410
00:24:29.072 --> 00:24:34.540
and it just tells you,
you're supposed to connect to HTTPS.

411
00:24:34.540 --> 00:24:38.775
So by doing along to port 80, it just
allows for that to happen and then for

412
00:24:38.775 --> 00:24:41.009
them to automatically flip that over.

413
00:24:41.009 --> 00:24:44.280
And that's what you wanna do,
and allow them to connect in.

414
00:24:44.280 --> 00:24:48.980
So port 80 is really for the user or
the end user's convenience, okay?

415
00:24:48.980 --> 00:24:53.180
Now the other thing that we also
want to remember is that port 443,

416
00:24:53.180 --> 00:24:58.280
that's just about 99% of everything
that's gonna go through Office 365.

417
00:24:58.280 --> 00:25:00.257
And that's the reality of it, okay?

418
00:25:00.257 --> 00:25:02.006
Now that's not always HTTPS,

419
00:25:02.006 --> 00:25:06.790
there's a lot of other stuff that's
also connecting through here as well.

420
00:25:06.790 --> 00:25:11.230
There is tons of stuff that is
essentially is encapsulated inside

421
00:25:11.230 --> 00:25:14.870
of 443 to allow for
this connection to go on.

422
00:25:14.870 --> 00:25:19.450
So, if you allow for 443, you're not just
allowing for HTTPS, you're allowing for

423
00:25:19.450 --> 00:25:23.690
everything that's encapsulated
inside of port 443 as well.

424
00:25:23.690 --> 00:25:26.358
So that's why you also want to allow for
that to go on too.

425
00:25:26.358 --> 00:25:32.440
3378 and 5223,
this is all Skype for Business.

426
00:25:32.440 --> 00:25:34.820
You've gotta allow those for
Skype for Business.

427
00:25:34.820 --> 00:25:39.450
And for those particular sections to
be done, you also wanna allow these for

428
00:25:39.450 --> 00:25:40.980
Skype for Business as well.

429
00:25:40.980 --> 00:25:46.666
This kind of dynamic one is 50,000
all the way through 59,999 and

430
00:25:46.666 --> 00:25:49.825
make sure you allow for udp 59,999.

431
00:25:49.825 --> 00:25:53.880
Can you run all of Office 365 over TCP?

432
00:25:54.920 --> 00:25:56.264
Yes, you can, okay?

433
00:25:56.264 --> 00:26:01.427
But you are gonna find out something
that that means that on your void calls,

434
00:26:01.427 --> 00:26:03.130
you are gonna get echos.

435
00:26:03.130 --> 00:26:05.534
You are gonna get these
kind of weird artifacts.

436
00:26:05.534 --> 00:26:11.800
You are gonna do that because that TCP
connection has a ton of overhead into it.

437
00:26:11.800 --> 00:26:14.660
What you want though is
your udp connections to

438
00:26:14.660 --> 00:26:18.140
handle those faster types for
traffic to be able to do that.

439
00:26:18.140 --> 00:26:22.050
So if you only allow for
TCP here, it will work, okay?

440
00:26:22.050 --> 00:26:26.222
You'll do that, but if you wanna allow for
the best user experience,

441
00:26:26.222 --> 00:26:31.255
make sure you'll also allow for
udp 50000 through 59999 as well, okay?

442
00:26:31.255 --> 00:26:36.650
Now, down here at the bottom, I have this
last kind of little pieces here too, okay?

443
00:26:37.820 --> 00:26:39.320
Every once in a while, okay?

444
00:26:39.320 --> 00:26:42.830
You may also end up with what
we call host based filter, okay?

445
00:26:42.830 --> 00:26:46.910
Where you need to allow for this hostname
based types of filtering instead and

446
00:26:46.910 --> 00:26:49.030
especially these three here.

447
00:26:49.030 --> 00:26:51.650
Now, this can change over time.

448
00:26:51.650 --> 00:26:56.070
So in other words make sure you
check the Office 365 website, and

449
00:26:56.070 --> 00:26:58.620
see if they're still requiring this or
not.

450
00:26:58.620 --> 00:27:03.450
So some of these may change like,
I think earlier in time was like r1, r2,

451
00:27:03.450 --> 00:27:05.370
res outlook, stuff.

452
00:27:05.370 --> 00:27:08.935
But today is r3, r4 and
then the production msocdn,

453
00:27:08.935 --> 00:27:13.078
cuz we need that cdn
traffic to come in too.

454
00:27:13.078 --> 00:27:15.560
So just realized that you
may also need to do that and

455
00:27:15.560 --> 00:27:17.350
open those up on your firewall too.

456
00:27:17.350 --> 00:27:19.760
>> So Ronnie,
what about bandwidth considerations?

457
00:27:19.760 --> 00:27:21.540
Are there any,
what do we need to understand it?

458
00:27:21.540 --> 00:27:25.160
>> Yeah, there are some bandwidth
considerations that we need to take a look

459
00:27:25.160 --> 00:27:30.720
at here just briefly before the end of our
show which is just a few minutes away.

460
00:27:30.720 --> 00:27:33.380
So I gave you an example
right here on the screen.

461
00:27:33.380 --> 00:27:38.890
And I typed most of it out because
there's no other way to do that.

462
00:27:38.890 --> 00:27:40.629
I was trying to think like
how can I shorten this out.

463
00:27:40.629 --> 00:27:43.671
>> No, it's great you did this-
>> But we'll need to do this, okay?

464
00:27:43.671 --> 00:27:47.080
So at this point here,
I always said one but here, okay?

465
00:27:47.080 --> 00:27:50.830
Be aware that for
Office 365 per client, okay?

466
00:27:50.830 --> 00:27:54.910
Two connections as a minimum
are required for basic connectivity for

467
00:27:54.910 --> 00:27:55.590
a single mailbox.

468
00:27:55.590 --> 00:27:57.820
That's for sending and
receiving that, okay?

469
00:27:57.820 --> 00:27:59.600
So two connections.

470
00:27:59.600 --> 00:28:02.529
Most companies that use IP
addresses private ones, right?

471
00:28:02.529 --> 00:28:05.780
Are also ending up using that, okay?

472
00:28:05.780 --> 00:28:10.730
And so notice what this means, that all
private IP addresses are hidden normally

473
00:28:10.730 --> 00:28:13.490
behind a single public IP address.

474
00:28:13.490 --> 00:28:14.420
So that's normal.

475
00:28:14.420 --> 00:28:16.420
That's not anything that's different.

476
00:28:16.420 --> 00:28:18.778
So we have a single IP
address here at ITProTV.

477
00:28:18.778 --> 00:28:22.305
We have hundreds of different devices
inside of our network that use IP

478
00:28:22.305 --> 00:28:23.330
addresses, okay?

479
00:28:23.330 --> 00:28:25.090
But they're all hidden behind and

480
00:28:25.090 --> 00:28:28.220
the way that they do that
is by using port numbers.

481
00:28:28.220 --> 00:28:32.608
There's approximately 65,535 or

482
00:28:32.608 --> 00:28:38.130
536 ports that every IP
address can end up using.

483
00:28:38.130 --> 00:28:41.430
And let's say that some of those
are not gonna be available.

484
00:28:41.430 --> 00:28:45.937
So here, notice it says that NAT,
Network Address Translation,

485
00:28:45.937 --> 00:28:50.776
gives us about 64,000 ports for
every public IP address, okay?

486
00:28:50.776 --> 00:28:56.952
And that also means then that
we can have approximately 64,000

487
00:28:56.952 --> 00:29:02.250
possible individual connections
to that one IP address.

488
00:29:02.250 --> 00:29:04.570
Possibly, but is that for real?

489
00:29:04.570 --> 00:29:05.972
Is that absolutely true?

490
00:29:05.972 --> 00:29:10.840
Is not per user,
is a possible connection here, okay?

491
00:29:10.840 --> 00:29:13.476
So let's make sure that we
understand what this balls down to.

492
00:29:13.476 --> 00:29:17.550
If I have 64,000 ports, okay?

493
00:29:17.550 --> 00:29:20.139
Let's say there's about 4,000 ports that

494
00:29:20.139 --> 00:29:24.190
are gonna be restricted by
the Operating System here, okay?

495
00:29:24.190 --> 00:29:25.750
And the highest consumption,

496
00:29:25.750 --> 00:29:28.120
let's say that we're just
doing an average here, okay?

497
00:29:28.120 --> 00:29:30.431
Peak port consumption per device.

498
00:29:30.431 --> 00:29:34.132
Let's say we're gonna say six
possible connections per device.

499
00:29:34.132 --> 00:29:39.067
And peak port factor, I wanna say pork,

500
00:29:39.067 --> 00:29:42.970
P-O-R-K, X at one time.

501
00:29:42.970 --> 00:29:46.790
How many are we actually using in
any one particular time, okay?

502
00:29:46.790 --> 00:29:49.510
Well, the way that we've ball
that down is right over here.

503
00:29:49.510 --> 00:29:51.896
So I had changed it into
a mathematical problem.

504
00:29:51.896 --> 00:29:55.610
If I take 64,000 ports,
I subtract out the ones I can't use,

505
00:29:55.610 --> 00:29:59.730
restricted by the Operating System,
that gives me 60,000, okay?

506
00:30:01.860 --> 00:30:06.670
Then, I take the ports that
are actually available per device, and

507
00:30:06.670 --> 00:30:09.910
I add that together with the ports that
I've probably been using at any one time

508
00:30:09.910 --> 00:30:13.820
about four per time here,
and that gives me 10.

509
00:30:13.820 --> 00:30:17.800
So when I do that, and
I do the division between them,

510
00:30:17.800 --> 00:30:22.810
in theory my maximum number
of devices behind one public

511
00:30:22.810 --> 00:30:27.950
IP address might be around 6,000 instead.

512
00:30:27.950 --> 00:30:32.630
So it's not what we think, you go,
I can have 64,000 different PCs.

513
00:30:32.630 --> 00:30:37.670
No, every different PC that's gonna
connect is probably gonna consume a bit

514
00:30:37.670 --> 00:30:40.670
of different ports that
they're gonna actually do and

515
00:30:40.670 --> 00:30:45.200
that will end up again kinda of colliding
right there with a single IP address.

516
00:30:45.200 --> 00:30:47.710
If you start experiencing
some connectivity issues

517
00:30:47.710 --> 00:30:51.300
make sure you check NAT and
see what's happening there as well.

518
00:30:51.300 --> 00:30:56.210
So checking NAT, making sure your
firewall rules are up and available.

519
00:30:56.210 --> 00:31:02.050
Verifying how your proxy servers, if they
are actually spread out, in other words,

520
00:31:02.050 --> 00:31:06.270
if they're sized correctly for the number
of connections that you're making.

521
00:31:06.270 --> 00:31:11.660
All that will help enable the client
connectivity that you want to have for

522
00:31:11.660 --> 00:31:13.530
Office 365 and for

523
00:31:13.530 --> 00:31:17.105
your end users to have the best
possible user experience to do so.

524
00:31:17.105 --> 00:31:20.870
So all that will actually
end up helping you as well.

525
00:31:20.870 --> 00:31:23.630
Now, there's only one other
thing that I'm wanna show here.

526
00:31:23.630 --> 00:31:26.362
I know I'm running just
a little bit late on time.

527
00:31:26.362 --> 00:31:28.848
And that there's a website that
can also help you out too.

528
00:31:28.848 --> 00:31:29.579
>> Very good.

529
00:31:29.579 --> 00:31:33.470
>> Now let me just bring up
a website here just briefly.

530
00:31:33.470 --> 00:31:42.240
And this one is
testconnectivity.microsoft.com.

531
00:31:42.240 --> 00:31:45.140
And this is something that's
actually very nice for us.

532
00:31:45.140 --> 00:31:49.421
Where it gives you this ability to
be able to test and see what your

533
00:31:49.421 --> 00:31:54.435
connection is over microsoft.com
based on your connectivity right now.

534
00:31:54.435 --> 00:31:59.159
So if I select Office 365,
notice I can do general test here,

535
00:31:59.159 --> 00:32:06.390
Office 365 Exchange domain connectivity,
link, single sign-on test, you name it.

536
00:32:06.390 --> 00:32:09.681
This can help verify if you
are actually getting what you want.

537
00:32:09.681 --> 00:32:11.391
And it will actually run through and

538
00:32:11.391 --> 00:32:14.583
give you some of those different
dynamics that will test whether or

539
00:32:14.583 --> 00:32:19.120
not you're actually handling everything
the way that everything was set up, okay?

540
00:32:19.120 --> 00:32:22.780
And if everything is good or not,
at least the most basics there.

541
00:32:22.780 --> 00:32:26.820
So use this in conjunction with some of
those other things that we talked about.

542
00:32:26.820 --> 00:32:29.840
And you'll see that you'll
probably at least be able to

543
00:32:29.840 --> 00:32:33.124
guess your best guess at this point,
right?

544
00:32:33.124 --> 00:32:37.410
How to actually make sure that your
clients will get the best possible user

545
00:32:37.410 --> 00:32:40.520
experience with Office 365 as well.

546
00:32:40.520 --> 00:32:41.260
>> Fantastic, Ronnie.

547
00:32:41.260 --> 00:32:44.130
More great information,
enable client connectivity.

548
00:32:44.130 --> 00:32:48.870
And make sure you watch every single
episode of Office 365 that Ronnie is

549
00:32:48.870 --> 00:32:51.680
part of, because you gonna love them all
and they're gonna help you with the exam.

550
00:32:51.680 --> 00:32:53.200
That's number one of course.

551
00:32:53.200 --> 00:32:54.920
And then, go visit our course library.

552
00:32:54.920 --> 00:32:55.893
There's hundreds of videos there.

553
00:32:55.893 --> 00:32:58.403
They're all designed to
help you go further.

554
00:32:58.403 --> 00:33:00.783
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

555
00:33:00.783 --> 00:33:02.224
They will be mighty glad you did.

556
00:33:02.224 --> 00:33:03.036
Thanks for watching.

557
00:33:03.036 --> 00:33:03.930
I'm Zach Memos.

558
00:33:03.930 --> 00:33:05.962
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong
>> And we will see you soon.

559
00:33:05.962 --> 00:33:12.883
[MUSIC]

560
00:33:12.883 --> 00:33:15.681
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to manage rights management through Azure. They demonstrate how to activate it and assign roles for rights management.
episodes.title: Administer Azure Rights Management

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.128
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don-

California [CROSSTALK]

>> Hello, and thank you for

7
00:00:14.229 --> 00:00:16.066

8
00:00:16.066 --> 00:00:19.518
I'm your host Zach Memos and
this is Office 365.

9
00:00:19.518 --> 00:00:23.690
And in this episode we're going to
administer Azure Rights Management.

10
00:00:23.690 --> 00:00:25.050
What's that [LAUGH] all about?

11

We're gonna find out, we've asked
Ronnie Wong to come in and help us.

12
00:00:28.050 --> 00:00:30.450
Ronnie, thanks for being here,
appreciate it very much.

13
00:00:30.450 --> 00:00:35.010
>> Thank you, Zach, for having me back on
the show as we continue on in Office 365,

14
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:38.610
making sure that we understand that
there are a lot of details here.

15
00:00:38.610 --> 00:00:41.133
As we're getting set up, of course, for

16
00:00:41.133 --> 00:00:45.328
our organization to have Office 365
run in the way that we need to.

17
00:00:45.328 --> 00:00:49.996
And we're up in this point where we need
to begin talking about this idea of rights

18
00:00:49.996 --> 00:00:51.190
management.

19
00:00:51.190 --> 00:00:54.120
And that's something that
we really want to get into.

20
00:00:54.120 --> 00:00:57.300
>> So what is Azure Rights Management,
Ronnie?

21
00:00:57.300 --> 00:00:58.826
>> Well,
that's actually a great place to begin.

22
00:00:58.826 --> 00:00:59.499
>> It is!

23
00:00:59.499 --> 00:01:03.100
>> And that's because most of us don't
really understand what this is about.

24
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:07.306
But the simple nature of this,
Zach, when we get started,

25
00:01:07.306 --> 00:01:10.177
is the way that we think about security.

26
00:01:10.177 --> 00:01:13.110
>> Right.
>> Okay, and securing our own data.

27
00:01:13.110 --> 00:01:14.790
Well, when we secure our own data,

28
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:17.985
our own files that we have existing
right now on our network, it's simple.

29
00:01:17.985 --> 00:01:20.849
It's on my network,
it's on our network, right?

30
00:01:20.849 --> 00:01:23.680
And as long as I can
defend the perimeter and

31
00:01:23.680 --> 00:01:27.330
as long as I'm using things like
the permissions that are available to me

32
00:01:27.330 --> 00:01:31.002
within my network,
I can control access to them.

33
00:01:31.002 --> 00:01:33.091
If you're not a member of that network,

34
00:01:33.091 --> 00:01:35.742
you're pretty much denied
access to them as well.

35
00:01:35.742 --> 00:01:37.679
>> Yeah.
>> So if I think about it,

36
00:01:37.679 --> 00:01:42.079
it's essentially like my home,
my castle, that I can defend and

37
00:01:42.079 --> 00:01:46.090
that I have protection of
the data that exist, okay?

38
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:49.820
And that always works,
okay, until it doesn't.

39
00:01:49.820 --> 00:01:52.530
Again, a favorite phrase of
a professor that I used to, said yeah,

40
00:01:52.530 --> 00:01:53.890
that always works until it doesn't.

41
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:56.800
And you might be going, well,
what the heck does that actually mean?

42
00:01:56.800 --> 00:01:59.730
Well, remember that today
what you're starting to see,

43
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:04.070
and especially with Office 365,
is this migration or

44
00:02:04.070 --> 00:02:07.360
hybridization of things that
are beginning to happen.

45
00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:13.521
Not only are we storing files on premises,
but we're also cloud-dependent.

46
00:02:13.521 --> 00:02:16.785
And that means we actually
have some of our services,

47

of everything that we can do here.

405
00:22:26.221 --> 00:22:28.152
Rights management is gonna be important,

406
00:22:28.152 --> 00:22:31.650
especially if you have sensitive
documentation inside your organization.

407
00:22:31.650 --> 00:22:33.918
And you need to make sure
it remains private or

408
00:22:33.918 --> 00:22:36.556
it remains confidential in
the way that you need to.

409
00:22:36.556 --> 00:22:40.501
Rights management is the way to go and
we've now also shown you how you

410
00:22:40.501 --> 00:22:44.500
can actually create a template for
protecting email as well.

411
00:22:44.500 --> 00:22:48.174
So Zach, that really does help us to round
out some of the knowledge that we need

412
00:22:48.174 --> 00:22:51.470
when we start talking about
administering Azure rights management.

413
00:22:51.470 --> 00:22:55.222
>> Ronnie, great and valuable information,
thanks for adding that on too by the way.

414
00:22:55.222 --> 00:22:57.133
So administer Azure rights
management part three.

415
00:22:57.133 --> 00:22:59.706
There's a part one,
there's a part two, watch them all.

416
00:22:59.706 --> 00:23:04.740
In fact, watch everything in
the Office 365 series, it's good stuff.

417
00:23:04.740 --> 00:23:08.177
And also go to our course library,
hundreds of videos there,

418
00:23:08.177 --> 00:23:11.166
all designed for one reason,
to help you go further.

419
00:23:11.166 --> 00:23:15.506
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be very glad you did.

420
00:23:15.506 --> 00:23:17.380
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

421
00:23:17.380 --> 00:23:19.157
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> And we will see you soon.

422
00:23:19.157 --> 00:23:26.548
[MUSIC]

423
00:23:26.548 --> 00:23:29.188
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie examine the different admin roles in Office 365. They also show configure those roles in the admin center and PowerShell.
episodes.title: Manage Office 365 Administrator Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.666
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.666 --> 00:00:06.231
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.231 --> 00:00:08.192
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.192 --> 00:00:12.180
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.180 --> 00:00:14.449
>> Hello again, thank you for
choosing ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.449 --> 00:00:16.750
Helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.750 --> 00:00:17.810
I'm your host, Zack Memes.

8
00:00:17.810 --> 00:00:19.690
This is Office 365.

9
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:25.200
And we're gonna be managing Office 365
administrator roles with Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:26.610
Hey, Ronnie good to see you again sir.

11
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:27.420
Thanks for being here.

12
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:31.270
>> Thank you for having me back here on
the show as we continue on taking a look,

13
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:32.720
of course, at Office 365.

14
00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:36.650
And now we're moving into the realm
of starting to manage a few of

15
00:00:36.650 --> 00:00:38.710
the administrative roles that we have.

16
00:00:38.710 --> 00:00:39.810
And we'll also, of course,

17
00:00:39.810 --> 00:00:44.730
probably in future episodes take a look
at managing just identities, of course.

18
00:00:44.730 --> 00:00:48.510
Users that get added in, and
then even groups a little bit later on.

19
00:00:48.510 --> 00:00:53.009
But this show is specifically talking
about those ideas of the different

20
00:00:53.009 --> 00:00:57.224
administrative roles that
are available inside of Office 365.

21
00:00:57.224 --> 00:01:00.240
And it's very important that we
actually understand what they are?

22
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:02.866
And of course, how do we actually
assign users to them too?

23
00:01:02.866 --> 00:01:06.470
>> So Ronnie, what administrative
roles do we actually have to assign?

24
00:01:06.470 --> 00:01:10.210
>> Yep, well that's a good
questions because it seems like

25
00:01:10.210 --> 00:01:14.200
you really don't have kind of to
thinking about it in two ways, right?

26
00:01:14.200 --> 00:01:15.630
In all practicality,

27
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:20.610
if you have actually created yourself as
an attendant administrator, in theory as

28
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:26.830
long as you're willing to manage
the entirety of Office 365 by yourself.

29
00:01:26.830 --> 00:01:29.750
You don't need any other roles, okay?

30
00:01:29.750 --> 00:01:34.270
Now, but the problem with that though
is that it's not scalable, right?

31
00:01:34.270 --> 00:01:36.082
>> Right.
>> But an organization that begins

32
00:01:36.082 --> 00:01:37.394
with five or ten people,

33
00:01:37.394 --> 00:01:40.970
that attendant administrator is
probably gonna be able to do that.

34
00:01:40.970 --> 00:01:43.430
And as long as it says at around five or
ten people,

35
00:01:43.430 --> 00:01:49.040
there's probably never a need to start
assigning administrative roles at all.

36
00:01:49.040 --> 00:01:50.920
Why?
Because when they're signed in,

37
00:01:50.920 --> 00:01:53.890
they're considered
the Global administrator and

38
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:57.610
that Global administrator gives them
the permissions for everything, okay?

39
00:01:57.610 --> 00:01:59.440
It doesn't matter what you need done.

40
00:01:59.440 --> 00:02:05.514
That one person can actually do anything
that we need them to do administratively.

41
00:02:05.514 --> 00:02:09.912
But Zach, the problem that we have is
simple, just like what we know and what

42
00:02:09.912 --> 00:02:14.821
we've actually discovered and found out
over years, and years, of working in IT.

43
00:02:14.821 --> 00:02:19.733
A network rarely remains static and
what that means, of course is that, and

44
00:02:19.733 --> 00:02:23.511
a couple of things right,
one in terms of just equipment.

45
00:02:23.511 --> 00:02:28.470
The equipment may remain the same, but the
technology continues to change behind it.

46
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:30.600
Operating systems get upgraded.

47
00:02:30.600 --> 00:02:33.644
Technology that we used two or
three years ago, is no longer viable, so

48
00:02:33.644 --> 00:02:35.392
we switch it out with other technology.

49
00:02:35.392 --> 00:02:36.865
>> Or two weeks ago for
that matter, [LAUGH]

50
00:02:36.865 --> 00:02:38.340
>> Or two weeks ago sometimes.

51
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:40.330
Yeah, there's no doubt,
it becomes a little bit quicker,

52
00:02:40.330 --> 00:02:44.280
but also the people in your
organization from a year ago

53
00:02:44.280 --> 00:02:48.140
might be starkly different
than the people you have now.

54
00:02:48.140 --> 00:02:52.620
And even the idea of the size of
the organization continues to change.

55
00:02:52.620 --> 00:02:55.250
So good example of that Zach, is IT ProTV.

56
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:58.562
Zach, even since you've
come on board at ITProTV,

57
00:02:58.562 --> 00:03:01.170
there's been several additions, right?

58
00:03:01.170 --> 00:03:02.990
Kind of struggling, right?

59
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:05.108
>> Yes, since May 2017, several editions.

60
00:03:05.108 --> 00:03:07.613
>> Yeah, it starts to startle you,

61
00:03:07.613 --> 00:03:12.720
wait a minute since I've been on board,
we've hired so many more.

62
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:16.510
Yeah, Zach can look around the room
in our morning standard and go, wow,

63
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:20.120
there's a lot more people
here now than there were.

64
00:03:20.120 --> 00:03:22.130
When Zack was first hired on and

65
00:03:22.130 --> 00:03:25.480
when I was first hired on it
was really like five of us.

66
00:03:25.480 --> 00:03:26.930
>> Goodness.
>> There was five and

67
00:03:26.930 --> 00:03:30.170
then we were just kinda standing
around just in a room and just saying,

68
00:03:30.170 --> 00:03:31.161
all right what are we doing today?

69
00:03:31.161 --> 00:03:33.228
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that was pretty much it, and

70
00:03:33.228 --> 00:03:36.303
it took us all about 35,
40 seconds to do so.

71
00:03:36.303 --> 00:03:39.388
But now,
organizations continue to change and

72
00:03:39.388 --> 00:03:44.631
when something like that happens and
Office 365 is a part of that technology,

73
00:03:44.631 --> 00:03:48.870
now you have to be getting
the idea of scalability, okay?

74
00:03:48.870 --> 00:03:54.840
Because there's just not enough time for
one individual to manage anything anymore.

75
00:03:54.840 --> 00:03:59.050
So that means that what we have
to do is we now have to depend

76
00:03:59.050 --> 00:04:02.330
on the idea of actually adding
in some more administrators.

77
00:04:02.330 --> 00:04:03.630
Now in theory Zach,

78
00:04:03.630 --> 00:04:08.780
if I wanted to I could give everybody
the idea that tenet administrator rights.

79
00:04:08.780 --> 00:04:13.930
The Global administrator make them
responsible for everything that goes on.

80
00:04:13.930 --> 00:04:17.890
That's not best practice nor is it good
practice to do something like that.

81
00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:21.508
Because there are areas that we really
don't want certain people to be able to

82
00:04:21.508 --> 00:04:22.677
change and manipulate,

83
00:04:22.677 --> 00:04:26.201
and then there's other things that we
don't really want them to control.

84
00:04:26.201 --> 00:04:28.935
So instead we can separate those out, and

85
00:04:28.935 --> 00:04:34.120
in Office 365 they gave us several
different roles that we wanna consider.

86
00:04:34.120 --> 00:04:37.691
So let's take a look at how we can
actually see these different roles, and

87
00:04:37.691 --> 00:04:39.889
let's talk about each
of them just briefly.

88
00:04:39.889 --> 00:04:40.732
>> Good.
>> We're not gonna go

89
00:04:40.732 --> 00:04:41.570
into a super deep dive.

90
00:04:41.570 --> 00:04:44.100
We've already talked about them
a little bit in a previous episode.

91
00:04:44.100 --> 00:04:45.167
But this is a good refresher and

92
00:04:45.167 --> 00:04:46.903
it's actually something
we have to be able to do.

93
00:04:46.903 --> 00:04:47.620
>> Very nice.

94
00:04:47.620 --> 00:04:48.250
>> So here it is,

95
00:04:48.250 --> 00:04:52.370
I've logged in as our Global
administrator right now at Cherokee.

96
00:04:52.370 --> 00:04:55.540
And I'm going to select the Admin tile.

97
00:04:56.820 --> 00:05:01.040
And once I do so that should bring me
into the Office 365 Admin center for

98
00:05:01.040 --> 00:05:02.380
my tenancy.

99
00:05:02.380 --> 00:05:06.310
And now, underneath the first
grouping here that we see

100
00:05:06.310 --> 00:05:10.120
on the Admin center under Users,
I'm going to select Users.

101
00:05:10.120 --> 00:05:12.020
That should help me to focus in and

102
00:05:12.020 --> 00:05:17.190
these are the accounts we've been working
with since the beginning of the show.

103
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:23.292
So here on the first day of our
shooting of 70-346 when Zack on air,

104
00:05:23.292 --> 00:05:27.193
Cherokee and I did the show,
and I signed on and

105
00:05:27.193 --> 00:05:31.010
created the Global administrator account.

106
00:05:32.075 --> 00:05:34.710
So you see where it's actually
the Global administrator here.

107
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:37.780
But if I am doing this for
another organization, right?

108
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:39.545
Zach, I've kind of mentioned this before.

109
00:05:39.545 --> 00:05:41.570
>> Mm-hm.
>> If I'm the one setting this up,

110
00:05:41.570 --> 00:05:45.010
I really don't want to
use this account again.

111
00:05:45.010 --> 00:05:46.410
Now do I still have all those privileges?

112
00:05:46.410 --> 00:05:51.700
Yes, but if I'm not actually really
a part of that organization.

113
00:05:51.700 --> 00:05:55.703
Then the rest of the configuration
of everything that I do,

114
00:05:55.703 --> 00:05:57.872
it shouldn't be under my name.

115
00:05:57.872 --> 00:06:02.768
It shouldn't be tied to me in any way so
that's when we also took Cherokee's

116
00:06:02.768 --> 00:06:07.520
role here, and then we also assigned
her the Global administrator role.

117
00:06:07.520 --> 00:06:08.880
Now how did I do that?

118
00:06:08.880 --> 00:06:13.391
Well, let me double click
on Cherokee's account here.

119
00:06:13.391 --> 00:06:16.458
And now,
when you hashly do something like this,

120
00:06:16.458 --> 00:06:19.670
you can now see here it
is Cherokee's account.

121
00:06:19.670 --> 00:06:23.939
Let's scroll down, we are looking under
Cherokee's account, and were looking for

122
00:06:23.939 --> 00:06:24.570
what it says role.

123
00:06:24.570 --> 00:06:26.875
And you see where it says
Global administrator.

124
00:06:26.875 --> 00:06:29.470
And at the beginning of that
she didn't have any in role.

125
00:06:29.470 --> 00:06:34.770
So if I select Edit, now you could
see where we were able to do that.

126
00:06:34.770 --> 00:06:38.680
Now, I was logged in as me, as Ronnie,
and then I was able to select this.

127
00:06:38.680 --> 00:06:43.290
But notice the Global administrator
cannot edit their own security settings,

128
00:06:43.290 --> 00:06:45.790
it requires another Global
administrator to do so.

129
00:06:45.790 --> 00:06:48.760
>> So like, you got like a super admin,
is that what the deal is here?

130
00:06:48.760 --> 00:06:51.010
>> Yeah, this is kinda the same thing, but

131
00:06:51.010 --> 00:06:54.260
at this point you can see that this
is where we can go to assign that.

132
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:57.850
Now, once we did that though, Zach, okay?

133
00:06:57.850 --> 00:07:01.185
We also ended up creating an account for
you, Zach.

134
00:07:01.185 --> 00:07:04.046
>> [LAUGH]
>> And this is where I'm logged in as

135
00:07:04.046 --> 00:07:08.550
Cherokee as you see up here, and I believe
we made you some type of administrator.

136
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:14.140
Password administrator is what we also
assigned to you, and I click Edit.

137
00:07:14.140 --> 00:07:18.174
And it's right here, signed in this
Cherokee, notice that I could actually

138
00:07:18.174 --> 00:07:21.166
create now Zach,
as a Global administrator wanted too.

139
00:07:21.166 --> 00:07:25.590
Or we're really focusing on these
particular administrator roles right

140
00:07:25.590 --> 00:07:27.000
here, okay?

141
00:07:27.000 --> 00:07:30.860
So when we start talking about
these types of administrative roles

142
00:07:30.860 --> 00:07:35.525
it is because that you realize your
organization is going to scale out, okay?

143
00:07:35.525 --> 00:07:39.027
And that's important, understanding
the possibilities of scaling up and

144
00:07:39.027 --> 00:07:41.936
scaling out is actually something
that we want to understand.

145
00:07:41.936 --> 00:07:42.712
>> Okay.

146
00:07:42.712 --> 00:07:46.370
>> Administratively, when we start talking
were normally talking about scaling

147
00:07:46.370 --> 00:07:47.144
out-
>> Right

148
00:07:47.144 --> 00:07:50.175
>> Office 365 will allow us to scale up as

149
00:07:50.175 --> 00:07:51.609
much as we want to.

150
00:07:51.609 --> 00:07:57.618
Zach, we can add from five users today,
or two users To 10,000 users in a day,

151
00:07:57.618 --> 00:08:02.472
Office 365 says I can scale up to do that,
it's no big deal.

152
00:08:02.472 --> 00:08:05.096
>> Wow.
>> But administratively though, Zach,

153
00:08:05.096 --> 00:08:10.151
that's an impossibility, with just
Cherokee being the global administrator,

154
00:08:10.151 --> 00:08:12.890
and you just being the password reset.

155
00:08:12.890 --> 00:08:17.248
With 10,000 users, if 9,000 of
those people right now, Zach, say,

156
00:08:17.248 --> 00:08:18.646
I need my password reset.

157
00:08:18.646 --> 00:08:23.372
And they have to come to you, that's 9,000
password resets that may take a little bit

158
00:08:23.372 --> 00:08:25.690
more time and challenge than you think.

159
00:08:25.690 --> 00:08:27.928
>> And we might have to question
who we've hired [LAUGH].

160
00:08:27.928 --> 00:08:31.639
>> Exactly, but it kinda lets you know,
right, that the scaling and

161
00:08:31.639 --> 00:08:36.096
the administrative side is when we start
talking about the idea of scaling out.

162
00:08:36.096 --> 00:08:39.633
Okay, so when we start doing that,
then we start planning for

163
00:08:39.633 --> 00:08:44.540
the future a little bit and saying, all
right, how do I need to scale out here?

164
00:08:44.540 --> 00:08:48.250
Well, there's two different things that
can happen, if you are only scaling

165
00:08:48.250 --> 00:08:52.550
a little bit, I could also make Zach
not only the password administrator.

166
00:08:52.550 --> 00:08:55.090
That one's easy, and that's what
I wanted to do at the beginning.

167
00:08:55.090 --> 00:08:58.834
And right, this means that Zach is
in charge of helping people to reset

168
00:08:58.834 --> 00:09:01.887
passwords, allowing them to
do stuff like that as well.

169
00:09:01.887 --> 00:09:06.314
But I could also make Zach,
if I wanted to, the billing administrator,

170
00:09:06.314 --> 00:09:08.790
notice that I can check mark both.

171
00:09:08.790 --> 00:09:13.242
And that allows me to scale out a little
bit, but not exactly a lot, okay?

172
00:09:13.242 --> 00:09:17.949
>> So like in a smaller enterprise,
I've noticed that they will assign one

173
00:09:17.949 --> 00:09:21.860
person or maybe two,
all those roles, is that not right?

174
00:09:21.860 --> 00:09:27.310
>> Yes, yeah, so you can actually see that
right here, it's fairly simple to do so.

175
00:09:27.310 --> 00:09:31.700
Now by default, when we start talking
about this idea of the administrator,

176
00:09:31.700 --> 00:09:34.960
you'll notice that there's a lot of
different administrators right here.

177
00:09:34.960 --> 00:09:37.357
But really, kinda the ones
that we're centered in around,

178
00:09:37.357 --> 00:09:40.506
especially when we start talking about
scaling up and scaling out here, okay?

179
00:09:40.506 --> 00:09:45.463
We're really talking about this idea of
the billing administrator, the Exchange

180
00:09:45.463 --> 00:09:50.493
administrator, the password administrator,
the Skype administrator, service

181
00:09:50.493 --> 00:09:56.140
administrator, SharePoint administrator,
and user management administrator.

182
00:09:56.140 --> 00:10:00.340
So in this one, it's seven roles, but
if you include global administrator,

183
00:10:00.340 --> 00:10:02.040
it becomes eight.

184
00:10:02.040 --> 00:10:05.341
So those are kinda the default
ones that are right there.

185
00:10:05.341 --> 00:10:08.096
Now, the great thing is,
with the global administrator,

186
00:10:08.096 --> 00:10:11.347
when they're actually the ones
creating and setting everything up,

187
00:10:11.347 --> 00:10:14.490
that's pretty much all you
really want to use that one for.

188
00:10:14.490 --> 00:10:19.080
But at the beginning here, you may
actually consider adding in one of these,

189
00:10:19.080 --> 00:10:22.218
if not all of these, depending on
what you actually end up needing.

190
00:10:22.218 --> 00:10:26.066
So the billing administrator makes sense,
somebody needs to

191
00:10:26.066 --> 00:10:30.285
purchase additional subscriptions for
your tenant if you need to.

192
00:10:30.285 --> 00:10:35.245
Or can actually say, I'm not gonna pay for
those anymore, and reduce that,

193
00:10:35.245 --> 00:10:38.620
well, the billing
administrator can handle that.

194
00:10:38.620 --> 00:10:42.870
Exchange administrators are, of course,
for those that handle the email services.

195
00:10:42.870 --> 00:10:46.600
Skype for Business is those that actually
handle the idea of the collaboration as

196
00:10:46.600 --> 00:10:48.300
well, a little bit of collaboration.

197
00:10:48.300 --> 00:10:51.384
The communication software
such as Skype for Business,

198
00:10:51.384 --> 00:10:54.221
and the SIP phones that you
may also be using as well.

199
00:10:54.221 --> 00:10:57.966
Services administrator, of course, are all
the services that users are normally also

200
00:10:57.966 --> 00:11:00.303
thinking about, and then,
of course, SharePoint.

201
00:11:00.303 --> 00:11:01.789
And then just user management,

202
00:11:01.789 --> 00:11:05.770
somebody to help somebody's user
account to get set up, all that stuff.

203
00:11:05.770 --> 00:11:08.790
Onboarding, you name it,
all that's actually possible for

204
00:11:08.790 --> 00:11:12.570
us, depending on what we need set, okay.

205
00:11:12.570 --> 00:11:14.290

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to manage users and passwords. They configure the password management for the tenant. Also they discuss and demonstrate how to manage user groups and bulk add users too.
episodes.title: Manage Passwords and Users

Welcome to ITProTV,

As we continue to move forward through

Office 365, especially the identities and

It is a good part of what we

something that we all have to deal

>> Yeah, there's not doubt that both of

We'll get kind of set up a little bit

a little bit later.

But what is actually gonna

Whether it's biometrics or something else

So Zach, in terms of passwords they

76

And the reason that they're actually
stolen very easily a lot of times is they

77

don't even have to come into contact with

78
00:04:17.658 --> 00:04:22.263
Most people fall into regular patterns of
passwords in the sense that they know that

there's a limited set of passwords that
just about everybody's used over time.

80
00:04:27.350 --> 00:04:29.410
And the majority of those

81

are the ones that still have the word

82
00:04:33.825 --> 00:04:35.665
>> [LAUGH] I can't imagine
anyone doing that still.

83
00:04:35.665 --> 00:04:37.535
>> Yeah,
you don't think it would happen but

84
00:04:37.535 --> 00:04:40.505
on the Internet it still happens,
and the very fact that

85
00:04:40.505 --> 00:04:44.525
a lot of the passwords that have
actually remained unchanged over time.

86
00:04:44.525 --> 00:04:47.665
What you were mentioning
was another factor.

87
00:04:47.665 --> 00:04:51.045
So even though you might have a company or
might have a,

let's just take an individual and

00:04:53.660 --> 00:04:57.501
And individual may have opened up

00:04:57.501 --> 00:05:01.224
What are the chances that have actually
change the password if they don't told to

00:05:01.224 --> 00:05:01.890
change it?

92
00:05:01.890 --> 00:05:02.760
Probably not good.

93
00:05:02.760 --> 00:05:05.750
They probably haven't change and all,
it's probably still the same password

94
00:05:05.750 --> 00:05:09.210
that it opened up the account
let 20 years ago, okay?

95
00:05:09.210 --> 00:05:15.560
And when you think about that staggering

96
00:05:15.560 --> 00:05:18.823
More than likely, their email accounts

97
00:05:18.823 --> 00:05:22.293
and they're just waiting for that right
piece of information to come across and

98
00:05:22.293 --> 00:05:23.567
pull that information too.

99
00:05:23.567 --> 00:05:28.040
So it's very easy, essentially, for
somebody to get access to the password.

100
00:05:28.040 --> 00:05:32.600
Because we do fall in those patterns and
we do tend to reuse these passwords

101
00:05:32.600 --> 00:05:35.505
that everybody on the planet
has used over and over again.

102
00:05:35.505 --> 00:05:36.050
>> Mm-hm.

103
00:05:36.050 --> 00:05:39.920
>> So it really limits that pool and
that idea.

104
00:05:39.920 --> 00:05:43.750
So some of the best practices of course
over the decades that we've talk about and

105
00:05:43.750 --> 00:05:45.380
that we've ended up using.

106
00:05:45.380 --> 00:05:49.604
Of course, is changing the passwords on a
regular basis like what Zach were saying.

107
00:05:49.604 --> 00:05:50.490
>> Absolutely.

108
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:55.400
>> It absolutely helped and a some that
does hard that most people don't like, but

109
00:05:55.400 --> 00:05:57.850
as a best practice I try to do that.

110
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:00.420
So even when I was teaching

00:06:00.420 --> 00:06:05.880
I told students that I try to follow my
own teaching and I took all my accounts.

112

And I told it to tell me to change my

00:06:10.070 --> 00:06:12.330
Or every four weeks, whatever it might be.

114
00:06:12.330 --> 00:06:15.160
It was annoying getting those particular

00:06:17.770 --> 00:06:22.106
But I'm realizing it was very

00:06:22.106 --> 00:06:24.424
I'm just giving an attacker more and

00:06:24.424 --> 00:06:27.882
more opportunity to simply
try their hack against me.

119
00:06:27.882 --> 00:06:28.760
>> That's right.
>> So, instead

120
00:06:28.760 --> 00:06:32.450
changing them makes them at least
reset the same way that I have to.

121
00:06:32.450 --> 00:06:35.945
And then, they actually get phased with
a new challenge in the same way I do to.

122
00:06:35.945 --> 00:06:37.880

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to manage users and passwords.  They configure the password management for the tenant.  Also they discuss and demonstrate how to manage user groups and bulk add users too.

As we continue on with Office
365 managed passwords and

This is kind of a third part to kind of a

Showing you how to manage those and

now were at this place where I know it's
become sound strange but we're really

19
00:00:46.853 --> 00:00:51.146
trying to get rid of passwords is what

20

And talking about some of the things
that are built into Office 365 to help

00:00:55.157 --> 00:00:56.290

And you might be wondering
at some point hopefully,

00:00:59.650 --> 00:01:02.370

00:01:02.370 --> 00:01:04.130
Where you realizing that,

00:01:04.130 --> 00:01:09.370
if there is a weakness in the systems that
we have in place in terms of security,

26
00:01:09.370 --> 00:01:13.170
authentication is probably one
of the weak points that we have.

27
00:01:13.170 --> 00:01:16.970
And the reason why there's weaknesses
there is that it kind of began on a weak

28
00:01:16.970 --> 00:01:20.180
premise at the very foundation of it,

29
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:24.565
It used to be at some point in time,

a challenge, it was a pit, almost
like a chess game between you and me.

and that was pretty much about it, okay?

33
00:01:38.310 --> 00:01:42.005
But then there came this idea
that we also needed to do,

34

what better authentication which
included both a user name and password.

35
00:01:47.310 --> 00:01:50.030
So that was considered a new
model of authentication.

36
00:01:50.030 --> 00:01:55.470
Not just having a simple password anymore
but now also username and password.

37
00:01:55.470 --> 00:01:59.310
Trying to guess the right combinations of
those two, seems actually made it stronger

38
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:01.940
because you might build and
guess what my passwords Zach.

39
00:02:01.940 --> 00:02:04.395
But you might not know what my
username is in that machine.

40
00:02:04.395 --> 00:02:08.726
So it's very possible but getting
the right combination, all together where

41
00:02:08.726 --> 00:02:12.676
you can actually go, I got the right
password with the right username.

42
00:02:12.676 --> 00:02:15.849
Now became a bit more challenging for

43
00:02:15.849 --> 00:02:20.762
us getting access and
then protecting ourselves.

44
00:02:20.762 --> 00:02:24.320
That didn't take long before
it was relatively easy and

45
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:29.800
the reason why is that users tend to fall
into patterns, like we've said before,

46
00:02:29.800 --> 00:02:34.810
where they reuse the same password or
they don't change those passwords.

47
00:02:34.810 --> 00:02:38.180
Where they actually kind of
almost telegraph their passwords

48
00:02:38.180 --> 00:02:40.980
in ways that they don't realize
what they're doing, okay?

49
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:46.040
So the password part and keeping
sign like that is also challenging.

50
00:02:46.040 --> 00:02:49.836
The other thing is the only way that we
actually started improving on that right

at the beginning is simple.

So in something like that Zach, when we
talk about making more complex passwords,

I can't make your username
any more complex than this.

Okay, but
I can make your password more complex.

So if I pick on Zach for a moment,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie talk about managing identities with powershell.  They emphasize the use of powershell in configuring passwords, creating bulk user accounts with CSV files, user account management such as licensing management and deleting accounts one at a time or in bulk.
episodes.title: Cloud Identities with PowerShell

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review some of the Azure AD cmdlets.  These commands require connecting to Office 365 and or Azure AD.  They review multiple cmdlets to help with user management, group management, service principal management, domain management and administrative unit management.

let's also the idea of the different

me all the details of my particular

Of course you can change

But I don't have any other

287

So here is Set-MsolUserLicense,
it modifies licenses,

You can also use this to help

294
00:16:53.520 --> 00:16:56.540
So on the licensing features,
they're all there.

295
00:16:56.540 --> 00:16:58.400
They are available for you.

296
00:16:58.400 --> 00:17:01.130
It can all be done inside

Remember that when you're doing this,

Well, what we can do is,

network administrative unit

management allows us to essentially

It also allows us to subdivide up for

This is the area that you also

All right, so taking a look at the

The rest is really for

So don't think that I'll just ignore this.

It's not something that you want to do.

It doesn't mean that you have to spend

And what they're for, and kind of

00:22:02.890 --> 00:22:08.100
So Zach, let me kind of, again,

So if I told you, okay?

The idea here and

And the great thing is the name

If I said, Zach,
we've got a complex Active Directory and

And you look at different

Well, hopefully it makes sense that

00:22:31.801 --> 00:22:34.850
is what, administrative unit somewhere,
>> Mm-hm, absolutely.

>> Makes sense, okay?

And you take a look at these commands,

administrative unit,

So notice like this one,
Remove-MsolScopedRoleMember, okay?

Well that's a little bit different.

But overall though, there's a lot of

The same thing inside of this, the company

Partner, partner, partner, okay?

Makes sense when you start

So taking a look at stuff like this,

Is really helpful in the long run on

But if you don't know what they are,

So take the time and go through

And that will actually help

So don't think that you have to

But you do need to at least be

And what are some of the types of

00:23:45.970 --> 00:23:49.060
And then I can eliminate from

00:23:49.060 --> 00:23:50.850

Or somebody may ask me about that,

00:23:56.010 --> 00:23:59.080
All right Zach, so there's a lot of

But we won't see a ton of them in show as

But we will actually see the majority

So dont' overlook that fact.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to create security groups in Office 365.  They demonstrate creating, editing and deleting a security group using the admin center interface and using the powershell connection to do so.
episodes.title: Create Security Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.635
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.635 --> 00:00:06.532
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.532 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:11.728
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.728 --> 00:00:15.611
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV, helping you grow and

6
00:00:15.611 --> 00:00:17.240
learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:17.240 --> 00:00:19.585
I'm your host Zach Memos,
and this is Office 365.

8
00:00:19.585 --> 00:00:22.700
We're gonna create security
groups with Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:22.700 --> 00:00:25.500
Ronnie, great to see you again,
sir, thanks for joining us.

10
00:00:25.500 --> 00:00:26.990
>> Thank you Zach for
having me on the show,

11
00:00:26.990 --> 00:00:30.410
as we continue on in our
journey through Office 365.

12
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:33.710
And we're taking a little bit
of time here and talking about,

13
00:00:33.710 --> 00:00:39.480
of course, managing users, and now we're
actually talking about groups as well.

14
00:00:39.480 --> 00:00:42.590
The idea of managing users is
a fairly simple concept, and

15
00:00:42.590 --> 00:00:45.130
we've done this throughout
our entire series.

16
00:00:45.130 --> 00:00:46.620
We've created user accounts,

17
00:00:46.620 --> 00:00:50.470
and showed you how you can add
roles to them as an administrator.

18
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:54.190
We've showed you how you can assign
different licenses of subscriptions to

19
00:00:54.190 --> 00:00:54.720
them as well.

20
00:00:54.720 --> 00:01:00.880
And we showed you how to remove them from
the Office 365 users that are out there.

21
00:01:00.880 --> 00:01:04.940
But at the same time, we actually
realized that as we continue to grow,

22
00:01:04.940 --> 00:01:09.810
and we talk about the idea of scalability,
right, and the ability to manage that.

23
00:01:09.810 --> 00:01:13.562
It becomes a little more difficult
to manage individual users, so

24
00:01:13.562 --> 00:01:18.185
that is another reason for us to actually
think about the idea of a security group.

25
00:01:18.185 --> 00:01:20.855
>> So Ronnie, obvious question,
what is a security group,

26
00:01:20.855 --> 00:01:22.115
can you define that for us?

27
00:01:22.115 --> 00:01:25.691
>> Yes, well, as easy as it is,
when it breaks down to

28
00:01:25.691 --> 00:01:30.533
everything that we want to do we can
define it in many different ways.

29
00:01:30.533 --> 00:01:33.357
But the easiest way to think about it,
right,

30
00:01:33.357 --> 00:01:37.940
is a security group is something that
we can say how we control access.

31
00:01:37.940 --> 00:01:41.060
Okay, and
it allows us to build a control access for

32
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:44.270
a group of users,
is what it allows us to do.

33
00:01:44.270 --> 00:01:48.652
So instead of me having me to
actually take Zach's user account and

34
00:01:48.652 --> 00:01:52.018
Cherokee's user account and
my user account, and

35
00:01:52.018 --> 00:01:56.813
individually assign them access, or
deny them access to what I want to.

36
00:01:56.813 --> 00:02:00.310
I can create just a group,
which is a representation,

37
00:02:00.310 --> 00:02:04.990
okay, of what I might want for them,
and I just assigned a name to it.

38
00:02:04.990 --> 00:02:08.830
And instead, I assign those
access permissions to the group.

39
00:02:08.830 --> 00:02:10.870
If Zach gets added to that group, well,

40
00:02:10.870 --> 00:02:14.630
he automatically gets those
permissions as well, or the denial.

41
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:18.080
And the same thing with everybody that's
added into the group as well, okay?

42
00:02:18.080 --> 00:02:21.060
So, for anything else, right,
it's about ease of management or

43
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:23.040
less administrative effort.

44
00:02:23.040 --> 00:02:28.020
And, Zach, that's a term that, if we
are not familiar with Microsoft exams,

45
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:31.440
then we need to become more
familiar with Microsoft exams.

46
00:02:31.440 --> 00:02:35.540
Any time that you see that idea, and
especially when you start to read

47
00:02:35.540 --> 00:02:39.350
more about the way that Microsoft does
things, it's always about scalability.

48
00:02:39.350 --> 00:02:44.170
And the idea of scalability here for what
you're gonna be doing as an administrator

49
00:02:44.170 --> 00:02:47.100
is that you want to be able
to do this effectively.

50
00:02:47.100 --> 00:02:50.611
But you wanna to do it with the least
administrative effort possible.

51
00:02:50.611 --> 00:02:54.530
And when you start talking about access

00:30:49.170 --> 00:30:51.260
Creating security groups.

507
00:30:51.260 --> 00:30:53.410
Couldn't be easier when
Ronnie is teaching, right?

508
00:30:53.410 --> 00:30:56.680
And there's a whole bunch of videos
inside of the Office 365 series.

509
00:30:56.680 --> 00:30:57.766
Make sure you watch them all.

510
00:30:57.766 --> 00:31:00.050
Also go to our course library.

511
00:31:00.050 --> 00:31:03.935
Hundreds of videos, all designed to
do one thing, help you go further.

512
00:31:03.935 --> 00:31:05.780
And tell everybody you
know about IT Pro TV.

513
00:31:05.780 --> 00:31:07.140
They'll be glad you did.

514
00:31:07.140 --> 00:31:07.860
Thanks for watching.

515
00:31:07.860 --> 00:31:08.730
I'm Zach Memos.

516
00:31:08.730 --> 00:31:09.460
>> And I'm Ronny Wong.

517
00:31:09.460 --> 00:31:11.126
>> And we'll see you soon.

518
00:31:11.126 --> 00:31:17.275
[MUSIC]

519
00:31:17.275 --> 00:31:19.130
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro Tv.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss integration of on-premises Active Directory and Azure Active Directory.
episodes.title: Prepare AD Synchronization to O365
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.023 --> 00:00:02.615
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.615 --> 00:00:05.951
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:05.951 --> 00:00:08.031
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.031 --> 00:00:11.695
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.695 --> 00:00:13.861
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPro.TV,

6
00:00:13.861 --> 00:00:15.577
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:15.577 --> 00:00:19.046
I'm your host Zach Memos as
we continue with Office 365.

8
00:00:19.046 --> 00:00:24.373
We're gonna prepare AD synchronization
to Office 365 today, and the person

9
00:00:24.373 --> 00:00:29.490
helping us do that, of course, is
the one and only IT wizard, Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:29.490 --> 00:00:30.600
Ronnie, glad to have you here.

11
00:00:30.600 --> 00:00:31.555
Thank you so very much.

12
00:00:31.555 --> 00:00:35.848
>> Well, thank you for having me back on
the show as we continue on our journey

13
00:00:35.848 --> 00:00:39.350
together in learning more
about setting up Office 365.

14
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:43.220
And this is where it starts to jump a
little bit more into some technical issues

15
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:45.818
that we may not have considered.

16
00:00:45.818 --> 00:00:48.776
So up into this point in the series,
if you've been watching from the very

17
00:00:48.776 --> 00:00:50.793
beginning in the way that
we've been doing this.

18
00:00:50.793 --> 00:00:55.511
We really haven't talked about
the idea that you may already have

19
00:00:55.511 --> 00:00:59.381
an on-premises Active Directory network,
right?

20
00:00:59.381 --> 00:01:03.191
So you've got your infrastructure already
set up, you've got your group policies.

21
00:01:03.191 --> 00:01:07.285
You've got everything set up there and
it works the way that you want to, okay?

22
00:01:07.285 --> 00:01:11.894
And now you're introducing a cloud
environment into that situation,

23
00:01:11.894 --> 00:01:16.906
well what is going to happen when we
actually start to do something like that?

24
00:01:16.906 --> 00:01:20.580
Well, there's a couple of things
that can end up happening here.

25
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:24.290
And usually the kind of
beginning aspect of this, right?

26
00:01:24.290 --> 00:01:28.779
Is that we go, they'll just have to
use an Office 365 login as well as,

27
00:01:28.779 --> 00:01:33.012
of course, an Active Directory login
when they're here on our network.

28
00:01:33.012 --> 00:01:37.950
When they need Office 365, they'll also
need to do something like that as well.

29
00:01:37.950 --> 00:01:42.890
But when you start to now move into
the direction and realm of saying,

30
00:01:42.890 --> 00:01:46.850
we want to kinda merge all
of that together as one.

31
00:01:46.850 --> 00:01:50.730
There may be this idea that
what we want to do instead

32
00:01:50.730 --> 00:01:55.620
is to talk about the idea of synchronizing
both of our on-premises along

33
00:01:55.620 --> 00:02:00.710
with Azure's Active Directory as well and
Office 365 all together.

34
00:02:00.710 --> 00:02:03.631
>> So Ronnie, why go through all
that effort of synchronization?

35
00:02:03.631 --> 00:02:08.880
>> Well, hopefully it makes sense here,
but sometimes it doesn't, right?

36
00:02:08.880 --> 00:02:12.976
So it's not about really some magic
voodoo that happens in the background.

37
00:02:12.976 --> 00:02:17.808
It is about trying to really provide as
seamless of an experience as possible,

38
00:02:17.808 --> 00:02:18.690
right?

39
00:02:18.690 --> 00:02:23.518
For things like email, in the beginning
here, and then even managing, of course,

40
00:02:23.518 --> 00:02:26.243
Office products that you
have along with that.

41
00:02:26.243 --> 00:02:29.720
So your Active Directory organization,
as well as your Exchange,

42
00:02:29.720 --> 00:02:31.679
we want that to be a seamless process.

43
00:02:31.679 --> 00:02:36.201
Where people don't really know whether
their e-mail is going to be running

44
00:02:36.201 --> 00:02:41.220
through an Exchange on-premises, or
even in the cloud out there somewhere.

45
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:44.990
The synchronization allows us
the first steps in setting that up

46
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:47.930
to ensure that something like
this also happens as well.

47
00:02:47.930 --> 00:02:50.594
It also allows us to reuse, essentially,

48
00:02:50.594 --> 00:02:53.629
the infrastructure that
we've already setup.

49
00:02:53.629 --> 00:02:58.501
Such as our groups and our contacts
that have been created on-premises

50
00:02:58.501 --> 00:03:01.760
to actually also get
added into Office 365.

51
00:03:01.760 --> 00:03:06.453
So I don't have to go and do and go,
all right, I've got 400 users inside of

52
00:03:06.453 --> 00:03:10.669
my Active Directory network, or
4,000 for all you care, okay?

53
00:03:10.669 --> 00:03:13.790
But we've already talked
about adding in bulk users.

54
00:03:13.790 --> 00:03:18.060
Yes, we can do that and we know how
to do that, but I don't have to.

55
00:03:18.060 --> 00:03:21.420
If I can use the synchronization
tools that are available to me,

56
00:03:21.420 --> 00:03:24.960
I can go ahead and
get those accounts setup in Office 365.

57
00:03:24.960 --> 00:03:28.993
But it's not a complete turnkey solution.

58
00:03:28.993 --> 00:03:31.872
Even if you do something like that,
you still have to go in and

59
00:03:31.872 --> 00:03:33.740
assign licenses a little bit later on.

60
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:37.630
But just kind of realize that
that will also do that, too.

61
00:03:37.630 --> 00:03:41.090
Now the other thing that's also
an advantage of this is, because it is

62
00:03:41.090 --> 00:03:45.700
a synchronization tool, whatever we modify
on-premises, in terms of objects and

63
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:52.350
groups, can also, again, accept and have
those modifications in Office 365 as well.

64
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:57.131
So let me go ahead and show you kinda the
examples of what I've just been talking

65
00:03:57.131 --> 00:04:02.067
about, and then we'll move into what we
also have to think about as well, okay?

66
00:04:02.067 --> 00:04:09.110
So here on my screen, this is kind of
the idea right at the beginning right?

67
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:13.490
So currently, let's say that we
are over here on the left-hand side.

68
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:16.700
Here is our ITPro.TV demo network.

69
00:04:16.700 --> 00:04:19.909
And that means that when
a user signs on here, right?

70
00:04:19.909 --> 00:04:20.861
When they sign on,

71
00:04:20.861 --> 00:04:25.027
they're actually signing on and they're
hitting some domain control over here.

72
00:04:25.027 --> 00:04:28.310
Which is gonna be the source
of authority at this point.

73
00:04:28.310 --> 00:04:29.803
And so when they actually sign on,

74
00:04:29.803 --> 00:04:32.225
they check against that
particular directory server.

75
00:04:32.225 --> 00:04:36.051
The directory server says, yes,
I've got credentials for you and yes,

76
00:04:36.051 --> 00:04:38.037
you've presented valid a username.

77
00:04:38.037 --> 00:04:40.516
Then you can get access in,
and password, of course.

78
00:04:40.516 --> 00:04:43.790
You can get access into this and
that's perfectly fine.

79
00:04:43.790 --> 00:04:45.750
But it doesn't give us any control or

80
00:04:45.750 --> 00:04:49.490
access over here on the right-hand side,
okay?

81
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:53.390
Now, over here on the right-hand
side though, this is gonna be

82
00:04:53.390 --> 00:04:58.220
our Office 365 that we've actually
create in terms of our tenancy instead.

83
00:04:58.220 --> 00:05:04.280
So currently, without synchronization,
we would actually present another sign on.

84
00:05:04.280 --> 00:05:08.930
So even for an individual user right here,
it essentially ends up with two

85
00:05:08.930 --> 00:05:13.670
different accounts, and identities and
everything else that you have.

86
00:05:13.670 --> 00:05:15.860
So over here,
he would also have his own account,

87
00:05:15.860 --> 00:05:19.991
he would have his own email and
Office 365 unit.

88
00:05:19.991 --> 00:05:24.440
But he also presents his own credentials
against another authority inside of

89
00:05:24.440 --> 00:05:26.362
Azure Active Directory, okay?

90
00:05:26.362 --> 00:05:30.520
So at that point that's
essentially what goes on.

91
00:05:30.520 --> 00:05:31.792
Now, can you run it like that?

92
00:05:31.792 --> 00:05:35.120
Sure, you can actually do that.

93
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:38.253
Now, is that the easiest way?

94
00:05:38.253 --> 00:05:42.412
It's easier, don't get me wrong,
it's easier for you and me,

95
00:05:42.412 --> 00:05:45.370
administratively, to just tell the engine.

96
00:05:45.370 --> 00:05:48.700
So Zach, you're just gonna keep
track of two accounts, okay?

97
00:05:48.700 --> 00:05:51.980
That's all Zach has to do,
is keep track of two accounts.

98
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:53.930
I go, anybody can do that, okay?

99
00:05:53.930 --> 00:05:55.690
Now I go to Zach, and Zach might say,

100
00:05:55.690 --> 00:05:58.530
what do you mean I have to
keep track of two accounts?

101
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:02.431
Now we're a little bit more
in that fuzzy area, right?

102
00:06:02.431 --> 00:06:06.268
So in that sense, it may be a little
bit harder on the end user to do

103
00:06:06.268 --> 00:06:10.920
something like this, but it can be done,
if you just want to do that.

104
00:06:10.920 --> 00:06:14.680
But the problem is,
when Zach has an issue.

105
00:06:14.680 --> 00:06:18.954
Let's say Zach says, Ronnie,
I forgot the password.

106
00:06:18.954 --> 00:06:21.766
Well, what did he forget the password to?

107
00:06:21.766 --> 00:06:23.583
You know, my password.

108
00:06:23.583 --> 00:06:26.856
Well, which account are you talking about?

109
00:06:26.856 --> 00:06:28.630
The one where I check email.

110
00:06:28.630 --> 00:06:31.123
Well, which one is that,
which account are you using?

111
00:06:31.123 --> 00:06:33.480
I don't know, it was one of them.

112
00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:35.970
Well now we're starting to have issues,
okay?

113
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:40.347
So that's where it seems like
it's logical that we can do this.

114
00:06:40.347 --> 00:06:43.440
And you can pretty much name
them identically if you want to.

115
00:06:43.440 --> 00:06:46.650
But at the same time,
this is where it gets a little bit tricky.

116
00:06:46.650 --> 00:06:49.534
What if I did that, what if I was
smart enough to say, all right,

117
00:06:49.534 --> 00:06:53.504
Zach's account is the same
exact over here as up here?

118
00:06:53.504 --> 00:06:57.240
So now the Office 365 username and

119
00:06:57.240 --> 00:07:02.650
password exactly the same as the one that
he has over here on his on-premises,

120
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:07.140
when he signs in to work on his
workstation and he happily works away.

121
00:07:07.140 --> 00:07:12.380
Well, so let's say I change it over here,
and I forgot to change it over here.

122
00:07:12.380 --> 00:07:16.460
Now Zach comes into work, he sits
down at his workstation, and he still

123
00:07:16.460 --> 00:07:21.230
can't sign in, even though I changed
it over here on the right-hand side.

124
00:07:21.230 --> 00:07:23.440
>> Because I'm a dinny [LAUGH].

125
00:07:23.440 --> 00:07:26.570
>> [LAUGH] Okay,
well that's one way to look at it.

126
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:30.730
No, what I'm saying is, you can see where
the administrative effort gets a little

127
00:07:30.730 --> 00:07:34.900
bit more challenging when you start
to think about it in that way, right?

128
00:07:34.900 --> 00:07:37.220
So can it be done?

129
00:07:37.220 --> 00:07:43.560
Yeah, you kind of squint at it, and you
kind of go, I'm bracing myself for this.

130
00:07:43.560 --> 00:07:47.260
Now, just with Zach's account,
that's enough to be a challenge for me,

131
00:07:47.260 --> 00:07:48.506
one because it's Zach.

132
00:07:48.506 --> 00:07:51.011
I'm joking,
I don't mean to pick on Zach in any way.

133
00:07:51.011 --> 00:07:55.037
But yeah, one because it might be Zach,
but no, that's not really true.

134
00:07:55.037 --> 00:07:56.431
It's when you start to scale.

135
00:07:56.431 --> 00:07:59.039
Remember when we've talked about this
in our series a little bit more, right?

136
00:07:59.039 --> 00:08:02.254
The idea of scaling up and
scaling out, okay.

137
00:08:02.254 --> 00:08:07.762
Well, now when we move up to 400 users or
thousands users, and let's just

138
00:08:07.762 --> 00:08:14.110
say it's 15% of them that's doing this
it now becomes much more of a challenge.

139
00:08:14.110 --> 00:08:17.104
So every time Zach or somebody else, or

140
00:08:17.104 --> 00:08:21.838
the 15% of the 400 that come in,
so what is that, 60?

141
00:08:21.838 --> 00:08:26.285
Okay, 60 that end up coming in our,
yeah 60, Joe was right.

142
00:08:26.285 --> 00:08:28.827
>> [LAUGH]
>> So 60 that come in, okay,

143
00:08:28.827 --> 00:08:29.970
what if I do that?

144
00:08:29.970 --> 00:08:34.423
Well, that means that I have to
actually change the account over

145
00:08:34.423 --> 00:08:37.313
here inside of my Office 365 tenancy.

146
00:08:37.313 --> 00:08:41.459
And then I have to go into Active
Directory over here and change it too.

147
00:08:41.459 --> 00:08:45.899
So for everyone single one user I
have to change it at least twice for

148
00:08:45.899 --> 00:08:48.532
a password, if that's what happens.

149
00:08:48.532 --> 00:08:49.346
>> Mm-hm.

150
00:08:49.346 --> 00:08:52.459
>> So now my administrative effort,
even though in my mind it says,

151
00:08:52.459 --> 00:08:54.680
this how it's gonna be,
it's gonna be easy.

152
00:08:54.680 --> 00:08:55.940
I'm not gonna worry about Zach,

153
00:08:55.940 --> 00:08:58.960
Zach's the only one who has to
worry about the two accounts here.

154
00:08:58.960 --> 00:09:01.527
I don't, I just tell Zach that
that's what's gonna happen.

155
00:09:01.527 --> 00:09:06.170
Well now my administrative effort had
just increased, pretty much, okay.

156
00:09:06.170 --> 00:09:10.734
So when we start to talk about
synchronization, what we're really

157
00:09:10.734 --> 00:09:15.710
talking about is how can this coexist
a little bit easier instead, okay.

158
00:09:15.710 --> 00:09:19.990
So the goal here is down here at
the bottom that you see, okay.

159
00:09:19.990 --> 00:09:23.601
Users have a single identity
to access both, okay.

160
00:09:23.601 --> 00:09:28.115
Users have a single identity
which single resources inside of

161
00:09:28.115 --> 00:09:31.869
your active directory
are also synchronized too.

162
00:09:31.869 --> 00:09:36.655
Now what that can actually mean,
again this is kinda based on everything

163
00:09:36.655 --> 00:09:40.978
else that goes on, but
there comes in this point in time, right?

164
00:09:40.978 --> 00:09:46.740
Where what we really want is what we
call a single source of authority, okay.

165
00:09:46.740 --> 00:09:51.565
So when we start this idea of Active
Directory Synchronization, we're pretty

166
00:09:51.565 --> 00:09:56.542
much saying, hey, let's synchronize
these two Active Directories together.

167
00:09:56.542 --> 00:10:00.266
And then e'll have a single
source of authority at the very

168
00:10:00.266 --> 00:10:04.680
beginning when we start to do this,
especially with Office 365.

169
00:10:04.680 --> 00:10:08.557
Well, the first time, okay,
that everything is finally synchronized up

170
00:10:08.557 --> 00:10:12.756
the source of authority is over here,
inside of the Office 365 Cloud, okay.

171
00:10:12.756 --> 00:10:15.842
But then, once it's done and complete,

172
00:10:15.842 --> 00:10:21.397
that source of authority will migrate
back over to our on premises if I can,

173
00:10:21.397 --> 00:10:28.160
I didn't exactly space this very well,
over here on my on premises instead, okay?

174
00:10:28.160 --> 00:10:31.708
And this now actually means that
the synchronization will not be two ways.

175
00:10:31.708 --> 00:10:35.264
And this is actually a wrong arrow,
I probably should have actually have a one

176
00:10:35.264 --> 00:10:38.540
way synchronization is what
ends up happening here, okay.

177
00:10:38.540 --> 00:10:44.508
So the synchronization will always happen
in this one direction instead, okay.

178
00:10:44.508 --> 00:10:47.051
So everything that I
make a modification and

179
00:10:47.051 --> 00:10:51.270
change over here it will also
sync up over here too, okay.

180
00:10:51.270 --> 00:10:54.442
So it's not gonna be two way where
if I make a change over here,

181
00:10:54.442 --> 00:10:57.432
it syncs down over here,
it's just not gonna be that way.

182
00:10:57.432 --> 00:11:01.679
But ultimately in the end, right, once
everything we start that synchronization

183
00:11:01.679 --> 00:11:05.457
I'm gonna show you that it's not
exactly the most difficult thing to do.

184
00:11:05.457 --> 00:11:08.903
But you do have them take some
considerations in mind when you do

185
00:11:08.903 --> 00:11:09.563
so, okay.

186
00:11:09.563 --> 00:11:12.634
But that's essentially what
is gonna happen, okay.

187
00:11:12.634 --> 00:11:16.270
So the very initial state,
right, remember it is over

188
00:11:16.270 --> 00:11:21.510
here at the beginning with the very
first initial synchronization.

189
00:11:21.510 --> 00:11:26.344
Once it's done, now when you actually
get synchronized here, okay.

190
00:11:26.344 --> 00:11:29.064
And the user logs on
with their Office 365,

191
00:11:29.064 --> 00:11:33.390
the Azure Active Directory synchronization
though it will check against

192
00:11:33.390 --> 00:11:37.810
the sources authority which will
be over here on your own domain.

193
00:11:37.810 --> 00:11:43.044
If you're keeping both the on-premises
which is your network over here,

194
00:11:43.044 --> 00:11:45.131
and of course Office 365.

195
00:11:45.131 --> 00:11:49.129
Now if you're saying, I'm migrating
completely over then at some point in

196
00:11:49.129 --> 00:11:52.814
the future after you make sure
everything is working that you want to,

197
00:11:52.814 --> 00:11:56.160
you kind of don't have to
worry about this one so much.

198
00:11:56.160 --> 00:11:59.884
But if you really need that hybrid
environment where you still have

199
00:11:59.884 --> 00:12:04.222
Exchange working and Skype working,
and everything else working, right?

200
00:12:04.222 --> 00:12:08.935
And then you're actually saying I wanna
move this to online or Exchange online and

201
00:12:08.935 --> 00:12:10.660
everything over here.

202
00:12:10.660 --> 00:12:14.042
Well, we need the synchronization
process to be up and

203
00:12:14.042 --> 00:12:18.094
working so that the end user has
the seam as close as we can, okay.

204
00:12:18.094 --> 00:12:21.670
The seamless environment
that we really want, okay?

205
00:12:21.670 --> 00:12:26.564
So that's a big part of what we're
actually trying to do and what we actually

206
00:12:26.564 --> 00:12:31.845
need to think about in terms of planning
and synchronization as it goes on, okay.

207
00:12:31.845 --> 00:12:37.039
So once we have that in our mind and

00:23:03.086 --> 00:23:08.580
.NET Framework 4.5,
other name resolutions here.

387
00:23:08.580 --> 00:23:11.310
If you're using Active Directory
Federation Services you'll need

388
00:23:11.310 --> 00:23:12.330
a certificate.

389
00:23:12.330 --> 00:23:13.980
That's a good one to remember,

390
00:23:13.980 --> 00:23:18.220
you can't run Federation Services
without the SSL certificate as well.

391
00:23:18.220 --> 00:23:21.550
You can't do it without having
all of your DNS records

392
00:23:21.550 --> 00:23:22.840
set up the way that you need to.

393
00:23:22.840 --> 00:23:24.580
And you also normally are gonna need,

394
00:23:24.580 --> 00:23:29.130
if you're using Federation Services,
a public IP address.

395
00:23:29.130 --> 00:23:31.160
That's gonna be a kicker as well.

396
00:23:31.160 --> 00:23:35.660
With the SQL Server,
that's normally used as your AD Connect.

397
00:23:35.660 --> 00:23:40.180
We'll normally install the version of SQL
Express Is essentially what you'll end up

398
00:23:40.180 --> 00:23:45.260
seeing but
if you have over 100,000 objects,

399
00:23:45.260 --> 00:23:51.150
it's going to recommend that you do
a full install of SQL Server itself.

400
00:23:51.150 --> 00:23:57.000
So you have above 100,000 objects, then
you have to go to the full version here.

401
00:23:57.000 --> 00:24:01.501
The other things of course, notice that
you'll need two accounts to make this work

402
00:24:01.501 --> 00:24:04.803
The global administrator
account inside of Office 365.

403
00:24:04.803 --> 00:24:11.304
And then, also, okay, you'll need
the Enterprise Administrator Account for

404
00:24:11.304 --> 00:24:15.905
Active Directory Two,
if you're gonna do this.

405
00:24:15.905 --> 00:24:19.230
Or the synchronization, there's also
a group that needs to be there,

406
00:24:19.230 --> 00:24:22.360
which is gonna be the AD Sync Admins.

407
00:24:22.360 --> 00:24:25.520
That's a group that we created
in a previous episode.

408
00:24:25.520 --> 00:24:26.580
We added in a couple of counts.

00:24:26.580 --> 00:24:29.470
I believe I added in Zach's
account to that, as well.

410
00:24:29.470 --> 00:24:29.990
>> Thank you [LAUGH].

00:24:29.990 --> 00:24:35.910
>> That needs to be there, if these things
are gonna end up working out for us, too.

412
00:24:35.910 --> 00:24:39.300
Connection, of course,
that means networking resolution.

413
00:24:39.300 --> 00:24:41.320
Stuff that you can follow on your own.

414
00:24:41.320 --> 00:24:42.590
I don't want to point all that out.

415
00:24:42.590 --> 00:24:47.500
Powershell, enabling for, of course,
Azure AD connect, if you're going to

416
00:24:47.500 --> 00:24:51.850
do TLS here over your federation, you

417
00:24:51.850 --> 00:24:56.330
But that's pretty much kinda the basic
prerequisites, right, that we also have,

418
00:24:56.330 --> 00:25:02.290
not only the best practices, but also just
that idea of those prerequisites, okay.

419
00:25:02.290 --> 00:25:05.880
So, Ronnie, okay, you've gone over
that in multiple episodes and

420
00:25:05.880 --> 00:25:09.060
you're doing it again, so
what's the whole point here?

421
00:25:09.060 --> 00:25:11.530
The whole point is everything
needs to be planned out, and

00:25:11.530 --> 00:25:14.550
you need to understand those facts

423
00:25:14.550 --> 00:25:15.830
>> It's all about preparation isn't it,

424
00:25:15.830 --> 00:25:17.470
>> It is really all about preparation.

425
00:25:17.470 --> 00:25:20.550
So, what about the cloud side, okay?

What is there really that needs

00:25:23.540 --> 00:25:27.750
Well, the key thing right if you're

428
00:25:27.750 --> 00:25:30.680
Is have your Azure AD Subscription.

00:25:31.700 --> 00:25:34.920
Whatever it is that you need
to actually think about.

00:25:34.920 --> 00:25:35.520
Count it up here.

431
00:25:35.520 --> 00:25:37.980
Do yo think that your particular
subscription is going to go over

00:25:37.980 --> 00:25:38.484
that limit.
