00:25:38.484 --> 00:25:40.470
That 300,000 limit.

434
00:25:40.470 --> 00:25:42.080
Be ready to call Microsoft for

435
00:25:42.080 --> 00:25:45.440
additional help to expand
out the object limit, there.

436
00:25:45.440 --> 00:25:46.190
Okay?

437
00:25:46.190 --> 00:25:51.970
Be ready to change your product
subscription, okay, if you need to.

438
00:25:51.970 --> 00:25:54.300
So, that doesn't sound exactly difficult.

439
00:25:54.300 --> 00:25:57.200
But it is easy things that we'll miss
on the exam if we don't think about

00:25:57.200 --> 00:25:58.370
it, as well.

The other thing, of course,
is we need to make sure

that the synchronization will actually

443
00:26:05.990 --> 00:26:09.820
The Azure AD connect tool allows us
to be able to run the synchronization

00:26:09.820 --> 00:26:11.540
to get everything ready to go.

445
00:26:11.540 --> 00:26:14.220
But on the active directory side,

446
00:26:14.220 --> 00:26:18.820
on Azure's active directory side,
we need to enable it, okay?

447
00:26:18.820 --> 00:26:23.210
And the enabling of this synchronization
that we're talking about here,

448
00:26:23.210 --> 00:26:24.080
has to be done.

449
00:26:24.080 --> 00:26:24.970
It doesn't have to be done.

450
00:26:24.970 --> 00:26:28.820
But it is going to be done at least
on our end here through PowerShell.

451
00:26:28.820 --> 00:26:29.630
That's what we're gonna have.

452
00:26:32.010 --> 00:26:37.250
So, I'm going to log in as our domain
admin as well as our global administrator.

453
00:26:37.250 --> 00:26:42.060
Then we're going to bring
up the PowerShell and

454
00:26:42.060 --> 00:26:47.621
connect into azureAD, so connect

00:26:47.621 --> 00:26:52.280
msolservice.

456
00:26:52.280 --> 00:26:55.180
Before I do that let me create
my variable for my credentials.

457
00:26:55.180 --> 00:26:56.520
I always forget this part.

458
00:27:03.989 --> 00:27:08.914
And remember, also in this, even though
I probably done it just about in

459
00:27:08.914 --> 00:27:14.180
every other episode, make sure you use
the UPN type of name and not the slash.

460
00:27:15.260 --> 00:27:19.518
ITProTVdemo slash name instead,
itprotvdemo.com,

461
00:27:19.518 --> 00:27:25.322
I got to make sure I spell that correctly,
since it's so tiny, there we go.

462
00:27:25.322 --> 00:27:28.120
And then, the super secret password.

463
00:27:37.754 --> 00:27:41.460
So, as long as I typed that in right,
I'm pretty much okay here.

464
00:27:42.500 --> 00:27:47.930
We do the connect- msllService and
do verbose here.

465
00:27:47.930 --> 00:27:49.940
You don't have to do the verbose.

466
00:27:49.940 --> 00:27:51.480
Then the credentials.

467
00:27:55.240 --> 00:27:56.531
Supply it with a variable here.

468
00:27:56.531 --> 00:27:57.887
Now, if it gives me red letters,

469
00:27:57.887 --> 00:28:00.640
it means I probably fat-fingered
the actual password.

470
00:28:00.640 --> 00:28:03.470
But everything is accepted and

471
00:28:03.470 --> 00:28:10.801
And once I'm actually done with this,
okay, if I'm just setting up and

00:28:10.801 --> 00:28:16.570
making sure that the Azure
side is actually connected and

473
00:28:16.570 --> 00:28:24.640
doing what we want to this is were we
need the set-msoldirsyncEnabled, okay?

474
00:28:25.690 --> 00:28:32.320
So, be careful here, make sure you see
that dirsyncEnabled then do a dash.

475
00:28:34.325 --> 00:28:40.504
EnabledirSync, then $true.

476
00:28:40.504 --> 00:28:44.850
Now, notice that we have a true and
we have a false here.

477
00:28:44.850 --> 00:28:52.130
So, set MsoldirSyncEnabled,
then the option here the -EnabledirSync.

478
00:28:52.130 --> 00:28:54.790
So, kind of neat, right?

479
00:28:54.790 --> 00:28:58.030
So, you're either enabling it,
or you are disabling it.

480
00:28:58.030 --> 00:29:02.460
One of the things I can tell you right
now, as if all of a sudden you run

481
00:29:02.460 --> 00:29:04.450
through, and you get everything
setup the way that you want to,

482
00:29:04.450 --> 00:29:08.010
and then you realize something,

483
00:29:08.010 --> 00:29:13.360
You have to come in here and
at least change that defaults first before

484
00:29:13.360 --> 00:29:18.270
you start uninstalling everything else
that you want to be able to uninstall.

485
00:29:18.270 --> 00:29:20.760
If you don't, it will keep it as true, and

486
00:29:20.760 --> 00:29:24.490
it will expect to find
everything still synchronized.

487
00:29:24.490 --> 00:29:28.410
So, that can end up giving you a lot of
errors, and cause a lot of heartache.

488
00:29:28.410 --> 00:29:30.000
If you're not careful.

489
00:29:30.000 --> 00:29:34.100
So, make sure that you understand this is
probably the first that you'll have to do

490
00:29:34.100 --> 00:29:37.580
as to stop the synchronization
that happening on both ends,

491
00:29:37.580 --> 00:29:39.260
just to make sure that is going on.

492
00:29:40.840 --> 00:29:44.360
Here it is, it says confirm here,
I was like typing the Y,

493
00:29:44.360 --> 00:29:50.090
even the default than others putting in
there is took a D-A-Y, which is for yes.

494
00:29:50.090 --> 00:29:55.240
And now on that side,
everything is pretty much good here, okay?

495
00:29:55.240 --> 00:30:00.800
So, on the Office 365 side, this should
now be ready for the synchronization

496
00:30:00.800 --> 00:30:05.420
to happen, if I've prepared everything on
my on premises active directory in the way

497
00:30:05.420 --> 00:30:10.440
that it needs to be that should
also be ready to go as well, okay?

498
00:30:10.440 --> 00:30:15.200
So, now that we've got both of those

499
00:30:15.200 --> 00:30:19.170

500
00:30:19.170 --> 00:30:23.180
And show you some of the options that
we may have to go through and select.

501
00:30:23.180 --> 00:30:25.860
And we are actually gonna make sure
that everything is set up the way that

502
00:30:25.860 --> 00:30:29.530
it needs to be as we continue
to move on through, and

503
00:30:29.530 --> 00:30:32.600
understand the synchronization
process that we have in place.

504
00:30:32.600 --> 00:30:36.240
But, Zach, that's gonna actually be for
another episode at this point.

505
00:30:36.240 --> 00:30:38.210
But at least now, we've got a good review.

506
00:30:38.210 --> 00:30:42.410
We've now actually set it up,
made sure that both sides are ready to go.

507
00:30:42.410 --> 00:30:44.920
And that's what we actually
have to make sure of, and

508
00:30:44.920 --> 00:30:48.330
then we'll be ready to run the tool,
probably in the next episode.

509
00:30:48.330 --> 00:30:51.620
>> Set up Azure AD connect tool part one,
there will be a part two.

510
00:30:51.620 --> 00:30:54.900
Make sure you see everything
in the series of Office 365,

511
00:30:54.900 --> 00:30:56.620
and everything in our course library.

512
00:30:56.620 --> 00:31:00.080
Hundreds of videos,
all designed to help you go further.

513
00:31:00.080 --> 00:31:02.960
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,

514
00:31:02.960 --> 00:31:04.590
Thanks for watching, I'm Zack Memos.

00:31:04.590 --> 00:31:05.330
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

516
00:31:05.330 --> 00:31:07.196

00:31:07.196 --> 00:31:13.181
[MUSIC]

00:31:13.181 --> 00:31:20.379
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show the connection steps and discuss the setup for the Azure AD Connect Tool to work.  They show the synchronization and then show some of the different considerations after the AD Connect Tool is in place and ready to go
episodes.title: Set Up Azure AD Connect Tool Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.380 --> 00:00:01.330
Welcome to ITProTV.

3

Coming at you live from San Francisco,

[CROSSTALK] [SOUND]

So everything that we've

Making sure that we understand
the requirements that are actually

And some of the other utilities on

And lab environment,

it means I'm also running that Azure

Now, is that a bad thing?

Not necessarily in a lab environment.

But in a real production environment,
the goal and

idea is not to have it tied

So the best practice at that point

34

The only other requirement that

35

that you give the access to the domain

37
00:01:51.840 --> 00:01:54.500
Okay, so as long as those two

00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:58.830
Because we want that really to become the
server, that standalone, that allows for

39
00:01:58.830 --> 00:02:02.770
the synchronization and the management of
it, to not necessarily be tied to that

40
00:02:02.770 --> 00:02:06.580
domain controller, so that
the synchronization can happen fully and

41
00:02:06.580 --> 00:02:10.900
freely without having to worry of whether
or not it's bogging down your domain

42
00:02:10.900 --> 00:02:14.210
controller, especially if things start

43
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:15.960
So in a production environment,

44
00:02:15.960 --> 00:02:20.900
do not put it on the same machine
as your domain controller..

45
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:24.647
In a lab environment,
we're gonna do it just for the ability

46
00:02:24.647 --> 00:02:29.290
to conserve resources on my machine so
that I can run what we need to, okay?

47
00:02:29.290 --> 00:02:30.920
So that's where it's actually running.

48
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:34.960
So I just want to make sure I actually set
it up before somebody goes well you're

49
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:38.860
running on them in controller, I should
too in my Active Directory environment.

50
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:42.529
No, you shouldn't, okay so let's just
make that perfectly clear at this point.

51
00:02:42.529 --> 00:02:44.410
>> Do as I say, not as I do.

52
00:02:44.410 --> 00:02:47.930
>> Right, that's gonna be true

53
00:02:47.930 --> 00:02:50.590
especially when you have

54
00:02:50.590 --> 00:02:54.410
So, in that sense,
just kind of remember that, okay,

55
00:02:54.410 --> 00:02:57.220
because that's the most
realistic situation.

56
00:02:57.220 --> 00:03:00.380
If your environment is already
running Active Directory and if you've

57
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:04.430
got things going on, you'll probably see,
and the recommended practice for as long

58
00:03:04.430 --> 00:03:08.570
as I know is let the domain controller

59
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:11.130
Don't turn it into a multi-purpose server.

60
00:03:11.130 --> 00:03:12.970
Don't do all that other stuff on it.

61
00:03:12.970 --> 00:03:14.810
Let it be what it's designed to be.

62
00:03:14.810 --> 00:03:18.200
And then build another machine to do

63
00:03:18.200 --> 00:03:20.045
And that's normally the real environment,

64
00:03:20.045 --> 00:03:22.400
that production environment
that we want to do.

65
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:24.610
Now when you install it,
you download the tool.

66
00:03:24.610 --> 00:03:28.350
And we've gone over that several

67
00:03:28.350 --> 00:03:33.210
And once you get all those prerequisites

00:03:33.210 --> 00:03:36.450
process, and everything should be up and

69
00:03:36.450 --> 00:03:41.460
And your result should pretty much look
like what I have on my screen, too, okay?

70
00:03:41.460 --> 00:03:44.049
So I'm running this on a 2016 Server.

71
00:03:44.049 --> 00:03:49.356
I am now logged in as Cherokee and

ends up leaving for us a nice

00:03:54.054 --> 00:03:57.198
which is the Azure AD Connect tool, okay?

74
00:03:57.198 --> 00:04:01.294
Now if you leave it running long enough

75
00:04:01.294 --> 00:04:04.750
through and trying to examine it,
and after a while it will start

76
00:04:04.750 --> 00:04:09.200
building other information if you've
already got things set up for you.

77
00:04:09.200 --> 00:04:11.855
Let me show you an example

78
00:04:11.855 --> 00:04:15.335
by launching the Active Directory Users
and Computers here.

79
00:04:15.335 --> 00:04:20.570
So inside of Active Directory Users and
Computers, if I go down to Users,

80
00:04:22.140 --> 00:04:27.010
you will see here is the ADSyncAdmins

81
00:04:27.010 --> 00:04:31.142
group that I created earlier
in one of the episodes I did.

82
00:04:31.142 --> 00:04:35.370
And Inside that are the members here,
which is Cherokee and Zach.

83
00:04:35.370 --> 00:04:37.230
So these were the ones that we created,

84
00:04:37.230 --> 00:04:40.170
cuz we knew that we're gonna be
doing the directory synchronization.

85
00:04:40.170 --> 00:04:43.250
I wanna have at least two accounts
that would kinda help me out.

86
00:04:43.250 --> 00:04:46.870
But this one though, okay,
this particular account right here,

87
00:04:46.870 --> 00:04:49.330
Zach, is not one that I created.

88
00:04:49.330 --> 00:04:52.780
I can even tell you if I created this,

89
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:55.101
even by random that I
would come up with this.

90
00:04:55.101 --> 00:04:58.949
Well this is actually generated
as Azure Active Directory and

of the on premises Active Directory.

314
00:18:38.870 --> 00:18:42.320
Earlier though, during our series
of shows, I made an account for

315
00:18:42.320 --> 00:18:45.040
you where, inside of Office 365.

316
00:18:45.040 --> 00:18:50.070
So this is saying,
I'll take a look at both of those, okay.

317
00:18:50.070 --> 00:18:55.460
And whatever matches up, I'll say hey,
that account looks like on premises,

318
00:18:55.460 --> 00:18:58.920
looks like it matches up
to the Office 365 account.

319
00:18:58.920 --> 00:19:03.720
So I'll go ahead and synchronize
based off of that information, too.

320
00:19:03.720 --> 00:19:07.690
Secondly, it will configure
password synchronization.

321
00:19:07.690 --> 00:19:10.190
And notice the key here, Zach.

322
00:19:10.190 --> 00:19:13.050
Look at the directionality
of that second step.

323
00:19:14.070 --> 00:19:17.666
Configure password synchronization,

324
00:19:17.666 --> 00:19:24.140
notice the directionality,
on-premises to Azure AD by default.

325
00:19:24.140 --> 00:19:30.800
That is key, the default configuration
here is on-premises to Azure AD.

326
00:19:31.900 --> 00:19:34.426
If we say then in Office 365, I go, Zach,

327
00:19:34.426 --> 00:19:37.288
I'm gonna change your
password in Office 365.

328
00:19:37.288 --> 00:19:39.760
And I click on reset the password.

329
00:19:39.760 --> 00:19:42.752
I type it in,
I tell it to save the changes.

330
00:19:42.752 --> 00:19:45.500
And I come back, and
it's gonna tell me password didn't save.

331
00:19:46.630 --> 00:19:48.140
Why didn't it save?

332
00:19:48.140 --> 00:19:51.310
Because it's actually
expecting synchronization.

333
00:19:51.310 --> 00:19:55.911
And according to this, the source of
authority is from the on premises,

334
00:19:55.911 --> 00:19:58.030
where the source of authority is.

335
00:19:58.030 --> 00:20:02.177
And it actually filters up to Azure AD.

336
00:20:02.177 --> 00:20:04.760
>> It sounds like that might be something
very important on the exam too.

337
00:20:04.760 --> 00:20:06.064
>> It could be, yeah.

338
00:20:06.064 --> 00:20:07.510
>> It could be!
>> There you go, yeah.

339
00:20:07.510 --> 00:20:10.190
So just kind of realize
that this is a part of it.

340
00:20:10.190 --> 00:20:13.220
And then of course,
the initial synchronization.

341
00:20:13.220 --> 00:20:16.450
Now this initial synchronization
means all the stuff that

342
00:20:16.450 --> 00:20:20.970
it thinks it can go ahead and match up and
do, it's gonna start the synchronization.

343
00:20:20.970 --> 00:20:23.400
And then this is kinda the key here.

344
00:20:23.400 --> 00:20:27.170
Remember in a previous episode,
actually I think in the one right before.

345
00:20:27.170 --> 00:20:32.560
I said there's gonna be issues if we just
go, all right, I don't want this anymore.

346
00:20:32.560 --> 00:20:35.930
I'm just gonna go ahead and
uninstall Office 365.

347
00:20:35.930 --> 00:20:42.620
This one is the scary one,
synchronize all attributes, okay?

348
00:20:42.620 --> 00:20:44.200
When you start doing that, you're saying,

349
00:20:44.200 --> 00:20:49.220
hey, we're actually making sure that
everything that's up here in Office 365

350
00:20:49.220 --> 00:20:54.240
matches what is in the on-premises
Active Directory, as well.

351
00:20:54.240 --> 00:20:58.360
So if it begins to synchronize
every single attribute,

352
00:20:58.360 --> 00:21:01.360
it's saying I should find
a match to it somewhere.

353
00:21:01.360 --> 00:21:05.620
If you go, I'm not gonna give you that
ability to find the match, someone's going

354
00:21:05.620 --> 00:21:09.280
to actually raise an alarm and go, yeah,
I don't think I'm letting you do that.

355
00:21:09.280 --> 00:21:12.128
Because if you do that,
I'm gonna break the synchronization here.

356
00:21:12.128 --> 00:21:14.100
And that's not going to work.

357
00:21:14.100 --> 00:21:19.010
So you might have to kind of
first of all then, stop or

358
00:21:19.010 --> 00:21:21.770
disable that synchronization, okay?

359
00:21:21.770 --> 00:21:25.320
And the easiest way is by
using that PowerShell command,

360
00:21:25.320 --> 00:21:28.300
the same one that we used to enable it,
okay?

361
00:21:28.300 --> 00:21:30.730
Which was the,
make sure I'm telling you right here,

362
00:21:30.730 --> 00:21:35.240
the Set-MsolDirSyncEnabled command, okay?

363
00:21:35.240 --> 00:21:39.757
And then, we did -EnableDirSync
with the dollar sign true.

364
00:21:39.757 --> 00:21:42.570
We would set that one
to dollar sign false.

365
00:21:42.570 --> 00:21:45.230
Stop the synchronization first.

366
00:21:45.230 --> 00:21:49.220
And then from that point, once you
ensure that that's all stopped and

367
00:21:49.220 --> 00:21:55.430
that there's nothing synching up, then you
can start to carefully uninstall things,

368
00:21:55.430 --> 00:21:57.686
or delete things that you want to.

369
00:21:57.686 --> 00:22:00.380
You might find out that there is still
some things that you're not gonna be able

370
00:22:00.380 --> 00:22:02.920
to do through the GUI interface anymore.

371
00:22:02.920 --> 00:22:06.500
And that means you'll have
to rely on PowerShell and

372
00:22:06.500 --> 00:22:09.090
some of those remove
dash commands instead.

373
00:22:09.090 --> 00:22:11.610
And that will get you through that too.

374
00:22:11.610 --> 00:22:14.470
So not everything is as easy as,
I'm just gonna check all these and

375
00:22:14.470 --> 00:22:15.610
just delete them out.

376
00:22:15.610 --> 00:22:17.130
It's not gonna work that way.

377
00:22:17.130 --> 00:22:20.480
And I hope that I'll be able to
show you some of this issues and

378
00:22:20.480 --> 00:22:21.760
problems that I'm talking about.

379
00:22:21.760 --> 00:22:23.870
Cuz that's where it gets
a little bit tricky.

380
00:22:23.870 --> 00:22:28.202
Especially, you'll find out something,
Zach, that it might be where you go,

381
00:22:28.202 --> 00:22:32.848
I wanted everybody synched up except for
those ten accounts there.

382
00:22:32.848 --> 00:22:35.050
Well, now that those ten
accounts have synced up,

383
00:22:35.050 --> 00:22:36.190
now you have to get rid of them.

384
00:22:36.190 --> 00:22:39.930
And all of a sudden,
you're fighting every inch of the way

385
00:22:39.930 --> 00:22:42.130
because it's not working
the way that you do.

386
00:22:42.130 --> 00:22:46.555
And the other thing, if you read
on Microsoft's Office 365 site,

387
00:22:46.555 --> 00:22:49.930
is that for troubleshooting,
it says do not ever just

388
00:22:49.930 --> 00:22:54.830
disable the directory synchronization
just for troubleshooting.

389
00:22:54.830 --> 00:22:57.592
So even their own documentation says,

390
00:22:57.592 --> 00:23:01.617
don't just disable and
enable it for troubleshooting.

391
00:23:01.617 --> 00:23:05.957
So now it just says hey, I didn't want
this to happen, and throwing errors.

392
00:23:05.957 --> 00:23:08.640
It's saying, don't turn off
the directory synchronization.

393
00:23:08.640 --> 00:23:11.490
So this is actually saying that this
can kind of mess some things up,

394
00:23:11.490 --> 00:23:12.305
if you're not careful.

395
00:23:12.305 --> 00:23:16.350
So be aware that if you're doing this,
it is a major issue for

396
00:23:16.350 --> 00:23:19.220
you to stop the synchronization process.

397
00:23:19.220 --> 00:23:21.865
Especially in a production environment
where things are constantly changing,

398
00:23:21.865 --> 00:23:24.340
that you may not want that to happen.

399
00:23:24.340 --> 00:23:28.000
So be aware that this is kind
of a key here on some things.

400
00:23:28.000 --> 00:23:31.020
Now, I say that not so
much for the exam, right?

401
00:23:31.020 --> 00:23:35.080
But in real life, when stuff like this
happens, don't just go, Ronnie just said

402
00:23:35.080 --> 00:23:38.400
let me stop the synchronization and
everything should be fine.

403
00:23:38.400 --> 00:23:42.730
Except when everybody on the planet is
trying to connect to your Office 365 and

404
00:23:42.730 --> 00:23:45.560
get stuff done, and
now you've disabled the synchronization,

405
00:23:45.560 --> 00:23:48.690
source of authority is gone,
now you're toast.

406
00:23:48.690 --> 00:23:49.880
So be aware [LAUGH].

407
00:23:49.880 --> 00:23:53.920
So things can actually happen
here that you are not sure of.

408
00:23:53.920 --> 00:23:55.270
So let's take a look, then.

409
00:23:55.270 --> 00:23:59.286
Now once again, my preaching has kind of
gotten to the extreme here, at this point.

410
00:23:59.286 --> 00:23:59.836
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

411
00:23:59.836 --> 00:24:04.335
look at the two options that we have right
down here at the bottom of the scream.

412
00:24:04.335 --> 00:24:05.509
Screen, scream?

413
00:24:05.509 --> 00:24:06.177
>> Scream.

414
00:24:06.177 --> 00:24:09.279
>> Scream, it is Halloween,
at least for our sake.

415
00:24:09.279 --> 00:24:12.050
>> Scream! [LAUGH] >> On the bottom
of the screen here, okay.

416
00:24:12.050 --> 00:24:13.660
Notice one says, use express settings.

417
00:24:13.660 --> 00:24:15.245
The other one says Customize.

418
00:24:15.245 --> 00:24:17.840
We've just told you what
the express settings do.

419
00:24:17.840 --> 00:24:20.056
And the idea behind
the express settings is simple.

420
00:24:20.056 --> 00:24:24.489
One domain, one forest, done, okay?

421
00:24:24.489 --> 00:24:26.200
And that's all you have to do.

422
00:24:26.200 --> 00:24:29.832
But remember, if there's any
other additional complexity,

423
00:24:29.832 --> 00:24:33.370
you're using multi-factor authentication.

424
00:24:33.370 --> 00:24:36.160
You decide in the future that
you're probably gonna end up using

425
00:24:36.160 --> 00:24:38.140
single sign-on in the future.

426
00:24:38.140 --> 00:24:40.300
You end up doing anything
else where you go,

427
00:24:40.300 --> 00:24:43.060
I'm gonna possibly have another forest.

428
00:24:43.060 --> 00:24:45.765
That may be something
else I need to add in.

429
00:24:45.765 --> 00:24:49.130
Then using the express heading,
even though you can do that now,

430
00:24:49.130 --> 00:24:52.210
it's probably better if you actually
think about planning and setting it up.

431
00:24:52.210 --> 00:24:56.450
And if you have to, that means you're
gonna select the Customize instead.

432
00:24:56.450 --> 00:24:59.970
Well, even though I only have a single
forest, I want us to walk through

433
00:24:59.970 --> 00:25:04.570
these options that we see over here on
the left hand side, to help us out and

434
00:25:04.570 --> 00:25:08.300
to make sure that we understand what
it is that we're actually seeing.

435
00:25:08.300 --> 00:25:12.050
And so each of these options,
where we see single user sign-in,

436
00:25:12.050 --> 00:25:15.200
and we'll talk about some of these
different options that are available.

437
00:25:15.200 --> 00:25:17.630
Connecting, and
then the synchronization, and

438
00:25:17.630 --> 00:25:20.930
all these filtering options,
we still need to actually go through and

439
00:25:20.930 --> 00:25:23.540
make sure that we understand
what's happening here, okay?

440
00:25:23.540 --> 00:25:26.330
Now, Zach,
there's a lot of information here.

441
00:25:26.330 --> 00:25:30.780
And I realize I only have two minutes
left, really, when it comes down to it.

442
00:25:30.780 --> 00:25:33.730
So Zach, it looks like it's better
if we actually take this and

443
00:25:33.730 --> 00:25:35.150
go into another part.

444
00:25:35.150 --> 00:25:37.406
>> Hey, that's okay with me,
because you've been doing an awesome job.

445
00:25:37.406 --> 00:25:41.530
And so this has been
Set Up Azure AD Connect Tool, Part Two.

446
00:25:41.530 --> 00:25:42.940
There will be Part Three.

447
00:25:42.940 --> 00:25:45.896
See all of those, and
see everything in the Office 365 series.

448
00:25:45.896 --> 00:25:47.860
Ronnie's an amazing teacher.

449
00:25:47.860 --> 00:25:50.720
And also in our course library,
there's hundreds of other videos.

450
00:25:50.720 --> 00:25:53.870
And they're all designed
to help you go further.

451
00:25:53.870 --> 00:25:55.764
And tell someone you know about ITProTV.

452
00:25:55.764 --> 00:25:56.764
They'll be glad you did.

453
00:25:56.764 --> 00:25:58.350
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

454
00:25:58.350 --> 00:25:59.140
>> And, I'm Ronnie Wong.

455
00:25:59.140 --> 00:25:59.696
>> And we will see you soon.

456
00:25:59.696 --> 00:26:06.799
[MUSIC]

457
00:26:06.799 --> 00:26:09.470
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show the connection steps and discuss the setup for the Azure AD Connect Tool to work.  They show the synchronization and then show some of the different considerations after the AD Connect Tool is in place and ready to go
episodes.title: Set Up Azure AD Connect Tool Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.340
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.340 --> 00:00:06.491
I'm your host, Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.491 --> 00:00:08.323
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.323 --> 00:00:11.921
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.921 --> 00:00:14.041
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITPro.TV,

6
00:00:14.041 --> 00:00:16.370
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.370 --> 00:00:17.990
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

8
00:00:17.990 --> 00:00:20.596
As we continue on with Office 365.

9
00:00:20.596 --> 00:00:25.310
This is part three of set
up Azure AD Connect tool.

10
00:00:25.310 --> 00:00:27.510
And who should bring us this information?

11
00:00:27.510 --> 00:00:28.410
Why, it's Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:30.468
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ronnie thanks for joining us.

13
00:00:30.468 --> 00:00:35.130
>> Thank you Zach for having me back on
the show as we continue to dive into some

14
00:00:35.130 --> 00:00:38.840
of the details inside of
the Azure AD Connect tool, and

15
00:00:38.840 --> 00:00:43.240
this is really where we're starting
to begin to use the tool itself.

16
00:00:43.240 --> 00:00:46.450
So in a previous episode, we kind of led
you up to this point and talked about

17
00:00:46.450 --> 00:00:51.240
the express settings, that, and what it
actually accomplishes for us with a single

18
00:00:51.240 --> 00:00:56.870
domain and a single forest, and
now we're moving onto the customization.

19
00:00:56.870 --> 00:00:59.260
If we have anything beyond the complexity,
and

20
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:02.310
what we've been talking about in terms
of single forces, single domain.

21
00:01:02.310 --> 00:01:04.600
This is where we gonna need to
set up the customized settings.

22
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:07.380
And this will get us an opportunity
to walk through those NAS where

23
00:01:07.380 --> 00:01:08.540
we are right now.

24
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:10.060
Let's go ahead and
jump right then to this, so

25
00:01:10.060 --> 00:01:14.170
that we can see that should be
happening for us as we go through here.

26
00:01:14.170 --> 00:01:17.420
So, instead of actually ending up
choosing the Express Settings which

27
00:01:17.420 --> 00:01:19.940
would have been perfectly fine for
what we're doing.

28
00:01:19.940 --> 00:01:21.800
And that's probably all I should do but
for

29
00:01:21.800 --> 00:01:25.260
us to take a look at the complex settings.

30
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:26.960
Notice that once we get into it, and

31
00:01:26.960 --> 00:01:30.990
we chose to customize, the first
thing here is about the User Sign-on.

32
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:35.110
And this is where we have four
different methods that we can choose,

33
00:01:35.110 --> 00:01:38.130
depending on what we actually
want to do here, okay?

34
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:42.550
So let's make sure we understand these
options in terms of user sign-on, and

35
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:44.790
what it's going to do for us, okay?

36
00:01:44.790 --> 00:01:49.590
When we start with this idea of connecting
the Active Directories together we

37
00:01:49.590 --> 00:01:53.100
have to think about what's going to happen
with our passwords and the sign-ons and

38
00:01:53.100 --> 00:01:54.950
what we end up doing it, okay?

39
00:01:54.950 --> 00:02:00.040
So now with these four options available
consider what was gonna be here, okay?

40
00:02:00.040 --> 00:02:04.540
Also as you do this on your own take
a look at when you hover over that

41
00:02:04.540 --> 00:02:07.680
blue dot every once in a while
mine disappears very quickly.

42
00:02:07.680 --> 00:02:11.510
I'm kinda surprised it actually stayed
up as long as it has right now.

43
00:02:11.510 --> 00:02:15.810
But you'll actually be able to see some
information, and you wanna get these

44
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:21.500
particular scenarios in your mind,
as what you actually end up using here.

45
00:02:21.500 --> 00:02:22.980
It's gonna be the key.

46
00:02:22.980 --> 00:02:26.425
Now once you set this up it doesn't
mean you can't run back through this and

47
00:02:26.425 --> 00:02:27.740
reset it up again.

48
00:02:27.740 --> 00:02:30.300
But in the end I'm gonna choose
just the do not configure for

49
00:02:30.300 --> 00:02:34.940
right now because we are gonna get into
the other signing of what we wanna do.

50
00:02:36.020 --> 00:02:39.100
But by default,
this is probably the first one here, okay,

51
00:02:39.100 --> 00:02:42.340
which is gonna be
the Password Synchronization.

52
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:46.010
With Password Synchronization,
if we choose this option,

53
00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:49.695
even though we are connecting
the Active Directory tool together,

54
00:02:49.695 --> 00:02:52.970
okay, we're still actually
having two different accounts.

55
00:02:52.970 --> 00:02:56.930
So the synchronization will take
whatever is in my Active Directory, and

56
00:02:56.930 --> 00:03:02.570
then if Zach has an account there
it will link it up and match.

57
00:03:02.570 --> 00:03:04.030
If someone does it, lets take for

58
00:03:04.030 --> 00:03:08.920
an example Taylor, if he does not have
an account on Office 365, it will create

59
00:03:08.920 --> 00:03:13.708
a duplicate account in Office 365
of what he has here on his Azure.

60
00:03:13.708 --> 00:03:18.276
On his on-premises Active Directory,
and will then create another

61
00:03:18.276 --> 00:03:23.090
account that will be named exactly
the same thing over an Office 365.

62
00:03:23.090 --> 00:03:28.520
The second thing it would do is this
idea of password synchronization.

63
00:03:28.520 --> 00:03:31.850
Password synchronization will then
look at the source of authority,

64
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:35.240
which is the on-premises
source of authority for us.

65
00:03:35.240 --> 00:03:37.360
And it will say here's the password.

66
00:03:37.360 --> 00:03:41.440
And Office 365 will say,
I don't have a password at this point.

67
00:03:41.440 --> 00:03:42.860
And then it will actually say, well,

68
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:46.840
make your password the same
as the on-premises side.

69
00:03:46.840 --> 00:03:51.030
So you have really this idea
of two accounts here, right.

70
00:03:51.030 --> 00:03:53.940
Where you have one for
your on-premises with a password,

71
00:03:53.940 --> 00:03:58.050
you also have the Office 365 account,

72
00:03:58.050 --> 00:04:03.140
they’ll end up having the same password
as well and the same user account too.

73
00:04:03.140 --> 00:04:06.110
Between those they will
end up synchronizing

74
00:04:06.110 --> 00:04:08.370
based on the password itself.

75
00:04:08.370 --> 00:04:09.920
So in that sense here,

76
00:04:09.920 --> 00:04:14.080
they are still two separate accounts
that are actually being used, but

77
00:04:14.080 --> 00:04:18.470
the only thing that they're really sharing
between them is really that password.

78
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:22.050
If we enable another feature and I'm not
exactly sure where it actually occurs in

79
00:04:22.050 --> 00:04:24.240
this, where it's password write back.

80
00:04:24.240 --> 00:04:28.694
I can change the actual password in Office
365, and that will allow me to write

81
00:04:28.694 --> 00:04:32.312
the feature back to the on-premises and
change it there as well.

82
00:04:32.312 --> 00:04:36.465
But normally by default, if that's not
actually enabled the password write back,

So if I select users,

We still actually to take a look

But the great thing is, if I am not sure.

So even though I can't do

551

552
00:32:21.080 --> 00:32:24.650
And now has to begin that

What did I do with this

555

So that's what we still have

556
00:32:32.900 --> 00:32:36.340
We need to verify that and we might need
to do a little bit more troubleshooting.

557
00:32:36.340 --> 00:32:40.840
But, Zach we are out of time, which

558
00:32:40.840 --> 00:32:42.260
four actually.

00:32:42.260 --> 00:32:44.638
For, of course, the connect tool as well.

560
00:32:44.638 --> 00:32:48.690
>> Say that Azure AD connect to a part

561
00:32:48.690 --> 00:32:51.480
and three as well and

00:32:51.480 --> 00:32:54.020
Ronnie's doing an amazing job,

And check out all the other

they're all designed to do one thing,

565

And tell everybody you know about

Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

569
00:33:05.156 --> 00:33:11.610

00:33:11.610 --> 00:33:13.672
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie show the connection steps and discuss the setup for the Azure AD Connect Tool to work.  They show the synchronization and then show some of the different considerations after the AD Connect Tool is in place and ready to go
episodes.title: Set Up Azure AD Connect Tool Part 4

topics.title: Manage Identities with Azure Active Directory Connect

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss how to prepare and plan for implementation of ADFS for our connection to Office 365.  They describe what it does for us and why we need it.  Lastly, they also discuss what are some of the elements that we must have together before we begin implementing it for our Office 365 environment.
episodes.title: Plan AD FS Requirements

00:27:34.516 --> 00:27:36.691
you get spit out 16 different errors.

485
00:27:36.691 --> 00:27:39.142
And it says you're still
missing stuff,okay?

486
00:27:39.142 --> 00:27:40.690
You're still doing this.

487
00:27:40.690 --> 00:27:43.745
And we'll even show you some of the issues
that you'll run into, at least at

488
00:27:43.745 --> 00:27:47.352
the beginning when you're trying to test
it, when you're also using Server 2016.

489
00:27:47.352 --> 00:27:50.170
So there's a lot more
to this than we think.

490
00:27:50.170 --> 00:27:53.120
But at the same time,
it's something that you've gotta plan for.

491
00:27:53.120 --> 00:27:55.780
It's not something you just go,
let me just install the role and

492
00:27:55.780 --> 00:27:57.120
let's see what happens.

493
00:27:57.120 --> 00:28:01.280
It's not that particular way of
setting up and making it work, okay?

494
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:05.490
So get that in your mind, go through some
of the elements in the requirements here

495
00:28:05.490 --> 00:28:06.910
that we're talking about.

496
00:28:06.910 --> 00:28:07.830
And then once that's done,

497
00:28:07.830 --> 00:28:11.970
that means we are gonna be ready
then to move on to the installing

498
00:28:11.970 --> 00:28:15.946
of Federation Services, and getting it
ready for setting up for single sign on.

499
00:28:15.946 --> 00:28:19.390
>> Pretty cool Ronnie and
thank you for at least helping and

500
00:28:19.390 --> 00:28:22.100
assist us with understanding
that each topology

501
00:28:22.100 --> 00:28:25.960
is gonna require different
configurations and set up there, so

502
00:28:25.960 --> 00:28:30.130
you guys can be prepared for how to
go ahead and set up ADFS, thank you.

503
00:28:30.130 --> 00:28:31.985
And thank you for joining us as well.

504
00:28:31.985 --> 00:28:34.910
But you don't wanna miss out on what
we have headed next for this show.

505
00:28:34.910 --> 00:28:37.620
We'll go ahead and sign out,
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

506
00:28:37.620 --> 00:28:38.400
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

507
00:28:38.400 --> 00:28:40.735
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

508
00:28:40.735 --> 00:28:46.725
[MUSIC]

509
00:28:46.725 --> 00:28:49.814
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie begin with the basic installation requirements and install the ADFS server for use.  After completing the installation and post-configuration, they use the Azure AD Connect tool to complete and verify ADFS is working correctly.
episodes.title: Install and Manage AD FS Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.350 --> 00:00:01.307
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.307 --> 00:00:06.172
I'm your host Don Pezet, coming at you
live from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:06.172 --> 00:00:07.269
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.269 --> 00:00:08.416
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.416 --> 00:00:11.803
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.803 --> 00:00:16.750
>> Welcome to your Microsoft Office 365,
Identities and Requirements Series.

7
00:00:16.750 --> 00:00:18.900
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:21.990
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at, well how to install and

9
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:24.250
manage our ADFS server.

10
00:00:24.250 --> 00:00:26.980
And with us today, back in studios,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:26.980 --> 00:00:28.060
How is it going, Ronnie?

12
00:00:28.060 --> 00:00:32.737
>> It's going well, Cherokee, thank you
for having me back on the show, as we

13
00:00:32.737 --> 00:00:37.710
continue to take a look here at installing
an Active Directory Federation Server

14
00:00:37.710 --> 00:00:42.119
to get us ready for the single
sign-on that we have with Office 365.

15
00:00:42.119 --> 00:00:44.127
So the great thing about this is,

16
00:00:44.127 --> 00:00:47.713
we don't really have to add in
a bunch of additional tools,

17
00:00:47.713 --> 00:00:52.060
but there are a few pre-requisites
that we want to make sure of, okay?

18
00:00:52.060 --> 00:00:56.070
When we first set up an Active
Directory Federation Server, okay,

19
00:00:56.070 --> 00:01:01.050
one of the things, of course, that you
have to get is going to be a third party

20
00:01:01.050 --> 00:01:04.600
certificate, okay, when things go out now.

21
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:07.480
Can you do this with
an internal certificate, yes.

22
00:01:07.480 --> 00:01:13.280
You can as long as you can get the other
side to trust your certificate,

23
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:15.250
you are off and ready to go.

24
00:01:15.250 --> 00:01:19.190
So generally, what you do, is you obtain
a third party certificate for your

25
00:01:19.190 --> 00:01:25.370
Federation Server, so you can go out to,
and find on your favorite search engine.

26
00:01:25.370 --> 00:01:26.170
Do what I did.

27
00:01:26.170 --> 00:01:27.500
Do a trial certificate.

28
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:29.150
A trial SSL certificate.

29
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:32.690
And that way, you fill it out,
you're off and ready to go.

30
00:01:32.690 --> 00:01:37.298
Once you get to that point where you're
ready to make the request, they'll have

31
00:01:37.298 --> 00:01:41.594
you verify that you own that domain name,
and that's actually gonna key.

32
00:01:41.594 --> 00:01:44.725
Cuz in the end when you do this,
let me show you here on my side,

33
00:01:44.725 --> 00:01:47.390
let's see if I can actually sign in here.

34
00:01:47.390 --> 00:01:54.656
So once I sign in, they're gonna ask you,
okay, to verify your ownership.

35
00:01:54.656 --> 00:01:58.570
And one of the ways that they ask
you to verify your ownership,

36
00:01:58.570 --> 00:02:02.420
maybe doing what we call a CNAME
hash is what it will give you.

37
00:02:02.420 --> 00:02:04.463
It's this big long number and

38
00:02:04.463 --> 00:02:08.475
you'll have to enter that
thing into your DNS registrar.

39
00:02:08.475 --> 00:02:12.135
And once you do that, and there's actually
exactly the way that they want it,

40
00:02:12.135 --> 00:02:15.629
they'll verify that your ownership is
there and that you are ready to go for

41
00:02:15.629 --> 00:02:18.150
everything else that you'll have to do,
okay?

42
00:02:18.150 --> 00:02:20.890
At that point, you'll be able, of course,

43
00:02:20.890 --> 00:02:26.280
then to get access to what they send
you which is going to be a copy

44
00:02:26.280 --> 00:02:31.530
of your certificate after you generate
that certificate request as well, okay?

45
00:02:31.530 --> 00:02:35.620
Now, generating certificate
request inside of Server 2016.

46
00:02:35.620 --> 00:02:41.991
You can actually do that by installing, of
course, the web server if you choose to,

47
00:02:41.991 --> 00:02:47.558
or by running a particular program
called DigiCert, that's out there,

48
00:02:47.558 --> 00:02:52.443
and I don't know if I still have
it on my computer or not, there.

49
00:02:52.443 --> 00:02:57.434
So let me see if I can show you
the DigiCert here, I still may have it,

50
00:02:57.434 --> 00:02:58.756
here there it is.

51
00:02:58.756 --> 00:03:06.312
The DigiCert utility So

52
00:03:06.312 --> 00:03:10.669
here's the DigiCert utility, and
you can see where it actually did get

53
00:03:10.669 --> 00:03:14.500
issued a certificate,
from Comodo here, to do so.

54
00:03:14.500 --> 00:03:19.460
You can run something like this to
help you to create that request, make

55
00:03:19.460 --> 00:03:23.900
sure you choose the SSL type, and that you
enter in all of the available information.

56
00:03:23.900 --> 00:03:26.615
The more information that you can
enter in, the better it's gonna be.

57
00:03:26.615 --> 00:03:29.842
It's gonna generate for you that
certificate in the end, and of course,

58
00:03:29.842 --> 00:03:32.497
wherever you actually go for
that third party certificate,

59
00:03:32.497 --> 00:03:36.214
you'll have to enter that information in
and you'll get your certificate, okay?

60
00:03:36.214 --> 00:03:40.096
So this has been around for
a while, that's out there.

61
00:03:40.096 --> 00:03:44.220
So I just found it then, I said,
that's the one that's used for ADFS a lot.

62
00:03:44.220 --> 00:03:47.240
So I just did that,
generate that certificate.

63
00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:50.200
And once you have that right,
you've got kinda the important

64
00:03:50.200 --> 00:03:54.980
pieces of information that you need,
if you're gonna run ADFS to get that done.

65
00:03:54.980 --> 00:03:56.902
The other thing that you may need, okay?

66
00:03:56.902 --> 00:03:59.470
Certificate is definitely
an important part, but

67
00:03:59.470 --> 00:04:03.000
if you are also going to be doing.

68
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:03.520
Okay?

69
00:04:03.520 --> 00:04:07.250
The idea here of running
that web access proxy.

70
00:04:07.250 --> 00:04:10.450
You're gonna also need
a public IP address.

71
00:04:10.450 --> 00:04:11.100
Okay?

72
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:13.767
So check out your organization, and

73
00:04:13.767 --> 00:04:19.510
verify that your ADFS machine can get
a public IP address assigned to it.

74
00:04:19.510 --> 00:04:24.470
And make sure that that's yours to use,
and then you're off and ready to go.

75
00:04:24.470 --> 00:04:26.910
It may take you a little bit
of time to request that, but

76
00:04:26.910 --> 00:04:28.850
once everything is done,
you'll need that as well.

77
00:04:28.850 --> 00:04:30.680
If you're not going to be
doing the web access proxy,

78
00:04:30.680 --> 00:04:35.140
you don't have to worry about
using the public IP address.

79
00:04:35.140 --> 00:04:38.950
But if you are gonna do that,
make sure you get a public IP address.

80
00:04:38.950 --> 00:04:42.650
Not a private one, that's not gonna
help you out as well, all right?

81
00:04:42.650 --> 00:04:46.050
So two basic requirements there for
the install and

82
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:47.790
getting everything to work, okay?

83
00:04:47.790 --> 00:04:49.700
>> Okay
>> So once we get that done,

84
00:04:49.700 --> 00:04:53.150
the next step is really kind
of just following along some

85
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:56.480
of the things we would normally
do in setting up a server.

86
00:04:56.480 --> 00:05:00.617
I just clicked on the start menu, and I'm
gonna bring up the server manager because

87
00:05:00.617 --> 00:05:04.540
the the Active Directory Federation
Services is really just a role.

88
00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:07.510
Now, you'll see I've already
installed this right here,

89
00:05:07.510 --> 00:05:12.410
but it'll give us a chance to a walk
through a portion of what we need to,

90
00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:14.850
to get some of the things set up here.

91
00:05:14.850 --> 00:05:18.149
So this is where you go through the add,
roles and feature wizard.

92
00:05:19.660 --> 00:05:23.730
And of course, you select the server
that you're gonna install this on.

93
00:05:23.730 --> 00:05:25.590
Verify that you've got this one checked.

94
00:05:25.590 --> 00:05:27.097
And you'll see where it
actually says install.

95
00:05:27.097 --> 00:05:28.860
And yours may not say
installed at that point.

96
00:05:30.210 --> 00:05:32.350
And then you continue to proceed.

97
00:05:32.350 --> 00:05:34.600
Usually, the kind of requirement
that's for everything,

98
00:05:34.600 --> 00:05:38.990
is going to be at least dot net framework,
four something, at this point.

99
00:05:38.990 --> 00:05:43.160
So I just continue to proceed on and
let it finish its install.

100
00:05:43.160 --> 00:05:45.224
At the end,
it's gonna generate, of course,

101
00:05:45.224 --> 00:05:49.450
telling you that it's fully installed,
but it needs additional configuration.

102
00:05:49.450 --> 00:05:52.970
You'll end up seeing in 2016,
where it'll tell you click here, and

103
00:05:52.970 --> 00:05:56.090
go to the configuration sock,
okay, which is fine.

104
00:05:56.090 --> 00:06:00.330
You'll answer a lot of questions
including, how, of course,

105
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:04.630
to get access to that certificate
to get that installed.

106
00:06:04.630 --> 00:06:08.280
And you'll need two accounts here, okay?

107
00:06:08.280 --> 00:06:12.240
And you'll just have to kind of follow
along in where they ask you for it.

108
00:06:12.240 --> 00:06:13.593
More than likely,

109
00:06:13.593 --> 00:06:19.437
you'll actually need to make sure that you
are logged in as a domain admin, okay?

110
00:06:19.437 --> 00:06:22.067
So they actually need to make sure
that you actually get logged in

111
00:06:22.067 --> 00:06:23.820
as a domain administrator.

112
00:06:23.820 --> 00:06:28.900
Secondly, you may also need
the enterprise administrator account.

113
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:30.860
Usually, you don't have to
worry about that one too much,

114
00:06:30.860 --> 00:06:32.420
unless it asks you for it.

115
00:06:32.420 --> 00:06:35.260
But if you're gonna be doing something
that's gonna ask you for the enterprise

116
00:06:35.260 --> 00:06:39.310
administrator, make sure you also
have access to that account as well.

117
00:06:39.310 --> 00:06:43.290
So I am going to select tools in
the upper right hand corner, and

118
00:06:43.290 --> 00:06:45.910
then click on ADFS management.

119
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:49.980
Okay, so
once you run through that install, it is,

120
00:06:49.980 --> 00:06:52.560
you are gonna have to kinda
fill out the information.

121
00:06:52.560 --> 00:06:53.770
And this is simple, okay.

122
00:06:53.770 --> 00:06:57.580
A lot of it is the idea of
providing the right credentials.

123
00:06:57.580 --> 00:07:00.860
The other thing that you
may also want to create,

124
00:07:00.860 --> 00:07:04.210
is going to be a group
managed service account.

125
00:07:07.898 --> 00:07:11.030
Let me make sure I can show you
what I'm talking about here.

126
00:07:13.600 --> 00:07:14.970
Wait, it's not on this computer.

127
00:07:16.540 --> 00:07:17.950
>> Yeah,
you were on the Windows 10 machine.

128
00:07:17.950 --> 00:07:18.880
>> Yeah, I was on the other one.

129
00:07:27.672 --> 00:07:28.789
>> Think that's it?

130
00:07:28.789 --> 00:07:30.559
>> I do.
>> [LAUGH]

131
00:07:30.559 --> 00:07:36.125
>> [LAUGH] I do think that's it.

132
00:07:36.125 --> 00:07:37.742
I was like,
where did my active directory search?

133
00:07:37.742 --> 00:07:38.540
There we go.

134
00:07:38.540 --> 00:07:39.040
Okay.

135
00:07:40.550 --> 00:07:43.780
So if I go under Manage Service accounts,
you'll see.

136
00:07:43.780 --> 00:07:47.489
I also created this, which was
a group managed service account, okay?

137
00:07:47.489 --> 00:07:48.980
I put both of them up here.

138
00:07:48.980 --> 00:07:51.954
This is for your sake,
depending on what you wanna do, okay?

139
00:07:51.954 --> 00:07:55.455
Remember that a managed service account
it sent you, the password doesn't expire.

140
00:07:55.455 --> 00:08:00.272
But in security safe, we normally want our
passwords to change anyway after a while.

141
00:08:00.272 --> 00:08:03.653
So creating a group managed
service account instead will

142
00:08:03.653 --> 00:08:08.740
allow us to actually have the passwords
rotated on a periodic basis instead.

143
00:08:08.740 --> 00:08:14.010
And you'll also need to install and
verify that your key, your KDC,

144
00:08:14.010 --> 00:08:17.790
your key management server is also up and
running to ensure that

145
00:08:17.790 --> 00:08:22.730
that will actually generate and
rotate your passwords as well.

146
00:08:22.730 --> 00:08:26.360
So either way, right, you actually
have that created and ready to go.

147
00:08:26.360 --> 00:08:30.330
This is the recommended method with 2016,
is to use that.

148
00:08:30.330 --> 00:08:34.150
And I always put a g in front of it for
the group managed service instead and

149
00:08:34.150 --> 00:08:35.518
you can even see the type here.

150
00:08:35.518 --> 00:08:38.430
The MSA Group Managed Service Account.

151
00:08:38.430 --> 00:08:40.990
So, those are some of
the things that you wanna

152
00:08:40.990 --> 00:08:43.060
make sure that you have
ready to go if you need to.

153
00:08:44.480 --> 00:08:48.200
And during the walk through on the wizard
as you start it, it will tell you,

154
00:08:48.200 --> 00:08:52.030
hey, which particular account is
gonna be used as a service account.

155
00:08:52.030 --> 00:08:55.700
Then you select that service account and
then you're off and ready to go.

156
00:08:55.700 --> 00:09:00.670
Once you are done and the configuration
is set up at the end here, okay, and

157
00:09:00.670 --> 00:09:02.280
everything is going through,

158
00:09:02.280 --> 00:09:06.920
this is where you want to check
which is underneath services, okay?

159
00:09:06.920 --> 00:09:10.650
So at this point, you can of course
go through each one of these,

160
00:09:10.650 --> 00:09:14.550
but I wanna point out the idea
of the authentication methods.

161
00:09:14.550 --> 00:09:19.600
And now you can see under Intranet,
internally, Windows Authentication,

162
00:09:19.600 --> 00:09:23.230
Passport authentication,
Forms authentication, Extranet.

163
00:09:23.230 --> 00:09:25.100
You see all this stuff as well.

164
00:09:25.100 --> 00:09:28.270
And of course, even Multi-factor as well,
if you want to.

165
00:09:28.270 --> 00:09:32.370
All of this is still configurable,
as long as you know how to configure it.

166
00:09:32.370 --> 00:09:36.090
We're not getting into that in
this shelf right now, okay.

167
00:09:36.090 --> 00:09:38.090
The other one that should
show up automatically,

168
00:09:38.090 --> 00:09:41.660
of course,
is going to be your certificate.

169
00:09:41.660 --> 00:09:44.650
So, here you can see
my entire certificate.

170
00:09:44.650 --> 00:09:50.140
And I added it in, and there is
an alias attached to this too, okay?

171
00:09:50.140 --> 00:09:53.590
So I made a ADFS,
the name of my server is actually

172
00:09:55.350 --> 00:09:57.850
FS01 for the Federation Service 01.

173
00:09:57.850 --> 00:10:02.910
The reason is if I know that in
the future my network continues to grow,

174
00:10:02.910 --> 00:10:07.620
I may add in another federation server and
I continue to go on and

175
00:10:07.620 --> 00:10:11.010
I create what we call
a federation server farm, okay?

176
00:10:11.010 --> 00:10:15.450
So if you set that up you also do that
during the installation process as well.

177
00:10:15.450 --> 00:10:19.540
Now the only thing that I wanna make
sure of before we move further in,

178
00:10:19.540 --> 00:10:25.150
in term of this, is at that point,
it's gonna ask you one of two things.

179
00:10:25.150 --> 00:10:27.310
When it says, hey,
what do you want to do here,

180
00:10:27.310 --> 00:10:29.850
at the very beginning when
you start the installation.

181
00:10:29.850 --> 00:10:33.502
You wanna create a stand alone,
federation server or

182
00:10:33.502 --> 00:10:38.500
do you want this to be a farm,
they are the first one in the farm.

183
00:10:38.500 --> 00:10:42.590
If you do a standalone,
it means that you will not be able to add

184
00:10:42.590 --> 00:10:47.630
in an additional federation server
if your network continues to grow.

185
00:10:47.630 --> 00:10:49.750
So, that's not a good thing.

186
00:10:49.750 --> 00:10:53.124
Normally, the best practice,
of course, is to just say,

187
00:10:53.124 --> 00:10:55.697
I'm gonna create a federation server farm.

188
00:10:55.697 --> 00:11:01.526
And that way, when you create this name
to give to that farm that means all

189
00:11:01.526 --> 00:11:07.190
of those different servers,
my FS01, 02, 010, or FS10.

190
00:11:07.190 --> 00:11:11.560
All those can now be listed
underneath that one name and

191
00:11:11.560 --> 00:11:16.880
I can hit any of those to allow me to
do my federation services if I need to.

192
00:11:16.880 --> 00:11:20.090
So you'll actually see the ones for
of course decrypting,

193
00:11:20.090 --> 00:11:23.080
service communications and
notice everything is actually encrypted.

194
00:11:23.080 --> 00:11:26.240
And there's that token sign in that
we were talking about in the previous

195
00:11:26.240 --> 00:11:27.410
episode.

196
00:11:27.410 --> 00:11:32.400
Where remember when we get authenticated
through our on premises active directory

197
00:11:32.400 --> 00:11:35.420

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the use and need of the Web Access Proxy Server for the SSO.  They talk about some of the additional prequisites to allow it work.  They also describer how users from outside of our domain will use the web access proxy.
episodes.title: Install Web Access Proxy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.370 --> 00:00:03.736
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.736 --> 00:00:11.030
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.030 --> 00:00:13.652
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

4
00:00:13.652 --> 00:00:16.620
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

5
00:00:16.620 --> 00:00:21.030
I'm your host, Zach Memos and this is
Office 365 and in this episode we're gonna

6

install web access proxy with the one and
only Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:26.360
Ronnie, great to have you here.

8
00:00:26.360 --> 00:00:27.136
Thanks so much.

9
00:00:27.136 --> 00:00:28.266
Enlighten us!

10
00:00:28.266 --> 00:00:31.010
[LAUGH]
>> All right, thank you for being here and

11
00:00:31.010 --> 00:00:35.910
thank you for having me back on the show
as we continue now to install kind of

12
00:00:35.910 --> 00:00:39.500
the second part of getting our
Active Directory Federation Services for

13
00:00:39.500 --> 00:00:42.200
single sign on and established right?

14
00:00:42.200 --> 00:00:47.120
So in a previous episode, we set up the
Active Directory Federation Services and

15
00:00:47.120 --> 00:00:52.720
verified that it was working properly
through that Azure AD Connect tool and

16
00:00:52.720 --> 00:00:55.670
that way we kind of knew
everything was set up.

17
00:00:55.670 --> 00:01:00.390
That even though that federation service
is now set up and what we actually need to

18
00:01:00.390 --> 00:01:05.830
do, okay is we need to begin to prepare
for what people connecting and using it.

19
00:01:05.830 --> 00:01:10.770
Now, let me go back to my diagram here for
just a moment.

20
00:01:10.770 --> 00:01:13.280
And that way we will do
a little bit of reminder and

21
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:18.270
a little bit of breather here for
what we're actually trying to do, okay?

22
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:22.760
So at this particular point and
time, this is established.

23
00:01:22.760 --> 00:01:26.450
I know it seems like a lot of you haven't
been watching the previous episodes here,

24
00:01:26.450 --> 00:01:29.880
don't worry about what's behind my head
right now, but as you're actually taking

25
00:01:29.880 --> 00:01:31.570
a look at it, let me see if I
can click on it, there we go.

26
00:01:31.570 --> 00:01:34.640
That will make it easier and
not get that thing out there, okay.

27
00:01:34.640 --> 00:01:39.020
So the Active Directory Federation
Services right here in the center,

28
00:01:39.020 --> 00:01:41.710
that's actually established for us.

29
00:01:41.710 --> 00:01:45.441
We can run through that
Azure AD Connect tool and

30
00:01:45.441 --> 00:01:50.677
it now is simulating us as a client
here within the ITProTV domain.

31
00:01:50.677 --> 00:01:55.252
When I present credentials over to
Office 365, it says hey I'm gonna

32
00:01:55.252 --> 00:01:59.752
redirect you over here to the Active
Directory Federation Services for

33
00:01:59.752 --> 00:02:01.252
your authentication.

34
00:02:01.252 --> 00:02:06.098
And it is the Active Directory Federation
Services that will essentially relay

35
00:02:06.098 --> 00:02:11.158
that at this point, right, over to where
our on-premises Active Directory is and

36
00:02:11.158 --> 00:02:15.320
where we're normally running
our Azure AD Connect tool.

37
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:19.630
Then it is there,
that will validate my credentials.

38
00:02:19.630 --> 00:02:22.950
Once the credentials are validated,
two things will happen.

39
00:02:22.950 --> 00:02:26.860
It will of course validate those
credentials, and it will send back a token

40
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:30.190
is what it will do, so
the authentication will say hey look.

41
00:02:30.190 --> 00:02:31.360
This guy's good.

42
00:02:31.360 --> 00:02:34.540
Now we need to actually
get an authorization token

43
00:02:34.540 --> 00:02:37.660
to get access to Office 365.

44
00:02:37.660 --> 00:02:42.781
So the authentication that is presented
here as it comes back to the user,

45
00:02:42.781 --> 00:02:45.756
even though they're now authenticated,

46
00:02:45.756 --> 00:02:50.071
what really gives them access
to Office 365 is that token.

47
00:02:50.071 --> 00:02:54.687
And so now, it actually does get
access in and they have that token and

48
00:02:54.687 --> 00:02:56.830
we are ready to go.

49
00:02:56.830 --> 00:03:01.030
The issue that we have though
is that if we think about it,

50
00:03:01.030 --> 00:03:04.780
this works fine as long as
you're within the organization.

51
00:03:04.780 --> 00:03:10.270
But once we start to deal with the very
fact that you're gonna have users not only

52
00:03:10.270 --> 00:03:16.060
Inside of the boundaries of your domain,
you may also have users that are outside.

53
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:19.936
Telecommuters right, the people that
are logging in from the outside that still

54
00:03:19.936 --> 00:03:21.423
need access to Office 365.

55
00:03:21.423 --> 00:03:27.020
Well now what happens is that it's
the same thing but it's from the outside.

56
00:03:27.020 --> 00:03:30.940
The problem right now If I get
somebody from the outside, so

57
00:03:30.940 --> 00:03:34.720
let me try to, of course I'm talking,
let me just select one.

58
00:03:34.720 --> 00:03:36.930
So let me do this here, okay?

59
00:03:36.930 --> 00:03:40.620
So let me just kinda simulate, that from
the outside of the domain, if they wanted

60
00:03:40.620 --> 00:03:46.190
to do the same thing, it's going to
redirect them the same way, back to ADFS.

61
00:03:46.190 --> 00:03:50.200
But the problem is that now means
I'm gonna have to get access

62
00:03:50.200 --> 00:03:54.500
inside of my domain,
which is already secure.

63
00:03:54.500 --> 00:03:59.710
Outside access inbound is not something
I really want to allow very easily,

64
00:03:59.710 --> 00:04:03.210
and especially without any
security boundary that's there.

65
00:04:03.210 --> 00:04:07.400
So we want to actually switch
that up by providing another

66
00:04:07.400 --> 00:04:12.960
server that will sit at the edge of my
network is what it will actually do.

67
00:04:12.960 --> 00:04:17.070
And when somebody on the outside
now tries to connect in,

68
00:04:17.070 --> 00:04:20.950
it will hit what we call a web
access proxy instead and

69
00:04:20.950 --> 00:04:25.510
as web access proxy that will proxy
that request internally for us.

70
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:28.390
So that way we're not allowing for
multiple connections on the outside

71
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:31.010
that we don't know where they
come from to all just hit

72
00:04:31.010 --> 00:04:35.850
the Active Directory Federation Services,
it's gonna hit that web access proxy.

73
00:04:35.850 --> 00:04:40.170
The web access proxy will actually decide
what gets kind of sent over and whether or

74
00:04:40.170 --> 00:04:41.530
not we'll get that access.

75
00:04:41.530 --> 00:04:42.330
>> So once again, for

76
00:04:42.330 --> 00:04:47.710
people with limited mind like me,
this is sort of a limited access.

77
00:04:47.710 --> 00:04:48.300
>> Right.

78
00:04:48.300 --> 00:04:50.690
>> Is what the web access
proxy is all about.

79
00:04:50.690 --> 00:04:53.730
>> Right, it's about protecting
our internal resources that we

80
00:04:53.730 --> 00:04:56.420
need to definitely protect,
that also gives, of course,

81
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:59.500
users that are on the outside,
that need the same access and

82
00:04:59.500 --> 00:05:02.850
the same protections,
to be able to do the same thing.

83
00:05:02.850 --> 00:05:05.860
So that's what we're actually
gonna end up seeing, okay.

84
00:05:05.860 --> 00:05:10.410
Eventually this is what
it's gonna take a look at,

85
00:05:10.410 --> 00:05:13.670
okay, or look like in the end
in terms of the topology.

86
00:05:13.670 --> 00:05:14.380
>> Okay.

87
00:05:14.380 --> 00:05:20.840
>> So usually, for us, our proxy server,
I've renamed ours as ADFS here, okay?

88
00:05:20.840 --> 00:05:26.394
So what will actually kind of do that and
the reason why is that, from the outside,

89
00:05:26.394 --> 00:05:30.760
I don't want them hitting
something like FS02.itpro.tv.

90
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:35.070
I want them hitting a service that they're
gonna actually kind of have a generic idea

91
00:05:35.070 --> 00:05:36.527
about from the outside, but

92
00:05:36.527 --> 00:05:40.200
not anything that seems to
indicate an internal name at all.

93
00:05:40.200 --> 00:05:41.250
So normally, here's what we have.

94
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:44.550
Of course, out on the Internet,
we have Office 365 out here,

95
00:05:44.550 --> 00:05:48.080
here's my DNS registrar,
that's out there on the Internet as well.

96
00:05:48.080 --> 00:05:50.820
I could have a partner
company that's also out here.

97
00:05:50.820 --> 00:05:54.730
Let's say that there's another public
network that I'm also a part of as well

98
00:05:54.730 --> 00:05:56.350
and here's of course, my network.

99
00:05:56.350 --> 00:06:01.430
And then, often its own central
port on the firewall or

100
00:06:01.430 --> 00:06:07.350
inside of some area here, we normally
call it a DMZ, a demilitarized zone.

101
00:06:07.350 --> 00:06:09.800
And that's where we're gonna
set up our particular proxy.

102
00:06:09.800 --> 00:06:11.790
>> Right.
>> So that way when people connect in

103
00:06:11.790 --> 00:06:15.240
from the outside or
from the public network and

104
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:18.400
now once we actually get that,
they hit this.

105
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:22.259
And this is what allows them access
inside to be authenticated and

106
00:06:22.259 --> 00:06:24.723
then they get that secured token, okay.

107
00:06:24.723 --> 00:06:28.450
So that's really the kind of set up
that we're actually talking about at

108
00:06:28.450 --> 00:06:29.880
this point.

109
00:06:29.880 --> 00:06:34.490
So there's only a couple of other
prerequisites and I made just a small and

110
00:06:34.490 --> 00:06:35.720
short list here.

111
00:06:35.720 --> 00:06:38.300
I didn't wanna overwhelm us,

00:06:38.300 --> 00:06:41.300
It's not really in any one
particular order of importance,

00:06:41.300 --> 00:06:43.380
but all the user are actually
important at some point.

114
00:06:43.380 --> 00:06:46.260
>> And this important maybe to
memorize for the exam, right?

115
00:06:46.260 --> 00:06:48.670
>> Well it's important at
least to get it working.

116
00:06:48.670 --> 00:06:49.940
Yeah, don't get me wrong.

117
00:06:49.940 --> 00:06:54.630
It can be exam basis where they talk
about what's missing here in this list.

118
00:06:54.630 --> 00:06:58.080
But probably on the Office365,
if anything, right,

119
00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:02.840
It's gonna be do you understand the idea
of what the ADFS server does for

120
00:07:02.840 --> 00:07:07.000
us and why the web access proxy
is important in what we're doing?

121
00:07:07.000 --> 00:07:11.600
But to get it operational, especially
if you're doing a web access proxy,

122
00:07:11.600 --> 00:07:15.260
well one of those things that you might
have to get is a public IP address.

123
00:07:15.260 --> 00:07:17.263
Now, this is an IP address
that is valid on the Internet.

124
00:07:17.263 --> 00:07:22.930
So it's not one that begins
with 192.168.whatever.

125
00:07:22.930 --> 00:07:28.242
It's usually not one that begins with
172.16 all the way through 172.31,

126
00:07:28.242 --> 00:07:32.834
anything like that, those are actually
considered private IP addresses,

127
00:07:32.834 --> 00:07:35.660
along with the 10.whatever, okay?

128
00:07:35.660 --> 00:07:39.270
Those all private, they're only meant for
inside of your local area network,

129
00:07:39.270 --> 00:07:40.830
not out on the Internet.

130
00:07:40.830 --> 00:07:44.540
So anything besides that,
okay, you can put out there.

131
00:07:44.540 --> 00:07:47.850
So what if you go, all right,
so I'm gonna set this up.

132
00:07:47.850 --> 00:07:49.940
Where the heck do I get
a public IP address?

133
00:07:49.940 --> 00:07:52.594
Well, it depends on where you are and
who you're working for, right.

134
00:07:52.594 --> 00:07:56.355
So if you're working for
a particular company, you say,

135
00:07:56.355 --> 00:07:58.751
I'm gonna need a public IP address.

136
00:07:58.751 --> 00:08:01.590
And whoever is in charge
with that should be able to

137
00:08:01.590 --> 00:08:04.940
assigned you a public IP
address to be able to use.

138
00:08:04.940 --> 00:08:07.480
Now if networking is not your strong suit,

139
00:08:07.480 --> 00:08:12.250
this particular exam is not focus in on
your networking skills but at the same

140
00:08:12.250 --> 00:08:15.630
time understanding at least the basics
of networking that's gonna help.

141
00:08:15.630 --> 00:08:20.320
So get your public IP address, make sure
you also get your subnet mask along with

142
00:08:20.320 --> 00:08:24.640
that so that you know what you'll have
to configure on that particular server.

143
00:08:24.640 --> 00:08:26.490
So you can figure that right
on the network interface.

144
00:08:26.490 --> 00:08:29.650
So make sure you actually
get that public IP address.

145
00:08:29.650 --> 00:08:34.384
The other thing that you will also
have to get configured, of course,

146
00:08:34.384 --> 00:08:38.085
is gonna be your DNS record

147
00:08:38.085 --> 00:08:40.822
So if you are doing this for
your own company,

148
00:08:40.822 --> 00:08:44.218
you should figure out who
your public DNS registrar is.

149
00:08:44.218 --> 00:08:48.338
AWS, GoDaddy, for me it's Hover.com.

150
00:08:48.338 --> 00:08:52.090
There's plenty of them out there
that are available to you.

151
00:08:52.090 --> 00:08:54.670
You just have to figure
out which one it is and

152
00:08:54.670 --> 00:08:59.760
then assign that public IP
address that you get along with

153
00:08:59.760 --> 00:09:04.060
the name that you're actually gonna
provide for your proxy server, okay?

154
00:09:04.060 --> 00:09:07.290
So we want that also
implemented in as well.

155
00:09:07.290 --> 00:09:12.330
The other thing that you'll need
on your proxy server itself is to

156
00:09:12.330 --> 00:09:19.430
reconfigure the host file to point
to your internal ADFS server.

157
00:09:19.430 --> 00:09:21.100
Okay?
So, it's a little bit strange,

158
00:09:21.100 --> 00:09:21.630
but I'll show you,

159
00:09:21.630 --> 00:09:25.770
as we go along here, what we need to be
able to do to get this up and running.

160
00:09:25.770 --> 00:09:26.420
Okay?

161
00:09:26.420 --> 00:09:30.460
Of course, also,
you'll need that proxy server certificate.

162
00:09:30.460 --> 00:09:35.860
So if you ended up getting a third
party certificate you're again going

163
00:09:35.860 --> 00:09:39.510
to install that on the machines that's
going to become your proxy server and

164
00:09:39.510 --> 00:09:40.970
you'll be able to do that.

165
00:09:40.970 --> 00:09:44.638
Now, if this is your point and
you're studying at home in a lab go,

166
00:09:44.638 --> 00:09:47.339
Ronnie I'm not gonna get
a server certificate.

167
00:09:47.339 --> 00:09:52.036
Well you have a chance to get 30 day or
90 day trial certificate depending on

168
00:09:52.036 --> 00:09:55.500
where you go, but
be careful with this, right?

169
00:09:55.500 --> 00:09:56.850
If you get it,

170
00:09:56.850 --> 00:10:00.430
pay attention to what they're telling
you as you fill out those forms.

171
00:10:00.430 --> 00:10:03.540
Try and see if they'll give
you a wildcard certificate.

172
00:10:03.540 --> 00:10:06.140
Usually the name on it,
is gonna be an asterisk.

173
00:10:06.140 --> 00:10:10.030
So just hit the asterisk.ITProTVdemo.com.

174
00:10:10.030 --> 00:10:13.710
And that will allow you to put it on
multiple machines if you need to,

175
00:10:13.710 --> 00:10:16.260
to get everything set up for ADFS.

176
00:10:16.260 --> 00:10:18.070
And that's usually the one that you want.

177
00:10:18.070 --> 00:10:20.380
You want to be able to put
it on to your ADFS server,

178
00:10:20.380 --> 00:10:23.100
the one that's actually doing
all the work internally.

179
00:10:23.100 --> 00:10:27.500
You also want to put it on to your web
proxy server as well and that will help

180
00:10:27.500 --> 00:10:31.610
you to get it set up without you having
to go, I have a certificate on one but

181
00:10:31.610 --> 00:10:35.490
I have it on the other one, you want both
of those to have the certificate on it.

182
00:10:35.490 --> 00:10:41.082
So, take a look at that when you talk
about getting an ADFS certificate.

183
00:10:41.082 --> 00:10:44.350
You have to import that in, and
we'll show you how to do that as well.

184
00:10:44.350 --> 00:10:48.960
Ideally don't forget the placement in the
topology normally is gonna be on the DMZ,

185
00:10:48.960 --> 00:10:54.710
or is gonna be really a true proxy which
you're gonna have two network interfaces,

186
00:10:54.710 --> 00:10:58.920
one inside of your network and
one going outside of the network.

187
00:10:58.920 --> 00:11:03.470
This is not a recommended
configuration in a production network.

188
00:11:03.470 --> 00:11:07.775
So, in other words, if you're working for
a company and you're saying hey,

189
00:11:07.775 --> 00:11:10.595
I'm gonna do this they're
probably gonna say no.

190
00:11:10.595 --> 00:11:13.810
But if you ask them can
I place one in the DMZ?

191
00:11:13.810 --> 00:11:17.080
That's probably gonna be a better
aspect of what you're gonna do.

192
00:11:17.080 --> 00:11:18.650
But what about in a lab setting?

193
00:11:18.650 --> 00:11:22.040
In a lab setting like what
I'm setting up right now,

194
00:11:22.040 --> 00:11:25.400
I did the real proxy server setting.

195
00:11:25.400 --> 00:11:27.920
I put one interface on the public side.

196
00:11:27.920 --> 00:11:31.400
I put one interface on
the internal side as well.

197
00:11:31.400 --> 00:11:35.030
And the reason why is I wasn't gonna setup
another firewall and do all that and

198
00:11:35.030 --> 00:11:38.720
get everything done because
it was just a lab setting.

199
00:11:38.720 --> 00:11:43.000
But in your networking, if you are not
sure about the network configuration, make

200
00:11:43.000 --> 00:11:48.040
sure you consult whoever is actually part
of that network infrastructure team and

201
00:11:48.040 --> 00:11:50.990
tell them,
here's what I need to be able to do.

202
00:11:50.990 --> 00:11:54.290
And then, let them know, and
they'll get it set up for you,

203
00:11:54.290 --> 00:11:59.120
at least help guide you along in what
the next steps are going to be, okay.

204
00:11:59.120 --> 00:12:04.070
So very important types of prerequisites
for us as we get that set up.

205
00:12:04.070 --> 00:12:07.470
So let's take a look at what we
do with this information then.

206
00:12:07.470 --> 00:12:12.680
Now that we have that,
I'm going to simply connect over to my

207
00:12:12.680 --> 00:12:17.380
public DNS registrar, okay,
so mine is hover.com and

208
00:12:17.380 --> 00:12:21.410
I race to that a couple of times here,
but we do a lot of cover.com.

209
00:12:21.410 --> 00:12:23.200
I like it.
It's very easy to work with.

210
00:12:23.200 --> 00:12:24.200
>> And it's free, right?

211
00:12:24.200 --> 00:12:26.721
>> Well, no, hover.com itself is not free.

212
00:12:26.721 --> 00:12:27.294
>> Okay.

213
00:12:27.294 --> 00:12:28.170
We've got to explain this.

214
00:12:28.170 --> 00:12:30.870
>> So this is one you'll pay, okay,
so if you're saying well, Ronnie,

215
00:12:30.870 --> 00:12:33.280
I'm doing this for a lab,
do I really need to do this?

216
00:12:33.280 --> 00:12:34.370
Well, it's up to you, right?

217
00:12:34.370 --> 00:12:36.260
You don't have to do this.

218
00:12:36.260 --> 00:12:41.050
But at the same time, if you wanna get
better at it, register a DNS name.

219
00:12:41.050 --> 00:12:45.300
Just do your whole name as one word,
or something very similar, and

a separate episode and that way we'll

logical as well.

Besides the certificate part

And this is where the wording,

But, for me,

Select the AD FS server, okay, to use for

>> That's what it sounds like to me,

>> That's what would I think, right?

>> Yeah.
>> That this is what has to happen here.

But if you put in the fully qualified

it's going to fail.

Yeah, so go figure.

And the key here is that you have

So this idea of the federation service

So let me scroll back over here to

And in a moment, I was hoping that

Then I'm gonna click on Tools,

So on this one, on the Web Access Proxy

So it's asking me for

Because it's joined to the domain itself,

I know that I can actually use just

00:05:59.739 --> 00:06:05.087
itprotvdemo, I'm gonna backslash.

And for us the administrator is

But to me at least,

00:06:50.057 --> 00:06:53.608
This is the one that I installed

The set-webapplication

So if you don't have this,

00:07:28.776 --> 00:07:29.958

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

The other one, of course, is that

Because even if you don't do

00:07:57.417 --> 00:08:02.348
But if that's already done, it might be

be used just like we did using the set

140
00:08:07.500 --> 00:08:11.400
So those are usually the three elements

00:08:11.400 --> 00:08:15.430
So if that just doesn't show up, I would

00:08:15.430 --> 00:08:20.170

00:08:20.170 --> 00:08:23.950

144
00:08:23.950 --> 00:08:27.070
So right now, you can see here,

00:08:27.070 --> 00:08:28.720

00:08:28.720 --> 00:08:34.510
Ensures the identity of a remote computer,

00:08:34.510 --> 00:08:40.232

00:08:40.232 --> 00:08:42.630

00:08:42.630 --> 00:08:47.380
And there we go, so mine's actually

00:08:47.380 --> 00:08:49.970
So you might be wondering, why 90 days?

00:08:49.970 --> 00:08:51.870
Cuz it's just a-

00:08:51.870 --> 00:08:56.280
>> Yeah, usually they're valid for about
a year is what they're normally valid for.

153
00:08:56.280 --> 00:08:59.800
So just kinda realize you

154
00:08:59.800 --> 00:09:04.689
So that is the one that
you want showing up here.

155
00:09:04.689 --> 00:09:10.048
I click Next, now you can see that
we could've done this all using,

00:09:12.975 --> 00:09:15.855
And that's because in the background
that's exactly what it did using

00:09:15.855 --> 00:09:17.050

00:09:17.050 --> 00:09:21.430
It said, hey you're trying to run
this command when you first selected

00:09:21.430 --> 00:09:25.220
to configure and

161
00:09:25.220 --> 00:09:27.130
Then, it went ahead and said,

162
00:09:27.130 --> 00:09:31.578
you're gonna be setting up the
FederationServiceTrustCredentialSystemMan-

00:09:31.578 --> 00:09:36.190
agementAutomationPSCredentials, and
here is the certificate you're going to

164
00:09:36.190 --> 00:09:40.690
install directly on here and
here's the federation service name.

165
00:09:40.690 --> 00:09:45.590
Believe it or not, fairly easy to actually
get installed even using PowerShell.

166
00:09:45.590 --> 00:09:47.340
Just pay attention to this.

167
00:09:47.340 --> 00:09:51.455
Install dash web application proxy,
and then normally you just do a dash

168
00:09:51.455 --> 00:09:54.569
certificate thumbprint,
put the thumbprint there.

169
00:09:54.569 --> 00:09:57.797
And then, of course, the Federation
Service name and it's off and

170
00:09:57.797 --> 00:09:58.767
ready to go, okay?

171
00:09:58.767 --> 00:10:02.869
All right, so from that point,
I am going to select Configure.

172
00:10:04.533 --> 00:10:07.278
Now in the end here, there's one
of two things that's gonna happen.

173
00:10:07.278 --> 00:10:09.990
It's either gonna tell me,
I can't do it, okay?

174
00:10:09.990 --> 00:10:12.980
Or it's gonna say, hey,
you're successful at doing this.

175
00:10:12.980 --> 00:10:17.220
So this is really kind of the frustrating
place a lot of times because it means

176
00:10:17.220 --> 00:10:20.190
somewhere along the line in
the path of setting it up,

177
00:10:20.190 --> 00:10:23.270
it didn't get set up correctly
if it doesn't happen.

178
00:10:23.270 --> 00:10:25.950
And that's what you have to
actually be able to do here.

179
00:10:25.950 --> 00:10:27.852
So at the end when it's
actually configuring,

180
00:10:27.852 --> 00:10:29.530
it does take a little bit of time.

181
00:10:29.530 --> 00:10:33.620
Because it is now talking with

182
00:10:33.620 --> 00:10:36.955
