183
00:10:36.955 --> 00:10:40.400
But this is kind of the waiting game,
and what we're actually looking for

184
00:10:40.400 --> 00:10:44.380
at the end is either an error
message that we can troubleshoot or

185
00:10:44.380 --> 00:10:47.210

186
00:10:47.210 --> 00:10:48.620
>> And
we had a question in the chat from Doug.

Can you address that now or

00:10:53.830 --> 00:10:56.790
>> The false configuration,
what we're doing right now, no.

190
00:10:56.790 --> 00:10:57.986
This is actually a real configuration.

191
00:10:57.986 --> 00:10:58.797
>> It is, yeah.

192
00:10:58.797 --> 00:11:04.260
>> Yeah, so we're actually setting
this up right now and it just depends.

193
00:11:04.260 --> 00:11:07.860
So right now we're essentially

194
00:11:07.860 --> 00:11:11.089
This is what we are looking for

195
00:11:11.089 --> 00:11:14.425
Web application was

00:11:14.425 --> 00:11:15.666

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to customize the ADFS Sign-In-Page. This allows O365 admins to customize the end-user experience for their needs, according to the team. They describe many options that can be changed and demonstrate how to change some of them using powershell.

topics.title: Implement and Manage Federated Identities for SSO

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie demonstrate some of the different methods to get information about the past history and current health of the O365 tenant. They show where you can find reports within the 0365 portal and used the Service Health Dashboard.
episodes.title: Analyze Reports and Monitor Service Health

So it gives you of course, step by step,
and what you might want to do and

489
00:27:35.959 --> 00:27:39.608
verify that everything is actually
done the way that you need to.

490
00:27:39.608 --> 00:27:42.630
If it solved your issue, you select Yes.

491
00:27:42.630 --> 00:27:43.148
And there you go.

492
00:27:43.148 --> 00:27:45.770
Thank you, congratulations,
your issue was resolved.

493
00:27:45.770 --> 00:27:48.083
>> Yehey.
>> So it allows you to troubleshoot in

494
00:27:48.083 --> 00:27:52.383
that way by simply asking those
questions that are available for

495
00:27:52.383 --> 00:27:54.700
you to be able to go and see, okay?

496
00:27:55.940 --> 00:28:00.760
Now, there is one last tool that
is officially mentioned for

497
00:28:00.760 --> 00:28:06.905
our particular objectives here, which
is gonna be the Microsoft Support and

498
00:28:06.905 --> 00:28:10.706
Recovery Assistant for Office 365, okay?

499
00:28:10.706 --> 00:28:12.160
Go figure, okay?

500
00:28:12.160 --> 00:28:16.130
Microsoft Support and
Recovery Assistant for Office 365.

501
00:28:16.130 --> 00:28:18.927
This one will help you out, okay?

502
00:28:18.927 --> 00:28:22.080
Problems with Outlook itself, okay?

503
00:28:22.080 --> 00:28:25.600
Outlook stops responding,
people can't receive emails,

504
00:28:25.600 --> 00:28:27.817
Outlook keeps trying to disconnect.

505
00:28:27.817 --> 00:28:30.970
Problems with email on your phone, okay?

506
00:28:30.970 --> 00:28:34.727
Problems with setting up
Office apps if you need to.

507
00:28:34.727 --> 00:28:37.221
Or are using OWA,
which they don't call anymore,

508
00:28:37.221 --> 00:28:40.470
It's called Outlook on the Web anymore,
can't sign in.

509
00:28:40.470 --> 00:28:44.355
Or if you're using one of the business
dynamics products that are there, or

510
00:28:44.355 --> 00:28:46.187
business intelligence products.

511
00:28:46.187 --> 00:28:50.680
It gives you all of that help
desk available for you to go.

512
00:28:50.680 --> 00:28:54.627
And you simply download it, and
when you download it you can run it and

513
00:28:54.627 --> 00:28:57.637
be able to do some of those
things that you want to do.

514
00:28:57.637 --> 00:29:02.404
Now, this is gonna be a download really
for Windows itself and not so much for

515
00:29:02.404 --> 00:29:03.910
a Mac computer.

516
00:29:03.910 --> 00:29:07.680
So make sure you are on a Windows
computer if you do this, okay?

517
00:29:07.680 --> 00:29:11.740
But this should again walk you through
a troubleshooter that will allow you

518
00:29:11.740 --> 00:29:16.260
to test those connectivities out and
to do everything that you need to do.

519
00:29:16.260 --> 00:29:19.796
So this one is actually very good and
it's very specific for

520
00:29:19.796 --> 00:29:21.575
us here with some of the ones.

521
00:29:21.575 --> 00:29:25.733
And I would take a look at this website
and even download it onto your Windows

522
00:29:25.733 --> 00:29:28.109
computer and
just take a look at it as well.

523
00:29:28.109 --> 00:29:32.303
If it asks you for an account, make sure
you actually do have a valid Office 365

524
00:29:32.303 --> 00:29:35.390
account and you should be off and
ready to go.

525
00:29:35.390 --> 00:29:39.680
But overall, Zach those are kind of
the basic tools especially when we can't

526
00:29:39.680 --> 00:29:43.379
get connected when there is a service
interruptions that goes on.

527
00:29:43.379 --> 00:29:46.810
All these tools that we've just showed
you right here in this episode should

528
00:29:46.810 --> 00:29:47.408
be helpful.

529
00:29:47.408 --> 00:29:53.366
And you should be make sure you're
familiar with at least what particular

530
00:29:53.366 --> 00:29:59.610
issue aligns with what tool when you
are ready to get set up for the exam.

531
00:29:59.610 --> 00:30:01.170
So, make sure you review them and

532
00:30:01.170 --> 00:30:04.469
make sure you take a look at some of
them that you are not familiar with.

533
00:30:04.469 --> 00:30:05.809
>> Wonderful job, as usual, Ronnie.

534
00:30:05.809 --> 00:30:08.909
Managing Office 365 identities and
requirements, and

535
00:30:08.909 --> 00:30:11.330
this has been isolate
service interruption.

536
00:30:11.330 --> 00:30:11.978
Great episode.

537
00:30:11.978 --> 00:30:16.500
They're all great episodes and
I invite you to watch all those Office 365

538
00:30:16.500 --> 00:30:21.050
episodes, because they're called up in
the end exam and you wanna do that.

539
00:30:21.050 --> 00:30:23.622
And also check out everything
in the course library,

540
00:30:23.622 --> 00:30:27.237
hundreds of other videos and they're
all designed to help you go further.

541
00:30:27.237 --> 00:30:29.370
Tell them what you know about ITProTV too.

542
00:30:29.370 --> 00:30:30.411
They'll be very glad you did.

543
00:30:30.411 --> 00:30:31.730
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

544
00:30:31.730 --> 00:30:32.890
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

545
00:30:32.890 --> 00:30:35.767
>> And we'll see you very soon.

546
00:30:35.767 --> 00:30:41.249
[MUSIC]

547
00:30:41.249 --> 00:30:43.798
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: n this episode, Zach and Ronnie demonstrate some of the steps necessary when you disable adfs and keep password synchonization running.
episodes.title: Disabling AD Federation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.360 --> 00:00:01.340
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.340 --> 00:00:02.170
Im your host.

3
00:00:02.170 --> 00:00:08.301
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.301 --> 00:00:10.975
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:10.975 --> 00:00:15.430
>> Hello and thank you for choosing IT Pro
TV, helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.430 --> 00:00:17.800
I'm your host Zach Memos.

7
00:00:17.800 --> 00:00:23.830
As we continue on with Office 365, in fact
this is a bonus episode of Office 365.

8
00:00:23.830 --> 00:00:25.900
Disabling AD federation.

9
00:00:25.900 --> 00:00:29.560
We built up the federation and
now we're gonna [LAUGH] tear it all down.

10
00:00:29.560 --> 00:00:31.980
And our IT expert Ronnie Wong is
here to help us out with that.

11
00:00:31.980 --> 00:00:33.430
Ronnie, good to see you sir.

12
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:35.790
>> Thank you for
having me back on to the show Zach.

13
00:00:35.790 --> 00:00:39.350
There is no doubt that's exactly
what we are going to do.

14
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:43.830
We are going to pretty much take away
some of the things that we ready build up

15
00:00:43.830 --> 00:00:46.510
from the actual show
that we've been doing,

16
00:00:46.510 --> 00:00:49.380
where at the end of everything
that we talked about, right?

17
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:53.509
Enabling this getting this to work
with our on-premises active directory,

18
00:00:53.509 --> 00:00:57.905
using the federation services as well as
establishing a web access proxy server.

19
00:00:57.905 --> 00:01:02.846
It was a lot to set up, a lot to get done
and some of the things that we had to do,

20
00:01:02.846 --> 00:01:07.090
it did actually involve quite
a few components into it.

21
00:01:07.090 --> 00:01:11.380
But there are times when we are going
to have to just disable this and

22
00:01:11.380 --> 00:01:12.950
to get it working.

23
00:01:12.950 --> 00:01:16.090
So, Zach, when we start to have
to do something like that,

24
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:21.080
we really need to be careful, because it's
not just the idea that I can just go well,

25
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:25.170
why don't I just turn off something and
don't have to worry about it?

26
00:01:25.170 --> 00:01:29.438
We end up breaking stuff and that's why we
wanted to take at least a short episode

27
00:01:29.438 --> 00:01:32.703
here, and talk about the idea
of disabling these services.

28
00:01:32.703 --> 00:01:33.591
>> And not to mention,

29
00:01:33.591 --> 00:01:36.800
there's all kind of dependencies
that could be considered as well.

30
00:01:36.800 --> 00:01:40.350
But, Ronnie, why would we wanna
disable the AD Federation?

31
00:01:40.350 --> 00:01:43.482
>> Well, let's go ahead and talk about it,
cuz that's a good issue for

32
00:01:43.482 --> 00:01:44.947
us to think about and consider.

33
00:01:44.947 --> 00:01:46.684
So let's take a look at my screen here,

34
00:01:46.684 --> 00:01:48.960
I'm gonna show you what
the set-up is currently.

35
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:55.235
Now, you've been watching the Office
365 show, I was about to say 346 show.

36
00:01:55.235 --> 00:01:57.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it is actually 70-346, but

37
00:01:57.660 --> 00:02:01.390
if you've been watching
the Office 365 shows,

38
00:02:01.390 --> 00:02:04.750
you've seen us essentially
build up this model right here.

39
00:02:04.750 --> 00:02:09.790
We first started off in the show where
we just established Office 365 and

40
00:02:09.790 --> 00:02:11.500
added users in there.

41
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:16.278
Once we got that point we've started using
the Azure Active Directory a little bit.

42
00:02:16.278 --> 00:02:21.403
Then we added in of course our domain and
started the idea of doing what we call

43
00:02:21.403 --> 00:02:26.691
a password synchronization using the
Azure AD Connect tool to get us working,

44
00:02:26.691 --> 00:02:30.170
and to get us going in
the way that we want it to.

45
00:02:30.170 --> 00:02:35.360
But even at that particular point
when we take a look at doing that,

46
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:38.130
the only thing that we're
really trying to do, okay.

47
00:02:38.130 --> 00:02:41.640
Was establish what we call
a single sign-on, or technically,

48
00:02:41.640 --> 00:02:45.680
a same sign-on, not exactly
single sign-on, but same sign-on.

49
00:02:45.680 --> 00:02:49.250
And what that means is that there's
an account over here which has got its own

50
00:02:49.250 --> 00:02:53.640
source of authority over
inside of the ITProTV demo.

51
00:02:53.640 --> 00:02:58.793
And then over here of course in your
Office 365 cloud, you have once again,

52
00:02:58.793 --> 00:03:04.123
another Azure Active Directory that is
it's own source of authority, as well.

53
00:03:04.123 --> 00:03:10.590
But by using that synchronization tool,
we matched up accounts, okay?

54
00:03:10.590 --> 00:03:15.140
What was over here,
also got matched up over here as well, and

55
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:17.510
that doesn't mean that
we're using one account.

56
00:03:17.510 --> 00:03:21.398
It means two accounts that
are essentially identical,

57
00:03:21.398 --> 00:03:26.039
so that way as a user logs on,
if he needs access to his on premises.

58
00:03:26.039 --> 00:03:30.000
He's checking against the source
of authority over here, okay?

59
00:03:30.000 --> 00:03:31.851
If he logs on to Office 365,

60
00:03:31.851 --> 00:03:36.050
he's checking against the source
of authority over there.

61
00:03:36.050 --> 00:03:38.700
It doesn't matter that both of
them have the same password and

62
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:42.580
the same username,
they're two separate sources of authority.

63
00:03:42.580 --> 00:03:46.550
And they are synchronized so
that when if a change occurs

64
00:03:46.550 --> 00:03:51.250
over in the on-premises side,
it will actually use the active directory

65
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:57.020
synchronization to sink up and make
sure that it matches over here as well.

66
00:03:57.020 --> 00:04:01.510
So, that way, when we start to do that,
the users end point.

67
00:04:01.510 --> 00:04:04.120
It looks like that they're
really only signing on to

68
00:04:04.120 --> 00:04:07.230
using one account in the very end of it.

69
00:04:07.230 --> 00:04:12.380
But overall though, it is really
established with two, is what we have.

70
00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:15.890
Now, we started realizing something,
even though that can be done and

71
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:18.500
that's probably the easiest
way to manage things.

72
00:04:18.500 --> 00:04:21.200
That way the end user doesn't
get confused about, well,

73
00:04:21.200 --> 00:04:22.690
which password do I need to use?

74
00:04:22.690 --> 00:04:24.710
Which account do I need to use?

75
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:28.897
We just established a format, we tell
them your username is gonna essentially,

76
00:04:28.897 --> 00:04:30.569
going to be your email address.

77
00:04:30.569 --> 00:04:34.716
Your password's gonna be the same, whether
you login to a machine right here in my

78
00:04:34.716 --> 00:04:38.580
domain, or whether you log on to
Office 365, it's gonna be identical.

79
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:42.210
So to them, it's just really
one username one password, and

80
00:04:42.210 --> 00:04:45.530
they don't really careless actually
two separate sources of authority.

81
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:49.020
You and I care, but
they don't really care, okay?

82
00:04:49.020 --> 00:04:52.120
So that's what we started to establish.

83
00:04:52.120 --> 00:04:54.820
But when we started to
say what we want to do,

84
00:04:54.820 --> 00:04:59.270
is we want to use a single source
of authority at this point.

85
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:04.998
That is now when we needed
the Active Directory Federation Services,

86
00:05:04.998 --> 00:05:06.851
or ADFS implemented.

87
00:05:06.851 --> 00:05:11.819
Once we had everything set up,
we went ahead and we configured,

88
00:05:11.819 --> 00:05:15.720
the Active Directory Federation
server itself.

89
00:05:15.720 --> 00:05:20.160
And we showed you how to do that install,
and how that also ended up applying, so

90
00:05:20.160 --> 00:05:22.432
that was the very first step that we did.

91
00:05:22.432 --> 00:05:23.787
Now by doing this,

92
00:05:23.787 --> 00:05:30.170
what really ended up happening is that
when the user was inside the domain, okay?

93
00:05:30.170 --> 00:05:35.852
Then they would go ahead and
login to Office 365, but when they did so,

94
00:05:35.852 --> 00:05:40.711
they were told by Office 365 that
they needed to check in with

95
00:05:40.711 --> 00:05:45.496
their own login server essentially
is what they needed to do.

96
00:05:45.496 --> 00:05:50.027
And they redirects them over to the ADFS
server, and then the ADFS server

97
00:05:50.027 --> 00:05:54.810
checks against your on-premises
Active Directory at this point.

98
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:58.310
And when they actually authorize or
authenticate, they'll say,

99
00:05:58.310 --> 00:05:59.570
yes, he can get in.

100
00:05:59.570 --> 00:06:03.490
And then the ADFS server will issue us
a service token is what it will do,

101
00:06:03.490 --> 00:06:07.370
and will present that so
that we can get access over here or

102
00:06:07.370 --> 00:06:10.350
even access anywhere else
inside of our own network.

103
00:06:10.350 --> 00:06:15.020
So now that's all tied to one account,
now even though that worked for

104
00:06:15.020 --> 00:06:16.310
users inside a domain.

105
00:06:16.310 --> 00:06:18.441
I don't have it let me put
somebody inside that domain.

106
00:06:18.441 --> 00:06:21.473
>> [LAUGH]
>> So even though that would actually work

107
00:06:21.473 --> 00:06:25.419
for a user inside the domain,
it doesn't necessarily work for

108
00:06:25.419 --> 00:06:29.748
users outside of the domain if I
don't have a web proxy setup either.

109
00:06:29.748 --> 00:06:34.850
A web proxy allows me to establish a
boundary so that the person on the outside

110
00:06:34.850 --> 00:06:40.440
of the network, does not have direct
access to internal resources here.

111
00:06:40.440 --> 00:06:44.580
So with that web access proxy set up,
he stands in between

112
00:06:45.670 --> 00:06:50.820
where he has an outside interface and
possibly an inside interface as well.

113
00:06:50.820 --> 00:06:54.453
Now that's a true proxy,
most of the time in a production network,

114
00:06:54.453 --> 00:06:57.021
we're not gonna ever set
anything up this way.

115
00:06:57.021 --> 00:07:00.960
In the lab environment, this is
exactly how we have it set up, okay?

116
00:07:00.960 --> 00:07:01.734
So with this,

117
00:07:01.734 --> 00:07:06.330
here's essentially the way that it would
be done inside the reproduction network.

118
00:07:06.330 --> 00:07:10.549
We would have a firewall or multiple
firewalls in this way, where there,

119
00:07:10.549 --> 00:07:13.452
of course, is the public network outside.

120
00:07:13.452 --> 00:07:18.307
Office 365 out on the internet,
hover.com, let's say that we're also

121
00:07:18.307 --> 00:07:22.279
connected to another partner
network somewhere else as well.

122
00:07:22.279 --> 00:07:24.255
And then we have our firewall,

123
00:07:24.255 --> 00:07:29.730
that sets us off to three separate
network locations through the firewall.

124
00:07:29.730 --> 00:07:32.703
So we put our
Active Directory Federation server or

125
00:07:32.703 --> 00:07:36.376
at least this time,
what we would actually call our web proxy,

126
00:07:39.060 --> 00:07:43.034
Our Web Proxy server out here
in what we call a DMZ and

127
00:07:43.034 --> 00:07:46.739
that way it is exposed
to the external traffic.

128
00:07:46.739 --> 00:07:48.985
But even when it communicates internally,

129
00:07:48.985 --> 00:07:52.210
it still has to go through
the firewall for protection as well.

130
00:07:52.210 --> 00:07:55.015
So you can do it this way, or
you can set up two firewalls,

131
00:07:55.015 --> 00:07:57.760
it's just up to your network and
how that's done.

132
00:07:57.760 --> 00:08:01.539
Now you might be wondering,
what does all of this do for us?

133
00:08:01.539 --> 00:08:05.291
It now allows for the outside user
when they want to go to Office365.

134
00:08:05.291 --> 00:08:09.979
If I have traveling sales people,
I have people that are always, you know,

135
00:08:09.979 --> 00:08:14.800
they're always on the go, and
they're not always inside the office.

136
00:08:14.800 --> 00:08:19.059
It allows them to be able to take their
laptop wherever they go when they access

137
00:08:19.059 --> 00:08:20.670
Office365.

138
00:08:20.670 --> 00:08:26.870
Office365 essentially redirects them, and
they hit a proxy server instead, the proxy

139
00:08:26.870 --> 00:08:31.680
server will actually either allow them
to connect them to the ADFS or it won't.

140
00:08:31.680 --> 00:08:33.430
That's pretty much the idea.

141
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:36.500
So we don't need a proxy server if
the only people that are gonna connect in,

142
00:08:36.500 --> 00:08:39.740
are only from my internal network.

143
00:08:39.740 --> 00:08:42.446
But if I'm needing a balance of both,
external users,

144
00:08:42.446 --> 00:08:47.010
as well as internal users connecting in,
then I will need to do that.

145
00:08:47.010 --> 00:08:50.809
So now that I've got that setup,
all that setup, to disable this, yes.

146
00:08:50.809 --> 00:08:52.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now, you might be wondering why?

147
00:08:52.900 --> 00:08:57.020
Why would we ever disable something
like this once we get it set up?

148
00:08:57.020 --> 00:09:00.210
Well, think about all
the pieces involved here, okay?

149
00:09:00.210 --> 00:09:04.370
Even in this basic diagram, don't get me
wrong, it's a little bit complicated.

150
00:09:05.630 --> 00:09:09.440
On my end, in other words, what I'm
responsible for, I'm not Microsoft, but

151
00:09:09.440 --> 00:09:13.580
what I'm responsible for and
what my team is responsible for,

152
00:09:13.580 --> 00:09:17.580
web proxy server, as well as the DNS
records that I have to manage.

153
00:09:17.580 --> 00:09:22.910
The ADFS, the Actual Federation Server
itself, my entire domain and all this

154
00:09:22.910 --> 00:09:27.650
stuff that's going on there, or any one of
those components that ends up breaking in

155
00:09:27.650 --> 00:09:32.900
this chain of things, it means somebody's
not gonna be able to access the resources,

156
00:09:32.900 --> 00:09:37.130
internally, nor out on Office 365.

157
00:09:37.130 --> 00:09:41.850
So if something internally breaks,
such as the ADFS server, well,

158
00:09:41.850 --> 00:09:44.790
now I don't have two separate accounts.

159
00:09:44.790 --> 00:09:48.860
It is Office 365 is redirecting them,
and they're looking for

160
00:09:48.860 --> 00:09:51.500
that service token,
that's all they're looking for.

161
00:09:51.500 --> 00:09:56.790
Well, if I can't issue out a service token
because the ADFS server is broken, well,

162
00:09:56.790 --> 00:10:00.290
that's why it might be a consideration
that we have to think about.

163
00:10:00.290 --> 00:10:03.300

No, of course, it's ADSyncCycle,

00:10:03.410 --> 00:10:05.337
Initial means full, okay?

00:10:05.337 --> 00:10:07.473
That's what we really want here, okay?

176
00:10:07.473 --> 00:10:12.574
So at this point,

00:10:12.574 --> 00:10:18.759

And in theory, okay?

00:10:24.262 --> 00:10:26.059

183
00:10:36.240 --> 00:10:41.150
So the great thing is this one does

184
00:10:41.150 --> 00:10:44.897
But if I wait two to five minutes,

00:10:44.897 --> 00:10:47.984
I type in the delta and

186
00:10:47.984 --> 00:10:52.640
it means I have actually successfully

187
00:10:52.640 --> 00:10:56.334
If I get an error, it means somewhere

188
00:10:56.334 --> 00:10:58.725

189
00:10:58.725 --> 00:11:01.963
So at this point here,

00:11:01.963 --> 00:11:04.715
All right, so now I'm going to connect and

00:11:37.330 --> 00:11:38.941

00:24:42.580 --> 00:24:44.120
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

433
00:24:44.120 --> 00:24:45.100
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

434
00:24:45.100 --> 00:24:47.457
>> And we'll see you again soon.

435
00:24:47.457 --> 00:24:53.056
[MUSIC]

436
00:24:53.056 --> 00:24:55.010
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss rights managements basics. They discuss the problems that companies face protecting email and documents.  Then, they discuss how Rights Managment provides a solution for protecting our data, regardless of who receives the data, where it resides and technology available.
episodes.title: Document and Email Protection
episodes.transcript:

Protecting our data using

And we showed where just implementing this

and that's what we think about, right?

33

Is using some type of

But in the end result of this though,

And the problems that we have of course is

So we're gonna take in a high level,

So first and foremost here

one of the issues happens to be,

And what I mean by that

It's just that when we think about,

I wouldn't worry about that,

The other one though that comes

Data custodians are the ones that

The problem is that is shifts though,

So, it might be Zach is an executive at

the company,

Or he doesn't mark it and he goes,

Well, how does the data custodian

really guarded as being secret and

which is just public information?

If Zach forgets them then he comes out and

I don't know why you don't understand

00:04:56.310 --> 00:04:58.150
I'm an executive of this company,

everything that I say is

Well, now you're actually putting that on

So, they have to make that decision

So in that sense, even custodians,

And that means it's gonna be inconsistent

And this is where we also have

So those problems, and
those issues arise from, well really,

the idea of assumption on Zach's part,

as an executive of just saying,

He should absolutely know that everything

absolutely protected,
encrypted with whatever do.

I shouldn't have to worry about it,

Well, then he sends out a happy

And Zach calls that's silly,

Well, but

he's having to make that decision and

Use your best judgment, well, then at that

So, there are issues that we have to deal

Which really shouldn't reside in the data

>> Right, now the other issue that may

address of course, as far as email and

is the technology that we put in place

Now in that particular

we have to worry about all the technology,

Not only where does the data reside right

So I might be able to protect

Well now, it becomes inconsistent.

Or, we move on to those devices

These particular devices in which

So we have to worry

On networks tend to guard the perimeter,

That's usually how we do it,

So that's where we had that.

>> Well, yeah,

Well, inside then we'd have to use kinda

Maybe some type of access control policy.

It maybe where we implement

So there are policies

That's where were heading is that

>> So even though

Now we move into the realm that we've

Now, some of those

So this is where it becomes

Turn on the management of things up in

now we've got a couple of

Complexity levels that we've add in.

So there are many problems

that we can think about
when it comes down to

protecting especially things like our
data, like our documents, and our email.

175

Now, the system that we're talking about,
okay?

176

That we've also shown in
the show really does kind of

00:10:05.940 --> 00:10:10.260
help us in every aspect of what we're
dealing with even on something like this.

178

But it's real effort of what we're talking
about,of course is rights management when

180

But this is actually kind of a key
aspect of something that we do need to

Is all the protections we've

As far as protecting data, it helps, but

It is really about protecting

It is about protecting the data

Encryption, okay, is the only one that's

And even encryption has its own problems,

>> The very fact is somebody can steal

00:10:54.940 --> 00:10:57.520
So, Zach, somewhere in between
somebody could make a copy of it.

And then I send it,
they make a copy of the data.

00:10:59.290 --> 00:11:02.670
They can unlock the key as well

193
00:11:02.670 --> 00:11:06.660
So, even encryption itself
can have some issues.

194
00:11:06.660 --> 00:11:12.410
So we addressed it in the show when we
used Azure Rights Management to help us

195
00:11:12.410 --> 00:11:16.310
out And we showed where you can implement
some type of encryption And that was

196
00:11:16.310 --> 00:11:20.250
a part of it and that's really kind of the

197
00:11:20.250 --> 00:11:24.351
But it really is just a small sliver
of some of the things that we have to

00:11:24.351 --> 00:11:25.076
do, okay?

199

But we also have to realize something,

200
00:11:27.487 --> 00:11:31.220
that even though there
are problems that are there.

Those are not the only thing that we

00:11:35.135 --> 00:11:37.030

203
00:11:37.030 --> 00:11:41.000
And that is the realm of what we call
business requirements that we may

actually think about too.

So let's take from the example here, the
example that is used with Zach just for

In that particular example,

okay, where Zach is saying,
here is the protected email.

Well, what if Zach actually
sends an email and

Well now let's say that Ronnie

And now,
what does Ronnie do with that email?

Okay, he might just go I'm gonna forward
